REVISED AND EDITED BY

LONDON:
STEVENS & SONS, 119, CHANCERY LANE, E.C.

Held on Monday, April 28th, 1879, and following days,

BEFORE THE RIGHT HON. SIR CHARLES WHETHAM, Knt., LORD MAYOR of the City of London; The Hon. Sir
JOHN MELLOR , Knt., one of the Justices of the Queen's Bench Division of the High Court of Justice; The Hon. Sir JAMES FITZJAMES STEPHEN, Knt., one of the Barons of the Exchequer Division of the High Court of Justice; THOMAS QUESTED FINNIS, Esq., Sir

HENRY JAMES GODDEN , Esq.,
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT.
WHETHAM, MAYOR. EIGHTH SESSION.

A star (*) denotes that prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been more than once in custodyâ€”an obelisk (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age.
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

515.
ARTHUR TROOP (41)
PLEADED GUILTY to feloniously forging and uttering five post-office orders for the payment of 1s., 1s. 1s. 1d. and 1d. respectively, with intent to defraud, he having been previously convicted on the 20th of May, 1878, at Westminster.â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

516.
DAVID WILSON (33)
to stealing, whilst employed in the Post-office, a post letter containing two sovereigns and 60 penny postage stamps, the property of
Her Majesty's Postmaster Generalâ€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

517.
JAMES BURRELL METCALFE (19)
to a like offence.â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

518.
JOHN SMITH (25)
PLEADED GUILTY * to feloniously uttering counterfeit coin.â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

519.
CORNELIUS HICKEY** (41)
to unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.â€”
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

520.
PERALCE COSTELLO (29) was indicted
, with
William Williams and
George Adams, who Pleaded Guilty last Session (See-page 6), for uttering counterfeit coin, having other counterfeit coin in his possession.

ESTHER SPRING . I am barmaid at the Bull Inn Tap, Aldgateâ€”on March 26th I served Williams with a glass of stoutâ€”he gave me a bad florinâ€”I called the barman's attention to it, who broke it in half in the prisoner's presenceâ€”we gave him one half and kept the other half, and gave it to the policemanâ€”the prisoner then asked for another glass, and gave me a good half-crownâ€”I gave him the change, and then he had another glass and paid with 1 1/2 d.â€”when he left I followed him.
WALTER BASE . I manage the Bull Inn Tapâ€”Spring called my attention to a bad florinâ€”I asked the prisoner where he got itâ€”ho said that he did

not knowâ€”I asked if he had any more; he said" No"â€”I broke the florin in half, kept one piece, and gave him the otherâ€”after he was served again I went out and followed him about 20 yards round the corner, where be touched Costello on the shoulder, who was standing still, and who then fol-lowed him 40 yards down Middlesex Street, they joined and walked side by side, and then turned into a place which is no thoroughfareâ€”they came out in about 10 minutes, and I followed them into Bishopsgate Street, and at Houndsditch they came upon Adams, who was standing at the cornerâ€”I saw them putting their hands together, and Williams, I think it was, received some change, but I could not see itâ€”they seemed to be hiding each otherâ€”they walked down Liverpool Street side by side, and I pointed them out to Cusickâ€”I followed Adams and pointed him out to Foster, who took him, he ran away going to the station, but he was brought backâ€”I gave the broken piece of florin to Cusick.

THOMAS CUSICK (City Policeman 880). On March 26th Bass called my attention to the three prisoners, who were in conversation in Liverpool Streetâ€”they separated, and I followed Costello and Williams, and said to Williams, "Where is the two-shilling piece you uttered at the Bull Tap?"â€”he said, "I have not got it, I left it at the public-house"â€”I said, "Hare you any more on you?"â€”he said "No"â€”I said, "I shall take you both in custody, for I believe you have counterfeit coin in your possession"â€”Lord came up, and we took them to the stationâ€”I searched Williams, and found a good half-crown, and Costello had a good florinâ€”I saw 15 bad florins, 28s. 4d. in silver, and 3s. 4 1/2 d. in bronze found on Adams.

Cross-examined. You said at the station, "I know nothing about either of the prisoners; I met them and asked them the way to the Great Eastern Railway; remember, there is no bad money found on me"â€”when you and Williams were close together, your coat was hanging on the bar in front of the dock; it had been taken off to search youâ€”Adams was about a yard offâ€”I do not say that he attempted to put anything into your coat.

Re-examined. I took two of them into the charge-room togetherâ€”I had hold of Costello, and Lord of Williamsâ€”they did not both go in at the same time, but they were close together, and I believe Costello was firstâ€”I do not think one of them would have attempted to pass anything to the other without my seeing itâ€”Lord was nearer to Adams than I was, and between Costello and Adamsâ€”I was standing between Adams and Costello, and Williams was alongside of Costello-three officers stood behind three pri'soners, but they moved in the dock as they were searchedâ€”I got to the station with my prisoner first, and the others were brought in five to seven minutes afterwards.

JOHN LORD (City Policeman 960). I took Williams in Liverpool Street, and said "I shall take you to the station"â€”he said "Very good nâ€”I saw him take his left hand from his left trousers pocket, and said "What have you there?"â€”he said "Never mind what I have got"â€”I held his hand, he opened it and gave me this bad florin (produced)â€”he and Costello were placed in the dock ten minutes before Adams came inâ€”Costello was put into the dock first on the right and then shifted, and Williams was put to the far end of the dock to be measured; Costello was then brought back to his first place on the left, and after he was searched his coat was left hanging on the rail of the dock; Adams was then brought from the muster room into the charge room, where the dock is, and as he entered I

saw his right hand in his right-hand trousers pocket, and he tried to pass these 11 bad coins (produced) into Costello's coat, which was hanging thereâ€”I took them from his hand and gave them to Fosterâ€”Costello was looking at him and could see him do it; he was between Adams and Williams, in the centre.
Cross-examined. I mentioned the coins on the first occasion before the Magistrate, but forgot to say anything about your coat till the second remand.

WILLIAM FOSTER (City Policeman 122). Bass called my attention to Adams; I followed him into Blomfield Street and said "I am informed that you have got some bad money in your possession, I must take you in custody; you will have to go with me to the station"â€”he said "Me got bad money 1 pooh! pooh! I am quite ready to go with you"â€”in Bishopsgate Street he ran across the road, I ran after him, and he was stopped almost directlyâ€”I took him to the station, and as I was about to search him, Lord handed me this packet containing 11 counterfeit coins, which he said he had taken from him, and on further searching him I found a packet con-taining these four bad florins in his coat tail pocket, and 1l. 8s. 1d. in silverâ€”I heard Lord on the third remand make a statement about money passing from Adams to Costello.
Cross-examined. I did not see anybody put money into your coat.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . I am in the employ of the Mintâ€”this is a portion of a bad florin, and this fragment found on Williams is bad and from the same mouldâ€”these 15 coins are bad, and two of them are from the same mould as the formerâ€”they were all mixed together when I saw them.

Costello's Statement before the Magistrate. "On the afternoon of 26th I met this man, Williams, and asked him to show me the way to the station; he went into a public-house, I waited for him; he came out, touched me by the coat, and said "Come on." We went together to Liverpool Street, where the policeman took us in custody. He is a perfect stranger to me."

WILLIAM WILLIAMS . (The Prisoner). On the afternoon of 26th March I met Costello at the corner of Houndsditch; he said "Which is the way to Liverpool Street station?"â€”I said "Wait a minute, I am only just going down here, and I will show you when I come back"â€”I then went into the Bull tap, where I tendered the florin, and when I came out I saw him waiting, and I said "Now, come on, I will show you"â€”we then went down Middlesex Street and down a labyrinth of turnings, and finding there was no thoroughfare we had to come back again, and took the most direct way to the stationâ€”we met Adams and I spoke to him while Costello stood byâ€”I' said "Come on," and went down the station to show him the road he wanted, because there are two, and going down the incline we were accosted by a constable, who charged us with passing counterfeit coinâ€”Costello said "I have no coin, you can search me if you like"â€”he knew nothing what
ever of the errand I was going on to the public-houseâ€”I was charged with uttering counterfeit coin, and about ten minutes afterwards Adams was brought inâ€”that was the first time I ever saw Costello in my. life.

Cross-examined by MR. CRAUFURD. I met him about twenty yards from the corner of Houndsditch, between the church and the Bull tapâ€”I did not explain to him where I was goingâ€”Costello took no notice while I spoke to

Adamsâ€”Adams passed something to me; it was a counterfeit florin, and it was found on me when I was takenâ€”I do not believe Costello saw it pass; he might have been looking that wayâ€”Adams went away; he only went two or three steps with usâ€”Costello was on my right and Adams on my leftâ€”we had no conversation about these pieces.
GEORGE ADAMS . (The Prisoner). On the afternoon of 26th March Costello and Williams came up to me at the top of Houndsditchâ€”Costello had no conversation with meâ€”I had never seen him before.

Cross-examined. I passed something to Williamsâ€”Costello was then on the other side, not near me; I do not think he saw what was passed, I should not allow himâ€”it was between Liverpool Street and the churchâ€”we could not see the railway station from that corner; it is near the end of Liverpool Streetâ€”if you cross over at the corner of Liverpool Street you can see the station.

p.hi: The Prisoner in his defence stated that he had only been nine weeks in London; that he met Williams and asked him the way to Liverpool Street Station, who said that he was going there; that he waited for Williams while he went into a public-house, and that afterwards they met Adams, but that until then both prisoners were strangers to him.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

521.
PERALCE COSTELLO was again indicted
for unlawfully having counterfeit coin in his possession, with intent to utter it, upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: ADAMS **â€” Twelve Years' Penal Servitude.[Both defendants were tried and had their judgements respited in the last session. See p.6]

div1.p:
522.
ELLEN WALTERS (30)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
MESSRS. CRAUFURD and LLYOD prosecuted; MR. MONTAGU WILLIAMS Defended.

ESTHER SKEEF . My husband keeps an oil and colour shop at 6, John Street, Maryleboneâ€”on Saturday night, 3rd May, about 9.15, I served the prisoner with some soap and soda, which came to 4 1/2 d.â€”she gave me a florinâ€”I gave her the change and she leftâ€”I had laid the florin on the counter, and it was not out of my sightâ€”I showed it to my husband, who said it was badâ€”I went out and saw the prisoner being served in Mr. Harvey's shop, about five minutes' walk offâ€”I saw her pass a coin, and said "You have been into my shop and paid a bad 2s. piece"â€”she said "No, I am a respectable married woman, and my husband is waiting outside"â€”Mr. Harvey said that the coin was badâ€”she said she-was not aware of itâ€”â€”he sent for a policeman, and she was given in charge.

Cross-examined. I did not see her in the street before she went into Mr. Harvey'sâ€”she was 100 yards in front of me when she went inâ€”I did not say before the Magistrate, "I don't think I have mistaken the prisoner for some one else"â€”I followed her from her general appearance.

Re-examined. I did not notice her dress, but she had a quantity of hair down her back and a black hatâ€”I stood at the door watching her, and saw her side faceâ€”I believe she wore a black dress, and I noticed her styleâ€”the coin first laid on the counter, and then my husband had it in his hand.

FREDERICK GEORGE SKEEF . I am the husband of the last witness, and saw her serving the prisoner, who passed me when I was turning on the lights outsideâ€”I also saw her come out, and saw which way she wentâ€”she
had a black silk dress; I am sure the prisoner is the womanâ€”my wife showed me a bad coin; I took possession of it.

BENJAMIN HARVEY . I keep an oil and colour shop at 53, Crawford Street, Maryleboneâ€”on 3rd May, between 9 and 10, the prisoner bought soap, pepper, and other things, which came to 5 1/2 d.â€”while my daughter was serving her Mrs. Skeef came in and said to her, "You have been in my shop and paid a bad 2s. piece"â€”she said, "l am a respectable woman, and my husband is outside"â€”my daughter handed*me a florin, and I bent it in the tryer and said, "Well, at all events this it a bad one"â€”the prisoner said, "If it is I am Act aware of it"â€”I gave her in custodyâ€”this is the florin (produced); it is bent.

LUCY HARVEY . I assist in my father's shopâ€”on 3rd May, between 9 and 10 p.m., I served the prisoner with some soap and other things, which came to 5 1/2 d.â€”she began counting coppers first, and then said she had not enough, and handed me a florinâ€”I was counting the change, but did not hand it to the prisoner, as Mrs. Skeef came in and stated that the prisoner had passed bad money in her shopâ€”I then handed the florin to my fatherâ€”the prisoner denied being in Mr. Skeef's shop, and said that her husband was outside, but she did not call him inâ€”my father found the coin was bad and gave her is charge with the coin.
Cross-examined. When I took the florin I put it on the counter just above the tillâ€”I never mixed it with any other coin.

MATHEW HILL (Policeman D 40). I was called to Mr. Harvey's shop, and said to the prisoner "Where did you get the money from?" she said she took it from the till before she left homeâ€”it was then said that she had been in Mr. Skeef's shop in John Street, and passed somethingâ€”she said "No, I was not in John Street at all to-night"â€”I took one coin off the counter, and Mrs. Skeef fetched the otherâ€”going to the station the prisoner said "I am a respectable woman and my husband is waiting to take me home by train; I have come to do my shopping"â€”she said at the police-court "I and my husband had a word or two tonight and I said I would go home alone"â€”she is married.
Cross-examined. She gave a correct name and address, and I found that her husband is a gasfitter and bellhanger in Westbourne Park.

FREDERICK BONNER (Police Sergeant D 20). I took the charge at the stationâ€”the prisoner said "It is untrue respecting the woman; I gave the man a two-shilling piece, but did not know it was bad until he told me so"â€”I found this purse in her hand with three half-crowns, a florin, a threepenny piece, and 2 1/2 d. in bronze in it, all good, and she had this empty basket.

Cross-examined. The shilling and the threepenny piece were in a com
partment shut up by themselves.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These florins are both badâ€”there is a good deal more tin in them than would be used by gasfittersâ€”the coins do not soil when the metal has been overheatedâ€”it is grain tin.
Cross-examined. Counterfeit coins are generally made from pewter pots, but there is tin in most of them.
The Prisoner received a good character.
NOT GUILTY .

523.
JAMES ARMITAGE and
ROBERT PEARCE,
Unlawfully failing to discover to their trustee in bankruptcy a sum of 4,000l., part of their estate. Other Counts for not discovering other sums of money to the trustee. The Prisoners
PLEADED GUILTY, to the latter Counts .â€”
Judgment Respited.

524.
ARTHUR JAMES LANGE (20)
, Unlawfully making a false declaration to a registrar of marriages.

MR. THORNE COLE
Prosecuted; MR. PRITCHAR Defended.

JOSHUA DOWLING . I am deputy superintendent registrar of births, deaths, and marriages for the district of Chelseaâ€”I produce the original declaration made by Arthur James Lange on his marriage with Sarah Ann Hibbert at my office, dated 24th January, 1878â€”he describes himself as 21 years of ageâ€”I was one of the witnesses to his signatureâ€”I do not recognise the defendantâ€”the declaration was filled up by meâ€”he gave me the particularsâ€”I read it over to him; it is my invariable practice to do so, so that I am sure I did it in this case.
Cross-examined. I have no recollection whatever of this particular caseâ€”the lady is described as 22 years of ageâ€”the declarent gave me the particularsâ€”I don't remember either of the parties.

HENRY SANSOM . I am the registrar of marriages in the Chelsea districtâ€”I have an entry in my register-book of a marriage on 26th of January, 1878, between Arthur James Lange and Sarah Ann Hibbertâ€”it is my own writing (Read)â€”the marriage was by licenceâ€”I have it hereâ€”the parties signed the register.
Cross-examined. I have not the slightest knowledge of the partiesâ€”the fathers of both parties were stated to be dead.

REGINALD LEMPRIERE . I am now residing temporarily at the British Hotel, Cockspur Streetâ€”I did reside at 8, Melina Place, Grove End Road, N.W., up to a recent periodâ€”I had a 21 years'lease of the house; the furniture was mineâ€”I came into negotiation with the defendant as to taking my house and furnitureâ€”I was on the point of going abroadâ€”I received one or more letters from him, and I have seen him writeâ€”I recognise his handwriting in this declarationâ€”I believe the signature to be his, also the signature in the register.

Cross-examined. He signed his name at my house when he was in nego
tiation with me; that was the only time I ever saw him writeâ€”I had never seen him before that negotiationâ€”he proposed to take a lease of my house, with the option of purchasing the furniture in 18 months for 450l.â€”I agreed to that on the faith of the representations he made to meâ€”I have been called to the Barâ€”I practised for a short time; I have never had the good fortune to put questionsâ€”the agreement was put into a formal shape by my solicitor, duly executed, sealed, and deliveredâ€”the rent was to be 16l. a month, paid in advanceâ€”7l. was paid for coal and other thingsâ€”the defendant went into possession of the house on the lease and agreementâ€”he did not pay the 16l. the day he went in; he did within a day or twoâ€”the March rent was paid, and the April and May rent was tenderedâ€”I never wanted to get the money for the furniture paid downâ€”on March 20th I wrote to him requesting him to give up possession and pay the costs of the lease before the Thursdayâ€”that was after I had seen him and asked whether he was a minorâ€”I got information on that subject about a week after he went into the houseâ€”on 23rd I wrote, stating, "I am willing to make an

effort to settle the question at issue between us;" that was, that he should turn out of the house and give me back possession; that was the only ques
tion between usâ€”I also said, "If you think you are able and are also willing to promise to pay me the amount of the purchase-money, 450l., on the 10th of next month, and will undertake to come to an arrangement with Messrs. Todd and Dennis for the costs in the course of to-morrow, I, on my part, am willing to hand you over the lease and place confidence in your bond fides in the whole transaction"â€”I had ascertained about his minority 10 days before thatâ€”if he had done what I asked he would have remained my tenant, I don't know about not hearing of this prosecutionâ€”I told my solicitors if he did not give up possession they were to issue a writ in Chancery to set aside the leaseâ€”I wrote to him on March 29th that it he would pay the 450l. and the costs I would accept him as tenantâ€”I had had a personal interview with him thenâ€”he told me he was coming into 6,000l. from his trustees.

Re-examined. He told me that he was under ageâ€”I presented a cheque to him, which was not honouredâ€”I told him I had come to speak to him about a complaint that his neighbours had made to me, that they were an
noyed by himself and his wife calling "Murder?" and using bad language in the garden, and the smashing of crockeryâ€”I showed him the cheque and said I hoped he would go and settle the matter with my solicitors, it was very unpleasant not to have the costs paid as he had stipulatedâ€”he had given this cheque for themâ€”he said, "It will be all right, I will go and see my solicitor, and it will be settled at once"â€”I then asked him whether he was of ageâ€”he looked confused and said he was notâ€”he said, "I know you cannot bind me, but I can hold you"â€”before he went into possession I saw the certificate of marriageâ€”if I had known he was a year and ten months under age I would not have allowed him to go into the placeâ€”he told me had 200l. a year, and his wife had 20l. a week from her fatherâ€”I subsequently heard him swear that he was a person of no means whateverâ€”that was at the Marylebone Police-court.

By MR. PRITCHARD. Yesterday evening I saw Mrs. Lange, the prisoner's mother; she has come here under subpoenaâ€”I did not ask her to com
promise the matterâ€”I did not say that I only took these proceedings for the purpose of getting Mr. Lange to buy the furniture, thinking he would settle the matterâ€”I did not say if she would guarantee me 60l. and all expenses that I would withdraw from this prosecutionâ€”I said I hoped it would not be necessary to take the affair to trialâ€”I said if they would make me a proper restitution of my property I should be very happy indeed to with-draw from the prosecution as far as possible; I was extremely sorry to prosecute him, and it went against me to do soâ€”I did not say that I did it on public groundsâ€”I said if her son had come forward at any time when the matter was at the police-court and offered to restore me my property and make me proper amends for the damage and loss he had caused meâ€”the cheque that was dishonoured was for 18l. for Todd and Dennis's charges for preparing the lease and inventoryâ€”it was an order on Mr. Jenkins, the prisoner's solicitor, and Mr. Jenkins said he had no cash. Witness for the Defence.
MARY ANN LANGE . I am a widow and live at Newcastle-on-Tyneâ€”I am the prisoner's motherâ€”he was born on 9th October, 1858â€”his father's
name was Carl Frederick Henry Langeâ€”I do not know when he was marriedâ€”I am one of the trustees under my husband's will.

Cross-examined. I do not approve of this prosecutionâ€”I knew of my son's marriage soon afterwardsâ€”I have allowed him 100l. a yearâ€”my eldest son is the acting trusteeâ€”the prisoner will come into some property in October; I cannot tell the amountâ€”Mr. Lempriere spoke to me yesterday; he said if the trustees would guarantee the rent for the 21 years, or give him a sum of 601. and pay all expenses, he would be glad to stop the case.
NOT GUILTY .

525.
WILLIAM ALFRED PHILLIPS (21)
PLEADED GUILTY to stealing 304l. of
Alfred Pontifex, his master.â€”
Eighteen Months' Imprison
ment. And

526.
ALEXANDER JONES (41)
to stealing 2 1/2 d. from the person of
James Holmes, having been before convicted.â€”
Three Months' Imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

527.
GEORGE STANNARD (18)
, Robbery with violence on
William Philip Bacchus.

MESSRS. POLLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS Prosecuted; MR. THORNE COLE Defended. WILLIAM PHILIP BACCHUS. I am a compositor and live at 15, Ever
sholt Street, Oakley Squareâ€”on 1st December, at 11.20 at night, I was in Seymour Street, Euston Square, going homeâ€”I was overtaken by three men, one of them took hold of my right wrist and one of the left; I thought at first they might be friends of mineâ€”the third man was behindâ€”I received a push somehow or other in the struggleâ€”I had a kick or blow "on the ankle and fell downâ€”I was dragged along the pathwayâ€”I felt the hands of the two men in my pockets, and I lost 14s. or 16s., a tobacco pouch, and a knifeâ€”I became insensibleâ€”when I came to I found myself at the hospitalâ€”my leg was broken and my foot was afterwards amputatedâ€”I saw the two men at my side, I could not see the one behind me.
Cross-examined. I said at the police-court "I cannot say which of the three men kicked me; I could not see the prisoner; one of the men was behind me."

HENRY MCCALL . I am a chairmaker and live at 54, Clarendon Streetâ€”on the night of 1st December, about 11.30, I was going along Seymour Streetâ€”I saw the prisoner and two others standing round Mr. Bacchus, who was lying on the pavementâ€”I gave evidence here in February, when two of the men, Wainwright and Phillips, were triedâ€”I saw Wainwright and Phillips drag Mr. Bacchus across the road, and the prisoner following about 2 yards behindâ€”I saw Wainwright put his hand in Mr. Bacchus's right-hand pocket; some money dropped outâ€”Mr. Bacchus fell down with his foot under himâ€”the prisoner picked up some of the money, and gave a private whistle, and Wainwright left Mr. Bacchus and went down Charles Street with the prisonerâ€”the other two men went down Charles Streetâ€”I assisted Mr. Bacchus, and he was taken to the hospitalâ€”I saw nothing more of the prisoner till he was in custody on 26th Aprilâ€”I then saw him at the House of Detentionâ€”I have no doubt he is the man.

Cross-examined. When I first saw Mr. Bacchus he was sitting on the groundâ€”I was walking along on the other side of the streetâ€”the two men put their hands in his pockets as they dragged him alongâ€”I and Phillips

took him to the hospitalâ€”I can't say the day I saw the prisoner in the House of Detentionâ€”one of the detectives in the case took me thereâ€”I was taken to seven different cellsâ€”one of the warders opened the doors for meâ€”the police constables were not near me, they were downstairsâ€”I had no conversation with the constable on the wayâ€”when I saw the prisoner in the cell I said he was the man.

Re-examined. The warder took me to the different cells, and opened one at a time; the prisoner was the last of the seven; I recognised him directlyâ€”on the night in question I was looking at him about a quarter of an hour, I stared at him quite hardâ€”I thought they looked rather suspicious characters.

JOHN GILBY (Policeman Y 472). I know the prisoner very wellâ€”I also knew Phillips, who was convicted in February; he was known as Bob Phillipsâ€”I did not know Wainwright till that timeâ€”on Sunday night, 1st December, about 11 o'clock, I was on duty in Euston Road, and saw Phillips, Wainwright, and the prisoner standing at the corner of Seymour Streetâ€”they went along Seymour Streetâ€”I had known Phillips and the prisoner before as companions.
Cross-examined. I gave evidence on the trial of Phillips and Wainwrightâ€”I then said, "I noticed three men standing at the corner of Seymour Street; I know two of them."

Re-examined. The two I knew were Phillips and the prisonerâ€”I was not able to find the prisoner till he was taken into custody. Charles Dodd (Police Inspector Y). On 22nd April I took the prisoner into custody at the Grecian Theatre on another chargeâ€”as we were in the cab he said, "What do you want me fori is it for that affair with Boh Phillips? if so I don't think you will do much with that; it is too far back"â€”I said, "No, it is for breaking into dwellings in the parish of Marylebone"â€”I knew him before, and Phillips alsoâ€”I have seen them together many timesâ€”he also said in the cab, "Mr. Dodd, I have 14l.; can you be squared? take 7l. and let us get out of the cab"â€”I made no reply to thatâ€”Otway was with me In the cab, and the prisoner said to him "Take 8l.; won't that do, Otway"â€”Otway replied, "Not for 80."

Cross-examined. Underwood was also in the cabâ€”I took McCall to the House of Detentionâ€”I told him the name of the person who was in custodyâ€”I did not accompany him to the cellâ€”a warder took him round. John Otway (Police Sergeant Y). I was with Inspector Dodd, the prisoner, and Underwoodâ€”the prisoner said he had lit, in his pocket, and asked us if we could be squaredâ€”Dodd made no answerâ€”he then looked across to me, and said "Will you take 8, Otway?"â€”I said "Not for 80." William Henry Copley. I was house surgeon at University College Hospital when Mr. Bacchus was brought there with a fractured foot; it. afterwards became necessary to amputate it.

CHARLES DODD (Re-examined). The charge against Wainwright and Phillips was robbery with violenceâ€”Wainwright was sentenced to six months' imprisonment with hard labour, and Phillips to two years with hard labour.
GUILTY (See Third Court Thursday).

528.
LOUIS LAMPHFER (28)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

GEORGE UPWARD . I keep the Cranbourne Tavern, St. Martin's Laneâ€”on 26th April, about 12.15 am., the prisoner came in and asked my sister for a pint of 4d. ale; he gave her a half-crown; she turned to me and said in his presence, "This is a bad half-crown, is it not?"â€”I said "Yes," and took it from her, bent it in the tester, and told the prisoner I could not take itâ€”he gave me another bad one without taking up the firstâ€”I said "This is bad likewise"â€”he made no reply, and I gave him in custody with the coinsâ€”my sister is not well and cannot appear.

JOSEPH HAMMERTON (Policeman C 281). The prisoner was given into my custodyâ€”I searched him on the spot, and found 2d. on himâ€”he then said, "Well, I know I had one bad half-crown; if I have any more about me somebody must have put them in my pocket"â€”he gave an address which I cannot findâ€”I received these coins from Upwardâ€”the prisoner appeared to have been drinking, but he knew perfectly well what he was about.
WILLIAM WEBSTER These two half-crowns are bad, and from the same mould.

p.hi: The Prisoner in his Statement before the Magistrate, and also in his Defence, said that he received the coins for gridirons which he sold in the street, and did not know they were had.

div1.p:
GUILTY .**â€”
One Year's Imprisonment.

529.
WILLIAM WILSON (37)
, Feloniously uttering counterfeit coin.

SAMUEL HUGH M'REA . I am a draper of 47, Ossulton Street, St. Pancrasâ€”on 30th April, about 6.30. the prisoner came in and said, "I want a cheap pair of socks"â€”I showed him some marked 2d., and he put down a florin; I took it up and pitched it farther on the counter for my wife to give change, which she did, and the prisoner leftâ€”I saw my wife put it into the till, and having a little suspicion went to take it out, and found three good florins and this bad one (produced), which had a peculiar ring, and I kept it in my pocketâ€”I had noticed the same ring when the prisoner tendered his florin, but being busy did not stop to examine itâ€”the prisoner came again the next evening, about 6.30, and said, "I want a cheap towel"â€”I said "I have none; can I serve you with anything else?"â€”he said "No," and left the shopâ€”I walked to the door and saw him cross the road and recross; I followed him to Phoenix Street, where he turned the corner and joined Esther Webster (See next case)â€”they went through Clarendon Street into Skevington Street, where the prisoner went into Mr. Williams's, a tobacconist, and Webster crossed the road and stood on the opposite side waiting at a shop windowâ€”Wilson was in the shop some time; he came out, but went back and came out again in a minute or so and joined herâ€”I went into Williams's shop and made a communication, and followed the

two prisoners into Eversholt Streetâ€”they were both'walking together; Wilson left Webster, and went into Mr. Secombe's shop, and Webster waited ten or twelve doors awayâ€”I spoke to Wtrd, and we went to Mr. Secombe's shop, and as Wilson came out we went inâ€”I afterwards went with Ward to Mornington Crescent and saw the prisoner join Websterâ€”they went to Arlington Road or Street, Webster a little in advance, and a constable detained the prisoner, and told me to stay with him while he went after the woman, who had got a few yards distantâ€”I stayed with the prisoner, who said "What does this all mean?" or "What is it for? I don't understand"â€”I said "You will know when the constable brings the female prisoner back"â€”when he brought her back the prisoner said, "I do not know her or any one for miles round"â€”he volunteered thatâ€”I said, "I charge him with attempting to pass bad money"â€”he said, "I cannot under
stand what it is about"â€”I gave the coin to the inspector.

Cross-examined. I could not charge you with the offence on April 30, but I should have detained you if you had passed a bad coin on 1st May; I could not say that the first coin was the one tendered by you.

CHARLES WILLIAMS . I am a news agent and tobacconist, of 14, Steb
bington Streetâ€”on 1st May, about 6.46 p.m., my wife served the prisoner with some tobacco; he put down a florin, she gave him the change, and he leftâ€”my attention was called to the coin, and I found it was badâ€”I went out and tapped him on his shoulder; two minutes had not elapsed; I said "You are wanted back in the shop"â€”when I got him backâ€”my wife said, "This is a bad one"â€”he said "I was not aware of it; I am very sorry"â€”she said "It is, and you must give me that money and the tobacco back"â€”he did so, and said he had not done any work for seven weeks, and it was all the change he had gotâ€”he took the florin backâ€”I examined the edge of it, and did not approve of the stamp on the edgeâ€”it was not marked, and I should not know it againâ€”I did not ring itâ€”M'Rea came in two minutes afterwards and spoke to me, and I went out and came back with a constableâ€”I afterwards identified the prisoner at the station.

ANN WILLIAMS . On 1st May the prisoner gave me a florin for half an ounce of tobaccoâ€”I gave him 1s. 10d. change, and put it in the till, but I had no other thereâ€”I found it was bad a few minutes afterwards, and spoke to my husband, and the prisoner was called backâ€”I told him he had given me a bad florinâ€”he said that he was very sorry, but he was not aware of itâ€”he gave me my change back and the tobacco, and I gave him the florinâ€”I tried it with my teethâ€”I cannot identify this florin, but there is a small mark on it.

MARION MARCHANT . I am assistant to Mr. Secombe, a draper, of 33, Eversholt Streetâ€”on 1st May, between 6 and 7 p.m., the prisoner came in and said "I want two pairs of paper cuffs"â€”I served himâ€”they came to 1d.â€”he put down a florinâ€”I took it to Mrs. Secombe, who said to bin? "Have you any smaller change?"â€”he said "Have you any twopenny three farthing towels?"â€”she said "I have some at 3 3/4 d."â€”he said "Then I will take one," and asked for some pins for the farthing, as the articles amounted to 5 1/2 d.â€”she gave him the change, one shilling and a halfpenny in copper and a sixpenceâ€”as he went out a constable came in, and Mrs. Secombe handed him the florin.
MARTHA MARY SECOMBE . My husband is a draper, of 33, Eversholt Streetâ€”on 1st May, about 6.30 p.m.; Miss Marchant gave me a florinâ€”I

did not like the look of it, but could not swear that it was bad, so I said to the prisoner "Have you smaller change?"â€”he said "No; have you any cheap towels?"â€”I said "What price?"â€”he said "2 3/4 d."â€”I said "No, I have some at 3 3/4 d.," and unpacked a parcel with them in; he had pins for the odd farthing, and the whole amounted to 5 1/2 d.â€”I gave him in change for the florin, 12 pence halfpenny in copper and a sixpenceâ€”directly he left I compared it with the only florin in the till, and while I was doing so a policeman came in and M'Rea behind himâ€”I handed the florin to the constableâ€”I noticed teeth marks on it when I took it, and M'Rea made some more.

JAMES WARD (Policeman S 104). On 1st May, about 7 p.m., M'Rea spoke to me and I went to Mr. Secombe's shop and saw the prisoner thereâ€”he came out and I went in, received this florin, came out again, and saw the prisoner walking up Mornington Crescent, and Webster two yards in advance of himâ€”I said "I want you"â€”he said "What for?"â€”I said "I will tell you in a moment"â€”I told M'Rea to stop with him while I went after Webster, who kept walking onâ€”I stopped her and took her back, and then said to the prisoner "I shall take you to the station for uttering counterfeit coin," and charged her with being concerned with himâ€”he said "I don't under
stand anything about it, I have never seen this woman before"â€”she said "I have never seen him before, he is a total stranger to me"â€”I took them both to the station, and found on Wilson 1s. 1 1/2 d. in bronze, a sixpence, a knife, some towels, and a packet of pins.
EMMA CHOPPER , I searched Webster at the station, and found 3s. 7 1/2 d. in good money.
>WILLIAM WEBSTER. These florins are bad, but not from the same mould; bad coins are greased, to discolour them and take off the brightness.

The Prisoners Statement before the Magistrate. "The witness M'Rea says I was in his shop on the 30th, and uttered a two-shilling piece in pay
ment for socks. That is quite false. I was in the shop on 1st May, but not on 30th April. The female prisoner is a stranger to me, I never saw her before. She was not with me when I was arrested, she was brought from the top of the street and I was arrested at the bottom."

The Prisoner in his defence repeated the same statement.
GUILTY . He was further charged with a previous conviction of feloniously uttering counter
feit coin in February, 1877, to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

530.
WILLIAM WILSON was again indicted, with
ESTHER WEB
STER (30)
, for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin. The same Counsel prosecuted, and the witnesses in the last case were recalled and their former evidence was read over to them by the shorthand-writer.

JAMES WARD (Policeman S 104). I said to Webster "I want you"â€”she said "What for?"â€”I said "For being concerned with a man in uttering counterfeit coin"â€”she said "What man?"â€”I said "Come back with me and I will show you"â€”when she saw Wilson she said "I have never seen that man before"â€”she said nothing about having been with any other man.

Webster's Statement before the Magistrate. "I do not know the man, I never saw him before in my life. I had an appointment at 8 o'clock in Park Street, Regent's Park, and was walking about Somers Town to pass the time away, and walked across Mornington Crescent to get into Park Street;
when I was three parts up the street the policeman came behind me and took me, and I told him I had never seen the man before."

Webster's Defence. I am an unfortunate woman; I had an appoint
ment and I was three parts up the street when the policeman stopped me. I never had any bad money to my knowledge.

WILSONâ€”
GUILTY . (See last case.)

WEBSTERâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
six Months' Imprisonment.

531.
CHARLES HART** (21)
PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin after a previous conviction of felony at Newington in Novem
ber, 1877.â€”
Eighteen Months'Imprisonment . And

532.
JOHN CLAXTON
to stealing a gelding, the property of
John Black, who recommended him to mercy.â€”
Nine Months' Imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

533.
MARY ANN WEBB (28)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

ALICE ELLEN TOWSER . I am a telegraph clerk at the Post-office, Clapham Commonâ€”on 18th March, between 5 and 6 p.m., the prisoner came and said "Three shillings in penny stamps," and put down a florin and a shillingâ€”she kept her hand over the money while I was getting the stamps, and when I gave them to her she pushed the money forwardâ€”as she was leaving I saw that the florin was bad, and asked a person there to stop herâ€”she was brought back, and I called Miss Pricker, who said "You must have known it was bad;" she said nothingâ€”I gave her back the shilling as that was goodâ€”she was given in custody.

JULIA MATILDA FRICKER . I am clerk in charge at the branch Post-office, Clapham Commonâ€”I received a florin from the last witness, on 18th March, after the prisoner was brought inâ€”it was obviously bad, it was dark and a very bad get upâ€”I said to the prisoner "You have passed a counterfeit florin"â€”she said "It is not bad"â€”I said "It is such a bad get up you must have known it was counterfeit, a child would have known it was counter
feit"â€”I took a penknife and cut the edge; she repeatedly said "I did not think it was a bad one"â€”I said "Where do you live?"â€”she said "In Westminster"â€”I said "What part of Westminster?"â€”she said "Near Victoria Station, near the music hall and the public-house"â€”I said "Can't you tell me the name of the street you live in?"â€”she said "I don't know the name of it"â€”I gave her in charge with the florinâ€”she said "Oh, don't, dear lady, give me in custody."

WILLIAM MORRELL (Policeman W 172). I took the prisoner and received a bad florin, it was light and very dullâ€”she said nothingâ€”the female searcher at the station afterwards gave me 1s. 1 1/2 d. good moneyâ€”the only address the prisoner gave was "Westminster"â€”she was taken before Mr. Paget, at Wandsworth, remanded till the 26th, and then discharged, and Mr. Paget threw the florin in the fireâ€”I have never seen that done before.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. A pawn ticket was found on you for half a crown in the name of Mary Ann Webb.

JAMES MASON . I am a baker, of 38, Chapel Street, Belgrave Squareâ€”on 28th April my cousin gave me this bad florin (produced), and I went into the shop and said to the prisoner "This is a bad two-shilling piece"â€”she said "A friend of mine gave it to me outside, I will go and find her"

â€”she put down two rolls and went out; I followed her to the corner of Chapel Street, whero a man and woman joined herâ€”they conversed for about a minute, the man then went towards Hyde Park Corner, and the prisoner said to the woman "Have you seen Mrs.â€”?" I did not catch the nameâ€”the woman said "She has gone this way," and we walked towards Victoria Stationâ€”the woman left about Wilton Streetâ€”I walked by the prisoner's side as far as Hobart Place, where she stood still and said two or three times "What are you going to do with me?"â€”I said nothing at first, and then said "I will give you in charge," having sent for a constable who came, and I gave her in charge with the florinâ€”she gave two or three different addresses.
Cross-examined. It was impossible for me to stop the three of you, and I did not want the man, I wanted you.

MARIA MASON . I serve in Mr. Mason's shopâ€”on 28th April, about 4.30, I served the prisoner with two penny rollsâ€”she give me a florin, it was very black; I tried it with my teeth, found it soft, and said "It is a bad one, where did you get it?"â€”she said "It belongs to my mistress, round the corner"â€”I did not know herâ€”I gave it to Mr. Mason, he spoke to her, she left and he followed her.

GEORGE HARE (Policeman B 335). I saw Mr. Mason and the prisoner standing, together in Hobart Placeâ€”he called me across and said, "I give this woman in custody for passing bad money; here it is"â€”she said, "They were not with me"â€”I took her to the station, where the female searcher gave me a purse with a half-crown and a sixpence in itâ€”I asked the prisoner her addressâ€”she said, 16, Victoria Street, or Victoria Road, just which you like.
FRANCES WAIN . I am female searcher at Cottage Road stationâ€”I searched the prisoner and found on her a half-crown and a sixpence good.
WILLIAM MORRELL (Re-examined). This coin resembles the one which Mr. Paget destroyed in the dulness of the colour.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . This florin is bad; it is of a bad colour, and I have no doubt if I had had the other one here I could have proved that they were made by the same personâ€”there is a great deal of lead in it, and being of a similar colour, the presumption is that they were the same mixture.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I did not know the man the baker saw me speak to; the woman did, but I did not."
Prisoner's Defence. Each of the persons from the Post-office is telling a lie. I only had 1s. 0 1/2 d. The female searcher ought to be here.

GUILTY .**â€”
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.

534.
CHARLES GRIFFITHS (21)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit corn.
MESSRS. CRAUFURD and LLOYD Prosecuted.

JOHN SULLIVAN . I am errand boy to Mrs. Jones, 4, Down Street, Picca
dillyâ€”a little after 8 p.m. on April 29th I was in Windmill Street with a boy named Tidman, and the prisoner called me over to him and said, "Will you go into that little shop and get half an ounce of tobacco for me?"â€”he was standing by the public-house, and the tobacconist's is next doorâ€”he pro
duced a couple of halfpence, but kept them back and gave me a florinâ€”I went and got the tobacco and tendered the florin to a little girl in the shop, who showed it to Mrs. Gardner in the parlourâ€”she came into the

shop, and I went to the door in consequence of what she said, and looked for the prisoner, but he had goneâ€”I told her I could not see him, hut afterwards he passed by and went into the public-house next door and lit his pipe, and Mrs. Gardner went in with me and accused him of itâ€”he said that he knew nothing about it, and came out and went round the corner of the Jews' streetâ€”we followed himâ€”he went under a doorway, and we gave him in custodyâ€”I did not notice Tidman outside when I went out. Francis Tidman. I live at 15, Little Windmill Streetâ€”I was talking to Sullivan on the night of April 29th in Windmill Streetâ€”the prisoner came across to Sullivan and said something about tobaccoâ€”I think he said, "Will you go and get me half an ounce of tobacco"â€”I saw his face wellâ€”I waited outside the shop when Sullivan went in, and the prisoner walked up and down while I was looking into a paper shopâ€”he came backâ€”Sullivan pointed him out, and he went into the public-houseâ€”after he came out, Sullivan, Gardner, and I followed him till he was given in custodyâ€”I had only lost sight of him while he was in the heershopâ€”he kept on walking up and down about the length of this Court, passing me while I was looking into the paper shop.

ELLEN GODDARD . I serve at Mrs. Gardner's shopâ€”on the evening of April 29th I served Sullivan with half an ounce of tobacco, which came to 1/2 d.â€”he gave me a florinâ€”I put it in my teeth and it grindedâ€”I called Mrs. Gardner because she had taken two bad ones before. Sophia Gardner. I am the wife of Charles Gardner, a tobacconistâ€”on the evening of April 29th my little girl gave me a bad coinâ€”Sullivan was there, and I asked him where he got itâ€”the prisoner passed the door, and the boy pointed him out to me as. he came out of a public-houseâ€”I said to him, "This is a bad two-shilling piece"â€”he said, "I did not give the lad the two-shilling piece, and I have not seen the lad"â€”I sent for a constable, and did not lose sight of the prisoner from the time I first spoke to him till I gave him in custodyâ€”he told the constable he had never seen the boy beforeâ€”I gave the florin to the policeman.

GEORGE NEAL (Policeman C 64). Mrs. Gardner gave the prisoner into my custody with this bad florin (produced)â€”he said that he knew nothing about it, but Sullivan said that he sent him for half an ounce of tobaccoâ€”I found on the prisoner 1 1/2 d. and the tobaccoâ€”I asked his address; he said, "I have got no home."

Cross-examined. You asked the boy to give a description of the person who uttered the florinâ€”he said that he knew it was you by your black and white scarf, but that the person who gave it to him had corduroy trousersâ€”you had brownish moleskin trousers.
Re-examined. His trousers looked a good deal like corduroy.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This coin is so bad that any one would see it.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I emphatically deny any knowledge of it or of the boy either."

Prisoner's Defence I went into the public-house to have a smoke, and the boy looked in and accused me. I did not go away because I knew nothing about it. In the darkness of the night the boy must have been mistaken.

GUILTY .â€”
Nine Months' Imprisonment.

537.
HENRY MEYER (29)
PLEADED GUILTY ** to unlawfully obtaining by false pretences 14 watches and other goods from
Arthur Paillard and others, and
to forging and uttering two orders for payment of 19l. and 27l. 10s. 6d., with intent to defraud, he having been previously convicted of felony.â€”
Two Years' Imprisonment.

538.
GEORGE SHERBORNE (44)
, Unlawfully within four months of his bankruptcy obtaining from
Samuel Brewer and others certain pianos, and disposing of them otherwise than in the ordinary course of his trade.
MESSRS. M. WILLIAMS and LYON Prosecuted; MR. POLLOCK Defended.

HENRY ALFRED STACEY , I am Superintendent of Records of the London Bankruptcy Courtâ€”I produce the file of proceedings in the case of George Sherborne, and the petition for liquidation, dated 20th August, 1878, which was duly presented on 20th August in the Bankruptcy Court at Newcastle, Northumberlandâ€”they are signed in the usual way by George Sherborne. George Blagrave Snell, I am one of the official shorthand writers to the London Court of Bankruptcy, and attended the examination of the prisoner on 15th January, 1879, before Mr. Registrar Pepys, and took down the questions put to him and his answersâ€”the transcript on the file of proceedings is correct.

FREDERICK LUCAS , I am a public accountant at 20, Great Marlborough Street, and was on the 13th September, 1878, appointed trustee of the estate of the prisoner at a general meeting of his creditors held at Messrs, Curtis'sâ€”he handed me this book.(produced) with others, and' my clerk, Mr. Sutton, took possession of the estate for meâ€”the book contains entries of pianos received from manufacturers and the cost pricesâ€”I find an entry of Messrs. Kirkman's pianos; the two last preceding the bankruptcy petition of 20th August are April 15th, a walnut cottage, 30l., and July 2nd, two walnut cottage pianos, 60l., and underneath is written, "My acceptance due January, 1879"â€”I find an entry 26th July, Samuel Brewer and Co., two walnut full cottage 48l., two truss pianos, 46l., and one pianet 19l., total 113l. (all-in pencil)â€”there was only one of Brewer's pianos in the shopâ€”he gave me no explanation how he had disposed of the other pianosâ€”I went through the books with him to. attempt to trace the pianos, but could not, and was obliged to give it upâ€”I found an entry (in pencil), July 10th, of the purchase from Ralph Allison of a rosewood coloured piano 26l., walnut piano 25l. 15s., and written underneath, "By per due 27th July 52l.," and May 2nd, Broad wood, a rosewood cottage piano 33l. 10s., and two ditto on May 3rd, and underneath, written by the traveller, a receipt for bill of exchange thereforâ€”the last entry in 1878 of purchase from Cadhy is June 6th, two rosewood cottages 49l. (10s. crossed out in pencil); 26th June, two rosewood cottages 49l. (10s. struck out in pencil)â€”I was present at the prisoner's examination in bankruptcy, and an order was made for his prose
cutionâ€”I do not think I found any of Allison's pianos in stock, but my clerk will produce the inventory.

Cross-examined. I do not suggest than any pianos received by the prisoner were not entered in the bookâ€”there were plenty of pianos entered of Kirkman'sâ€”page 1 begins "Ralph Allison, June 15th, 1872"â€”I should

not go further back than that dateâ€”there were entries of dealings with Collards, Mitchells, Wallace, Russell, Barnett, Samuels, Laing, Cocks, Kelly, Hopkinsons, Arthur Allison, and Broadwoodsâ€”there are two Allisons, Ralph and Arthurâ€”there is an entry here, Arthur Allison, 1878, July 8th, a walnut cottage 24l. 10s., and July 10th ditto, less 5 per cent, discouut, 2l. 9s.; settled as per receipt; by cash 46l. 11s., July 10, 1878â€”I did not see any entry here of Tolkienâ€”I find in the banker's book, Tolkien, June 8th, 60l., and 82l. paid to Wallace on the 15th June; 49l. 14s. 6d. to Laing on the 14th June; Arthur Allison, 47l. 15s. on the 18th; Kelly, 81l. 7s. 6d. on the 15th, and 10l. on the 19th; Brewer, 46l., June 17th; Kirkman, 100l., July 2nd; Kelly, 50l. 15s., July 3rd; Hopkinson, 16th July, 65l. Har-bottle, 24th June, 69l.â€”the last payment is "Self 40l., Clarke 69l. 7s. 6d."â€”I did not investigate the tea business; there was noneâ€”I made an appointment with the prisoner with my clerk to go through the stock of pianos with the invoices which had been, supplied to me from the various creditors, and we tried to trace them in. the books for two hours, but found it hopelessâ€”I cross-examined him, and he told me he had sold them, but did not tell me to whomâ€”he said he had sent them to Leeds, Scarborough, and Glasgow, to be sold by auctionâ€”he gave me no satisfactory explanationâ€”it appears to be the fact that he did send them there to be soldâ€”ho produced the bank book and all the books in his possessionâ€”the information he gave turned out to be trueâ€”he told me nothing that has turned out to he untrue, and I have not discovered that he kept anything from me.

Re-examined. I have not added up the amount of his purchases within four months before his bankruptcy petitionâ€”I have not been able to trace or identify from his books the pianos delivered to him within that time.

RICHMOND. I am in the employ of Messrs. Brewer and Co., pianoforte manufacturers, 23, Bishopsgate Street Within, and have been in their employ for the last nine yearsâ€”the prisoner was a customer and we supplied him to order on the 18th June with two walnut pianos, numbered 11648 and 11653, at 23l. each; and on the 6th July two walnut pianos, numbered 11470 and 11523, at 24l. eachâ€”I saw the pianos packed, addressed, and put into the vanâ€”no money was received for them to my knowledgeâ€”another walnut piano, 19l., was invoiced on the 6th July and dispatched from the warehouse on the 8thâ€”when the last three were sent we had received an intimation that there was something wrong, but I did not know he was selling by auctionâ€”that would not be an ordinary way of dealing.

Cross-examined. We knew when we sent the three last pianos he was a little "shaky;" that his business was not so good as it had beenâ€”I don't know what credit he receivedâ€”it might be six or twelve months; that would be an arrangement with the travellerâ€”the order came from the" traveller and I executed itâ€”the firm has dealt with the prisoner ever since I have been there, about 10 yearsâ€”I do not know to what extent, I have nothing to do with the financial departmentâ€”as far as I know the extent of his dealings may have been 1,000l.â€”I did not know the instruments were to be sold by auction or we should not have supplied them.

EDMUND STARKETY . I am a member of the firm of Starkey and Harland, auctioneers, Scarboroughâ€”the prisoner arranged with me for the sale of pianos on the 19th July, 1878, and I sold them in our sale room and

produce the catalogueâ€”they were new instrumentsâ€”the names of the makers on the catalogue were Kirkman, Broad wood and Son, Allison. Brewer, Cadby, "Wallace, and a harmonium by Dresserâ€”there were two by Brewer and one by Kirkmanâ€”one of Brewer's pianos, 11470, was sold to Mr. Hackers for 17l.; and another, 11523, to Mr. Sisson for 19l.â€”the Kirkman piano, No. 3134, was sold to Mr. Dove for 20l. 10s.; and the harmonium by Dresser to a Mr. Mitchell for 8l.â€”a piano by Broadwood (No. 50576) was sold to. Mr. Scariott for 23l.; and one by Cadby (No. 19347) to Mrs. Small wood for 18l. Cross-examined. July is the beginning of the season at Scarborough, and pianos would be likely to sellâ€”business was good and a fair number of people attended the auction, which was extensively advertisedâ€”our auction room is in Burton's Walk, a very public placeâ€”the prisoner's name did not appear on the placards, but the names of the makers did appearâ€”there were two of Kirkman's in the placard, but only one sent us for sala William Dove. I am a monumental sculptor at Scarboroughâ€”I attended Starkey and garland's sale of musical instruments on the 19th July, 1878, and purchased a new piano by Kirkman for 20l. 10s. numbered 31344; the last figure 4 was covered by a ticket! pasted over, making it appear 3134.
EDWARD HACKERS . I am a painter at 66, Eastborough, Scarborough and attended this sale on 19th July, 1878, and purchased a piano (No. 11470) by Samuel Brewer for 17l.

ROBERT NAYLOR SISSON . I am a coal merchant at 94, Westborough, Scarborough, and attended the sale on the 19th July, 1878, and purchased a new piano by Brewer and Co (No. 11523) for. 19l., and I sold it after
wards at a profit.
HARRIET SMALLWOOD . I reside at 64, Trafalgar Street West, Scarboroughâ€”I attended Starkey and Harland's sale on the 19th July, and purchased a piano by Cadby, No. 19349, for 18l., quite new.

CHARLES HENRY DUNSTER . I am. one of the trustees carrying on business as Kirkman and Son, 3, Soho Square pianoforte manufacturersâ€”the prisoner has been a customer of the firm for tour or live yearsâ€”we supplied him on credit on July 2nd with two walnut pianos, Nos. 31058 and 31344 for 31l. 10s. eachâ€”the order was received from our traveller, Mr. Sherwoodâ€”the prisoner owed the firm about 430l. on the filing of his petition for liquidationâ€”we did not know he was selling them, by auction, and it is unusual to sell new pianos by auction.

Cross-examined. We object to pianos being sold by auction, because it spoils our country trade, and we do not like there being hawked aboutâ€”we do not ask purchasers what they are going to do with pianosâ€”the prisoner has been our customer since 1873â€”4 and his dealings may have amounted to 1,000l.

EDWARD LATHAM . I am cashier to Kalph Allison and Sons, pianoforte manufacturers, 108, 109, and 110 Wardour Streetâ€”we supplied the prisoner within four months of August 20th with nine pianos, and have not been paid for them; they were numbered 19664, 19700, 19685, 19727, 19710, 19858, 19754,1977 and 1998, total value 232l., 15s.â€”the last supplied was July 20th.

Cross-examined. They were sold to him at 12 months' creditâ€”we had done business with him about six or seven years, and had extended the credit with him the last two yearsâ€”we have sold him about 89 instruments,

which would come to about 200l. a yearâ€”his transactions were smaller at first, but increased graduallyâ€”he owes us over 500l.â€”acceptances were given and dishonoured; they were not all due at the date of his bankruptcy, and I do not know if any were dishonoured before the bankruptcyâ€”he had paid his acceptances until then, but a great many were runningâ€”two years ago he asked our traveller to extend our credit, and we did so.
Re-examined. His debt when he failed was 509l. 7s.

CHARLES CADBY . I am a pianoforte manufacturer at Hammersmith Roadâ€”I "supplied the prisoner on the 6th of June, 1878, with two rosewood pianos, 19656 and 19661, invoiced at 24l. 10s., and two similar pianos at the same price, Nos. 19347 and 19300â€”we had no idea they were to be sold by auctionâ€”it is not usual in the trade to sell them by auction.

Cross-examined. No piano dealers sell by auctionâ€”I believe Kelley and Co. do, second hand onesâ€”I see their sales advertisedâ€”I do not think they are advertised as second handâ€”they are large dealers, but I know nothing of their businessâ€”I know they are auctioneers and sell off collections of old pianosâ€”I have dealt with the prisoner about six years, and his transactions from the beginning are about 600l.â€”I will not swear they were not more than 1,000l.â€”we do not ask purchasers what they are going to do with the pianos, but we should not sell them if we knew they were to be sold by auction, as we do not like them being hawked about, and it depreciates the value of our instruments.

ROBERT FULTON . I am a clerk to Messrs. Broadwood and Son, piano
forte manufacturers, 23, Great Pulteney Streetâ€”the prisoner is a customer of the firm, and we supplied him with instruments between 20th May and 20th August lastâ€”on the 2nd May, 1878, we supplied him with seven pianos, Nos. 5371 to 5377, invoiced at credit priceâ€”he owed us 107l. at the time of his bankruptcyâ€”we should not have supplied them if we had known they were to be sold by auction.
Cross-examined. We do not inquire what is going to be done with themâ€”we should object to their being sold by auction irrespective of the prices obtained.

CHARLES EDWARD SCARLETT . I am a flower dealer at Scarboroughâ€”I attended Starkey and Harland's pianoforte sale on the 19th July last, and purchased a Broadwood, No. 5376, for 23l.â€”it was apparently new.

CHARLES WINTER . I am clerk to Mr. Tolkien, pianoforte manufacturer, 51, King William Streetâ€”the prisoner is a customer and was supplied on the 19th July, 1878, with two pianos, Nos. 78142-43, at 23l. each, on creditâ€”we had no idea they were to be sold by auctionâ€”that is not the ordinary course for a dealer.

Cross-examined. We have dealt with him three or four yearsâ€”I have been at Mr. Tolkien's seven yearsâ€”the prisoner has not to my knowledge dealt with Mr. Tolkien 14 years, but he may have done soâ€”we do not ask people what they are going to do with pianos.

MORITZ KEYSER . I am manager and traveller to Mr. Laing, importer and dealer in musical instruments, 13 and 14, Kimberley Streetâ€”we received orders from the prisoner between April 20th and August 20th, 1878, and supplied him with goodsâ€”at the time of filing his petition he had not paid for them, and owed us 114l. 7s. 6d. for two pianos and a harmonium supplied on the 22nd April, 1878, and a harmonium on the 19th June.

Cross-examined. I did not know they were going to be sold by auctionâ€”the prisoner, in November, 1877, told me on my visit to Newcastle that he had and sale on his own premises to counteract a neighbour who was selling by auctionâ€”I knew subsequently of his selling by auction at Glasgow, and I sent my brother down to get his account settled, and told him to solicit further orders, and not to mention that I knew anything of his sale at Glasgow, in order to get payment of one or two of the prisoner's bills due in about three weeks after.

GEORGE TILT YOUNG . I represent the firm of Hardwick and Young, auctioneers, Leedsâ€”by the prisoner's instructions we sold some pianos by auction on the 30th July, 1878â€”we sold a piano by Kirkman to Mr. Bentley.
Cross-examined. The sale was advertised in two papers, and bills were printed and posted up giving the makers' names.
Re-examined. The prisoner's name did not appear.
MR. BENTLEY. I attended the sale at Leeds and bought a piano by Kirkman, No. 31058, for 28l.

JAMES HARDMAN SMITH . I am a member of the firm of Smith and Sheard, Edinburgh, and by the prisoner's personal instructions we sold pianos by auction on 1st June, 1878â€”we had sold by auction for him previously at the end of Aprilâ€”the names of the makers advertised in April were Collard and Collard, Kirkman, Hopkinson, Ciceroni, Ralph Allison, Cox and Co., and Wallace; and in June: Allison, Broadwood, and Collard and Collardâ€”we sold about 12 or 14 in April, and six or seven in June.
Cross-examined. The sales were advertised in two or three local paper, giving maker's names, and there were catalogues.

JAMES WALLACE . I am manager to my father, a pianoforte manufacturer, at 133 and 135, Euston Roadâ€”I know the prisoner as a customerâ€”we supplied him on the 11th June, 1878, on credit, with two walnut pianos, Nos. 1882 and 1884, at 22l. 10s. each; and a 14-stop harmonium, No. 12355, for 20l. 15s., and have never been paidâ€”we had no idea they were to be sold by auction.

Cross-examined. We have some idea what is going to be done with pianos when we sell themâ€”we have asked on various occasions, but have not asked the prisonerâ€”if a man comes to open an account he gives references, and if an auctioneer I should take it he was going to sell them by auction and should not supply himâ€”we have dealt with the prisoner four or five yearsâ€”I will not swear it is not 14 years, but I do not think soâ€”I think he never owed us more than the 609l. due at the time of his petitionâ€”his transactions during the time he has dealt with us would amount to as much as 5,000l.

HENRY ALFRED STACEY (Re-examined). The total amount of the prisoner's indebtedness is 4,180l., of which 4,083l. is due to pianoforte manufacturers in Londonâ€”his assets are 946l., according to the statement on his own estimate.
FREDERICK LUCAS . I have made an estimate of the assets of this estateâ€”speaking from memory, I think it is about 350l.

Cross-examined. I mean the present valueâ€”I have made no estimate of the assets at the date of the petitionâ€”I have received' nothing like that sumâ€”he may have offered 3s. 6d. in the poundâ€”I attended meetings of creditors,
but cannot distinctly remember such an offerâ€”if made it was without security.

MR. POLLOCK submitted that there was no evidence of any false pretence on the part of the prisoner. He had carried on a legitimate business for 20 years, and no false representation was proved or any evidence of an intent to defraud. MR. WILLIAMS contended that the purchases were made under the false pretence of dealing or carrying on business in the ordinary way of his trade. The COURT considered that there was no evidence of the false pretence under sub-section 14 of the Act.
NOT GUILTY .

rs.hi: There was another indictment against the prisoner,
upon which no evidence was offered.

div1.p:
539.
GEORGE GAY (18)
, Stealing a purse and two keys and 4 d in money, the property of a woman unknown, from her person.
MR. GEOGHEGAN Prosecuted; MR. THORNE COLE Defended.

ALFRED HEGLEY . I am a printer at 5, Ocean Street, Stepneyâ€”on Wednesday, the 19th March, between 2 and 3 p.m., while on London Bridge, my attention was called to the prisoner and another manâ€”they were going from lady to lady and looking into their jacket pockets, and then feeling in themâ€”I followed them to King William Street, and saw the other man go and face a lady while the prisoner took out this purse (produced) from her pocketâ€”the other man then went towards Eastcheap and Gay towards Arthur Street East, and I followed him and called out to the policeman, and I had a struggle with him and he got awayâ€”I first saw the purse in his 'hand, and am sure he is the man.

Cross-examined. It was my dinner-timeâ€”I was standing upon the bridge, and they were going over from the Surrey sideâ€”I saw who took the purse, and saw it thrown away, and I picked it upâ€”I did not look into it; they opened it at the stationâ€”I followed the policeman, and came up to him in Thames Street, where the prisoner ran on to the wharves, and I called out "Police!"

WILLIAM SHEEN (City Policeman 756). I was on duty in Arthur Street East on the 19th March, and saw the last witness struggling with the prisonerâ€”I went towards them, and Gay got awayâ€”in consequence of what the witness told me I went to Thames Street and apprehended the other man, Wilkinsonâ€”the witness gave me this purse.

Cross-examined. I did not go on to London Bridgeâ€”they were about 12 yards off when I heard some one call outâ€”I ran four or five minutes from Arthur Street, and Hegley ran with meâ€”I got close to the prisoner, but he escaped, and I lost sight of him.

DAVID SHIP (City Policeman 809). I apprehended the prisoner on the 5th May in the Steam Packet public-house, Lower Thames Street, and told him he would be charged with stealing a purse from a lady in King William. Street on the 19th Marchâ€”he said, "You are mistaken"â€”I said, "That is for the witness to prove."
Cross-examined. He said he knew nothing about it.

GUILTY . The Prisoner also PLEADED GUILTY to having been previously convicted of felony at Lewes on the 1st July, 1878.**â€”
Two Years' Imprison
ment.

540.
JOSEPH AVITA (22)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
Rosario Bertucco.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS Prosecuted; and MR. FRITH Defended.

EDWARD CLUNELESS DAVIS . I am house surgeon at the London Hospitalâ€”I was present when Rosario Bertucco died thereâ€”I was present before his death, when his deposition was taken in the presence of a Magistrate; he was in a dying stateâ€”the prisoner was present, and had an opportunity of asking any questions he pleased. (The deposition of Rosario Bertucco was read as follows: "I am an inmate of the hospital. At half-past 7 on Satur
day last, 26th April, I was in the ice cream shop kept by Marmarosi; I went there to have something to eat; another man, not the prisoner, gave Marmarosi a white shirt to wash. That man asked for his shirt again, and called Marmarosi a whâ€”â€”. I asked Marmarosi what was the matter; the other man who gave the shirt said to Marmarosi, 'You have got another man who talks Italian, call him out to tight.' That man went out and came in again, and said to me, 'Come out and right.' As I went outside I said, 'One to one I will fight English fashion.' There were about 20 Maltese outside. The prisoner said, 'Let that man go, and fight with me.' We fought to
gether with fists. After we had been fighting about three-quarters of a minute I felt a blow with a knife in my back, and I fell to the ground. I do not know who gave me the blow with the knife. A soldier said, 'That is the man.' The prisoner was running away, and the soldier pointed to him. I had known the prisoner two or three days. I had had no quarrel with him before. I was sober." Cross-examined. "I had not been drink
ing with the prisoner; I had drank two glasses of beer with an Australian young manâ€”I did not see the man running awayâ€”just after I felt the stab I fell down and called out 'Help me, Christians!'â€”I had no knife except the little penknife producedâ€”I put my hand in my pocket to take out this knife to frighten themâ€”I do not know whether the prisoner was always in front of me as we were fightingâ€”we were turning round all the timeâ€”I had no quarrel half an hour before with the prisoner or any other Malteseâ€”the police sergeant did not pull me off any one.") The deceased was admitted into the hospital on 26th Aprilâ€”I saw him when he was admittedâ€”he was suffering from a wound in the left buttockâ€”it was more than 5 inches deep, and about 1/2 an inch in breadthâ€”it had entered the pelvisâ€”there was considerable hÃ¦morrhageâ€”I should say a very long slender knife would inflict such a woundâ€”considerable force must have been usedâ€”this knife (found on the prisoner) could not have produced itâ€”he died on 1st Mayâ€”I made a post-mortem examinationâ€”the knife had penetrated into the bladder; that caused extravasation of urine and peritonitis, of which he died.

Cross-examined. I said before the Magistrate that if the prisoner and deceased were fighting, I should think the prisoner could not have turned round and inflicted the wound in the position in which I found it, not if he was fighting in front of him, he would have to stoop down to do it, and I don't think he would be able to use sufficient force in that position.
ALFRED COWLEY . I am a soldier in the 2nd Battalion of Grenadier

Guards quartered at the Towerâ€”I have been in the army 18 monthsâ€”on the night of 26th April, about a quarter to 9 o'clock, I was in St. George's Streetâ€”I was soberâ€”I saw the prisoner come out of the Crooked Billet public-house with the deceased and two othersâ€”the prisoner and deceased began to fight with their fistsâ€”they fought for about a quarter of an hourâ€”they had about four or five roundsâ€”the deceased was on his knee, and the prisoner was in the rear of him, and he drew a knife from his side with a bit of white tape on it like sailors have round their necksâ€”it was shut when he drew it, but he opened it and stuck it in the backside of the deceasedâ€”he said "Oh, I am stabbed," and he fellâ€”the prisoner ran awayâ€”I went after himâ€”he took the first turning to the leftâ€”I overtook himâ€”I found him on his hands and knees at the side of a wall, and I gave him in charge to a policemanâ€”he was about 200 yards from where the fight took placeâ€”he then had no knife but this; I did not notice any white cord about himâ€”I am sure he is the man that drew the knifeâ€”I was in the Crooked Billet before the fight took place for about a quarter of an hour having a pint of beer, and saw the prisoner and deceased there; they were quarrelling about something, I could not understand their language, they were haggling in some foreign talkâ€”I afterwards assisted the deceased to the hospital.

Cross-examined. I saw five altogether in the Crooked Billetâ€”I had not seen either of them beforeâ€”there were a great many people around the two men, who were fightingâ€”I did not see a tall man there with ginger whiskersâ€”I did not see Cavaleri, or Mallia, or Jones there.

JAMES FUNNELL (Policeman H 249). On Saturday, April 26th, about 9 o'clock, I was on duty in St. George's Streetâ€”it used to be called Ratcliff Highwayâ€”it is very much crowded on Saturday nightâ€”I saw a disturbance going on outside the Crooked Billetâ€”just before I got Up to it I saw the prisoner come out of the crowdâ€”he had blood on the side of his face and neckâ€”he turned up Denmark Streetâ€”I heard a man say, "I am stabbed"â€”I went after the prisoner, and found him crouched alongside a dark wall, about 100 yards up Denmark Streetâ€”the soldier saw him first and said, "Here he is"â€”I took hold of him and said he would have to go back with meâ€”he said, "What for?"â€”I said there had been a man stabbedâ€”he said, "I have been fighting, but I did not use any knife"â€”I took him back to outside the Kettledrum, where the deceased was, but he was not able to say anythingâ€”I took the prisoner to the station and searched him, and found this small knife in his pocketâ€”there were no traces of blood on itâ€”the prisoner had no wound on him; he had a black eye.
Cross-examined. I did not look to see if there was any wound on his neckâ€”there was no cord round his neck.

WILLIAM POUND (Police Inspector H). I was present when the prisoner was brought to Leman Street Stationâ€”I read the charge to himâ€”he said, "I did not do it, they know that," pointing to a number of persons who came into the station with him.

Cross-examined. I have made inquiries and ascertained that two fireman of the ship Nankin disappeared on that Saturday nightâ€”they had leave and did not return to the shipâ€”I ascertained that from the chief engineer.
Re-examined. The Nankin was in the South West India Dockâ€”the firemen were both Malteseâ€”no knife was found where the fight took place.

p.hi: The following Witnesses were called for the Defence.

div1.p: CHARLES SAID . I am a firemanâ€”I am a Maltese, now boarding at 156,

St. Geoge's Streetâ€”on April 26th I saw a fight between the prisoner and deceasedâ€”they fought with their handsâ€”the prisoner did not strike the deceased with a knife; it was another one named Alfredâ€”I do not know his other nameâ€”it was a long Spanish knife with a sharp pointâ€”I had seen him open it at the boarding-houseâ€”the prisoner does not wear a knife fastened to a white cordâ€”Alfred struck the deceased from behindâ€”the two were fighting in English fashion, quite fair, and Alfred came behind and struck himâ€”the two were one on the top of the other at the time, the pri
soner was under, and Alfred struck deceased and ran awayâ€”I have not seen him sinceâ€”there were a good many people standing round.

Cross-examined. I saw the soldier on the other side, talking to a girl about 20 yards offâ€”I saw Alfred open the knife in the boarding-houseâ€”he wanted to fight the deceased with it, and the prisoner said noâ€”he was a fireman, and belonged to the Nankinâ€”he told me soâ€”he was a long fellow, with a small moustache, no whiskersâ€”I had known the prisoner about a week.
WILLIAM POUND (Re-examined). I learnt from the chief engineer of the Nankin the names of the two firemen who disappeared; they were Alfred Portello and Constantine Spero.

LAURENCE MALLIA . I am a fireman, lodging at Marmarosi's, in St. George's Streetâ€”I saw the fight between the prisoner and Bertuccoâ€”I saw Alfred, the man who ran away, strike Bertucco with a knifeâ€”the prisoner did not use any knife, he struct with his hand, English fashionâ€”Alfred was a long man with a small black moustache; he belonged to the Nankinâ€”I have not seen him since.

Cross-examined. I knew Alfred in. London, and the prisoner too; I knew the prisoner about 36 daysâ€”I saw the soldier on the other side speaking to a girl alongside the boarding-house, about 14 yards awayâ€”I saw Alfred take the knife from his jacket pocket and open it; it was a Spanish knifeâ€”I did not hear him say anythingâ€”he is a Maltese; so is the prisoner, and so am Iâ€”I knew Bertucco about five months ago.
Re-examined. I went to the police-court and gave my evidence on the Monday.

ALFRED JONES . I am a fireman at 1, John Street, St. George'sâ€”I was standing at the corner of John's Hill, and saw the prisoner and deceased fighting; the prisoner had the big man (the deceased) in a bending position, and a tall man came round from the crowd and stabbed the deceased; he then shut the knife and put it in his right-hand pocketâ€”I went ever to see if the man was hurt, and saw him bleeding in the backsideâ€”I turned round to see if the man that did it was there, and he was goneâ€”the police
man came up, and he and the soldier went up Denmark Street and caught the prisoner; the policeman asked the soldier if that was him, and he said "Yes"â€”he walked him outside the Kettledrum, and then the soldier said, "No, that ain't the man"â€”the policeman heard him say soâ€”I am quite certain the prisoner is not the man that used the knifeâ€”they were all strangers to me.

Cross-examined. I am employed at New Crane Wharf, Wappingâ€”the policeman had hold of the prisoner at the time the soldier said he was not the manâ€”I did not see which way the tall man ranâ€”it was an open knife he stabbed with, and then he stood in the road and shut it and put it in his pocketâ€”there was a mob round the fight.

WILLIAM LAY . I am a wharf labourer, and live at 23, Cornwall Street, St. George'sâ€”I know nothing of the partiesâ€”I saw the two men fighting; the deceased called out "The knife! the knife!"â€”the prisoner opened his hands and said, "Me got no knife; fight fair, English"â€”that was all I saw.
Cross-examined. I was standing in the crowd not a yard from themâ€”the prisoner was in front of the deceased with his hands upâ€”I did not see any one run away.

MARY ANN DRISCOLL . I live in Alsop Place, St. George'sâ€”I saw the prisoner and deceased fighting; I saw the deceased stabbed, not by the prisoner, by a much taller man with a little bit of moustache and light trousers, and he went away down a back turningâ€”I can swear it was not the prisoner.
Cross-examined. They were all strangers to meâ€”I was standing close by.
