JOHN CAVALERI . I was in Marmarosi's ice-shopâ€”there was a row there with a tall fellowâ€”I saw the fight in the street; the tall fellow with a black moustache stabbed the man with a long Spanish knifeâ€”he was a Maltese belonging to the Nankinâ€”it was not the prisoner.
Cross-examined. The tall man had a moustache; it was not very black or gingerâ€”I did not know him before, only to speak toâ€”I drank with him before the fight.

JAKES FUNNELL (Re-examined). I did not hear the soldier say that the prisoner was not the manâ€”I am quite sure he did not, or I should have heard himâ€”it was a darkish night, but there was light from the shops.
ALFRED COWLEY (Re-examined). I did not say the prisoner was not the man or anything of the sortâ€”he is the man.
NOT GUILTY .

541.
GEORGE GARDNER (28)
, Feloniously shooting
Annie Gardner, with intent to murder. Other Counts varying the intent.

MARY PODBURY . I am servant to the prisoner at Portland Villa, Hillingdonâ€”on 6th May, about 4.30 p.m., I was helping my mistress putting some feathers into a new bed in a room at the top of the houseâ€”I heard the breakfast-room bell ring; that is on the ground floorâ€”there are three storeys to the houseâ€”I came down to the first landingâ€”my master called "Mary"â€”I said "Yes, sir"â€”he came to the bottom of the landing and said, "Damn it, what are you laughing at up there?"â€”he had a revolver in his hand; he pointed it at me, and said he would shoot meâ€”he said that twiceâ€”I ran back to my mistress and told herâ€”the prisoner ran after me and came into the roomâ€”he said "I will shoot your mistress, by God I will, and I mean it too," and he moved a few steps and firedâ€”he,. held the revolver pointed straight at my mistressâ€”she was struck, and the blood was streaming down her faceâ€”I jumped at the prisoner, and took the revolver out of his hand and put it in my pocket, and went to fetch Trotman, the gardenerâ€”he was not at home, but he came a few minutes after I came backâ€”I had seen the prisoner that morning before I heard the bell; he was not drunk; he appeared to me to be soberâ€”I had not heard him quarrelling with my mistress that morningâ€”he had gone downstairs before Trotman cameâ€”I came with my mistress to her bedroom on the first floorâ€”I sent for the doctorâ€”my mistress was sitting down when the pistol

was fired at her; he was standing two or three yards from herâ€”I afterwards picked up a bullet and a tooth in the room by the side of where my mistress had been sittingâ€”the prisoner is of no business or professionâ€”I remember on 13th April his wanting to go out; my mistress wanted him not to go, and he took up the poker and said he would kill us if either of us came near him.

Cross-examined. When I first went into the service the prisoner was away at Dr. Harland'sâ€”he was there for six months on account of ill healthâ€”he came home about Christmasâ€”he gave way to drink a good dealâ€”he did not have an attack of delirium tremens while I was thereâ€”Mr. Mac
namara used to attend himâ€”he was in a peculiar state on Easter Sunday (13th April)â€”he had been drinking for two or three daysâ€”he used to get very excited after thatâ€”he did not raveâ€”I noticed that his eyes glared and looked wildâ€”that continued for a few days after he left off drinkingâ€”he wanted to go out on Easter Sunday, and my mistress and I tried to prevent him; we thought it would be dangerous to let him' go outâ€”he had been drinking a good deal before the 6th of May, brandy and beerâ€”he was not a great deal excited that dayâ€”it was about 3.30 when I went upstairs to pick the feathersâ€”this occurred about 4.30â€”I had passed him in the hall as I went upstairsâ€”I had no opportunity of watching him during that dayâ€”I had not been laughing upstairs; I was smiling when I came to masterâ€”when not under the influence of drink he has behaved nicely to my mistress.

Re-examined. He had taken a little beer that day, about 2 o'clock, and he had a little egg and brandy shortly before this occurred, about 3.35â€”he dined at 2 o'clockâ€”after Easter Sunday he went about the house as usual.

ANNIE GARDNER . I am the prisoner's wife; I have been married to him nearly seven yearsâ€”on Tuesday, 6th May, I was upstairs with Maryâ€”we had dined about 2 o'clockâ€”after dinner the prisoner struck me on the side of the head with his hand; he did not say anything to me at the timeâ€”I thought he was soberâ€”I had objected to his spitting in the fire, I asked him not to do so, and then he struck me, I believe with bis open hand; it was not a violent blow, but it hurt me, because I was suffering from head
acheâ€”I was sitting by the fire after dinner in the down-stairs roomâ€”I left the room immediately after he struck me, and went up to my bedroomâ€”that was about 2.30â€”after that I was in the top room with the servant picking feathersâ€”I heard the bell ring; the servant went down; I heard my husband threaten to shoot herâ€”he said "Damn it, what are you laugh
ing at upstairs? I will shoot you"â€”I had not heard her laugh; she was smiling when she went downâ€”she ran back to me into the room, and he followed her immediatelyâ€”she said "Master is coming upstairs with a revolver in his hand"â€”I should say he was near enough to hearâ€”when he came into the room I noticed that his face was very red, and his eyes glaringâ€”he said "I will shoot your mistress, by God I will, I mean it too;" he said that just as he came into the roomâ€”I saw the revolver in his handâ€”this (produced) is itâ€”he came and stood about two yards from my left sideâ€”I was sitting downâ€”he then moved nearly opposite to me, and fired without hesitationâ€”my head was leaning downâ€”I was struck in the left cheek, just below the eye; the bullet passed down inside my cheek and knocked out one of my upper teeth and one of the lower teeth; both teeth came out in the room, one has been found just lately; I was bleedingâ€”I did not see what Mary did, I saw her leave the roomâ€”my husband did not help me at

all; he was looking about the room for the revolverâ€”I said "No, no, no"â€”he said "What will they do to me?"â€”assistance came, and Mr. Mac
namara attended to meâ€”I thought, in fact I know almost that my husband was sober after dinner.

Cross-examined. He is a confirmed drunkardâ€”I sent him away last year to Dr. Harland's establishment in the hope that he would be curedâ€”he did not take to drink again for three weeks after he came back, but soon after he didâ€”he has had several attacks of delirium tremensâ€”when not in drink he has behaved kindly to meâ€”he has had the revolver for nearly two years; he got it on account of being afraid of burglarsâ€”I hid it for some timeâ€”I thought it an unsafe thing for him to haveâ€”when he fired at me I was sitting on a chair with my head bent down; I was not looking at himâ€”I can't say whether his hand was not much higher than his hipâ€”I was not alarmed when I saw him with the revolver.

Re-examined. It is some time ago that I put the revolver out of his wayâ€”I did it because he threatened to shoot meâ€”it is only a few weeks agoâ€”I took very little notice where he kept it; he put it in one of his own private drawersâ€”he has many times threatened to shoot me, and himself too.
By MR. MEAD. I do not know that on two occasions previous to our marriage he attempted to commit suicideâ€”I was told of it some time after my marriage, by his own brother, who is dead.

CHARLES-TROTMAN. I am a gardener, and have worked in that capacity for the prisoner about 12 mouthsâ€”on the 6th May, just before 5 in the afternoon, I was fetched to the house by Mary Podburyâ€”I found the prisoner just coming out of one of the lower roomsâ€”I said, "What have you been doing?"â€”he said, "I am going upstairs to see my wife"â€”I saw that he had blood on his hands, and he was very much excitedâ€”he wanted to pass me to go upstairsâ€”I caught hold of him and threw him down, and held him thereâ€”I did not then know what had happened upstairsâ€”he asked me to let, him get up and sit in a chair, and I did soâ€”he then said, "Is Mrs. Gardner dead? I am afraid she is; I am afraid I shot too straight"â€”on several occasions prior to this I had been called in when he was suffering from delirium tremensâ€”on one occasion he tried to stab himself with a knifeâ€”in the beginning of 1878, when I was in care of him, he asked to see his wifeâ€”she came into the roomâ€”he was talking to her for two or three minutesâ€”he then caught her by the shoulders and began to shake herâ€”I prevented him from doing soâ€”after she loft the room I asked why he had done it, and he said he had no recollection of having done itâ€”he was a confirmed drunkard then.

Cross-examined. He was very excited through drinkâ€”if he heard people talking he always fancied they were talking about him, and became very angry and excitedâ€”if any persons came into the house and were speaking, he always thought they were talking about himâ€”Mrs. Gardner always treated him with great kindness, only tried to prevent him from drinkingâ€”he said she did not use him kindly.

GEORGE DOWDESWELL (Police Inspector). On Tuesday evening, 6th May, about 6, I went to the prisoner's houseâ€”I was in uniformâ€”I saw him in the gardenâ€”as soon as I entered the garden he said, "I know what you have come for, you want me"â€”I said "Yes"â€”he went indoorsâ€”I told him I should take him into custody for shooting his wifeâ€”he said, "I did it in a passion; don't worry me"â€”he went quietly with me to the stationâ€”

he appeared very excitedâ€”I considered him to be soberâ€”I went back to the house and saw the bullet and tooth found by Mary Podbury in the room upstairs among some feathers on the floorâ€”she handed me this revolverâ€”it has six chambersâ€”one appeared to have been recently discharged; one had not been loadedâ€”I found a cartridge in the prisoner's pocket which fitted itâ€”I have drawn the other charges, and have the cartridges here.

EDMUND VINCENT . I accompanied the inspector to the prisoner's houseâ€”while he had gone away I was left alone with the prisonerâ€”he said, "Who sent for you?"â€”I said, "Dr. Macnamara came to the police-station and gave information that you had shot your wife"â€”he said, "Did he say that I was drunk?"â€”I said "No"â€”he said, "Did he say that my wife would die"â€”I said "No"â€”he said, "That is one load off my mind; I should not have done it if it had not been for passion"â€”he also said, "I have been very poorly; I should think more of it if I thought it was all my fault"â€”I considered him soberâ€”he had taken drinkâ€”on 14th May I was with him as he was being conveyed from the House of Correction to Uxbridge to go before the Magistrateâ€”in the train he said to me, "Can you get me a local paper, an Uxbridge paper?"â€”I said, "Yes, I dare say I can"â€”he said, "Because that girl has perjured herself"â€”I said, "What girl?"â€”he said, "That servant of ours; she states that she took the revolver from me; she did not, I dropped it in the feathers, and I have some recollection of looking for it, and if I had found it, it would no doubt have been a bad job for all that were present; I should have done for all, and myself as well."

GEORGE HOUSEMAN MACNAMARA . I am a surgeon at Uxbridge, near the prisoner'sâ€”on 6th May, about 5 o'clock in the afternoon, I went to the prisoner's houseâ€”I found Mrs. Gardner in bed bleeding from the mouth, and also from a wound in the cheekâ€”the bullet had entered just under the left eye, passed inside, and came out behind the upper lip, knocking out the eyetooth of the upper jaw and a tooth of the lower jawâ€”such a wound would be inflicted from the firing of a revolverâ€”I saw the prisoner about 5.30â€”he was not perfectly sober, he had evidently been drinkingâ€”he knew what he was aboutâ€”I saw him later in the evening at the police-station; I spoke to himâ€”he appeared then to know what he was aboutâ€”I have attended him since September, 1877â€”I attended him three times in the course of a year for delirium tremensâ€”on one occasion I took possession of the revolver; he had it in his writing desk; that was in September, 1877, the first time I saw himâ€”-from the state he was then in I took the revolver from him and kept it for six months, I then gave it to Mrs. Gardnerâ€”she' is out of danger; there will be disfigurement; she has not quite recovered from the shock.

Cross-examined. I believe she will completely recoverâ€”when I took the revolver from the prisoner he had been threatening to shoot everybody and himself tooâ€”delirium tremens sometimes arises from depression from abstinence from drink; they always leave off drinking before they get delirium tremensthe quantity of alcohol stops them from drinking, the whole digestion is upset, and they leave off drinking and delirium tremens followsâ€”glaring of the eyes is one of the first symptoms of delirium tremensâ€”the prisoner was suffering from a complication of diseases before he went to Dr. Harlandâ€”he was suffering recently from Bright's disease; that is an incurable disease; it is very much the effects of drinkâ€”he is not suffering so much from it now as he was two years agoâ€”he also had con
gestion
of the liver and of the lungs; the lung disease would cause him to spit a good dealâ€”he has general congestion of every organ of his body.

GUILTY
on First Count. â€”
Twenty Years' Penal Servitude. The Court directed a reward of 5l. to be paid to the witness Mary Podbury for her courageous conduct.

542.
SAMUEL ADAMS (20) was indicted
for and charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with feloniously killing and slaying
William Shawcross.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS Prosecuted; MR. AUSTIN METCALFE Defended.

p.hi: The Prisoner being deaf and dumb, the evidence was interpreted by the Rev. S. Smith.

div1.p: EDWARD EDGSON . I am a labourer at Hammersmithâ€”on 15th April, about 8.30 or 8.45, I was at the Crown public-house, North End, Fulham, with my wife, who is the prisoner's sister; she had had a little too much to drinkâ€”I took a rose out of her hatâ€”she said she would fetch a policeman and lock me upâ€”after this I was standing outside the Crown holding a horse's headâ€”I saw the prisoner come up and I saw Shawcross fall on the road on the back of his headâ€”I did not see the prisoner do anything to him; he ran, up and said "Bo!" and Shawcross fellâ€”he pushed him, whether with his open hand or his closed fist I could not sayâ€”he had his hands in his pockets, and he fell on the back of his head.
Cross-examined. Shawcross was standing on the edge of the kerb; I did not see him do anything aggravatingâ€”the prisoner is a very quiet fellow.

CHARLOTTE KERL . I am the wife of Henry Kerl, of Garden Cottage, North End, Fulhamâ€”on 15th April, between 9 and 10 o'clock, I was by the Crown public-houseâ€”Mrs. Edgson and her husband were fightingâ€”the prisoner was thereâ€”Shawcross stood facing the Crown about a foot off the kerbstone, with his hands in the waistband of his trousersâ€”I saw the prisoner strike him, and he fell on his back in the road, where there were some granite stones; he was picked up and taken to a surgeon'sâ€”I did not see him do anything to the prisoner.
Cross-examined. The prisoner struck at him, and it caught him by the side of the ear, and he fell backward into the roadâ€”he only struck him once.

JAMES STAMMERS . I live at 10, Field Road, Fulhamâ€”I was outside the Crown talking to Shawcrossâ€”I had seen Mr. and Mrs. Edgson quarrelling, and she went for a policemanâ€”the prisoner came towards Shawcross and struck him two or three times with his fist in the face, and he fell to the ground on the back of his headâ€”he had his hands in his pocket all the timeâ€”I saw no reason for the prisoner's striking him.
Cross-examined. Shawcross made no insulting gesture of any sortâ€”I am sure of that.

CHARLES MARSH . I am a grainer, and live at 10, Crown Road, Fulhamâ€”I saw a disturbance outside the Crown; there was a quantity of peopleâ€”Shawcross was standing on the edge of the kerb with his back towards the road with his hands in his boltâ€”I saw him blow his nose with his fingers towards the prisoner, who was standing ten or twelve yards offâ€”the prisoner
shook his fist and ran and either hit or pushed him, and he fell in the road and struck his headâ€”I am positive there were not three blows.

JOHN SHAWCROSS . I am a labourer of North End, Fulhamâ€”the deceased, William Shawcross, was my brother; he was 49 years of ageâ€”he was brought home senseless on 15th April; he was attended by Dr. Murdock and died on the 24thâ€”he had about 150 fits between the 15th and 24thâ€”he had had no fits before that; he was a healthy man.

PATRICK ALEXANDER MURDOCK . I am a registered medical practitioner at Fulhamâ€”on the night of 15th April the deceased was brought to my surgeryâ€”he was suffering from a lacerated wound at the back of his head, and was bleeding from both ears and nose; the wound was about the size of a half-crownâ€”from the grit and sand in the wound I fancied it was from a fall on a Macadamised roadâ€”I had him taken to his own home, and I attended him daily till he died; I saw him in one fit; it was reported to me that he had othersâ€”an injury of that kind would be likely to produce fitsâ€”the cause of death was fracture at the base of the skull caused by the fall.
Cross-examined. There was no. trace of any blow about his faceâ€”I should certainly have expected to find some trace if the blow was violentâ€”I should not think a violent blow could have been given.

HENRY PICARD (Detective). I arrested the prisoner on 25th Aprilâ€”I made certain signs to him to denote that Shawcross was dead, and that he had caused itâ€”he nodded his head and held up his fist in the action of striking, giving me to understand that he knew what I meant.
The Prisoner's Statement as interpreted before the Magistrate. "The deceased insulted me by a motion of his fingers to his nose."

GUILTY. He received a good character, and was strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury. â€”
One Month's Imprisonment without hard labour.

543.
EUGENE MOISE SILVEYRA (34) and
JOSEPH TOUZON (41)
, Unlawfully obtaining 185l. 10s. within four months of their bank
ruptcy. Other Counts for obtaining diamonds and other goods.
MR. BULWER, Q.C., and MR. F. H. LEWIS Prosecuted; MR. BESLEY appeared for Silveyra, and MR. ATHERLY JONES for Touzon.

MR. BESLEY stated that the defendants declined to plead to the 17th and 18th Counts, winch charged false pretences, and demurred to them, they being bad in law, having been added without the permission of the Court being first obtained; and that they were added merely to give power to the Court to make a restitution order. MR. JONES contended that a totally dis
tinct charge had been placed in the indictment against Touzon, and that the invariable practice under such circumstances was to strike out the Counts or to quash the Indictment. MR. BULWER having stated that he should not ask the Jury to convict Touzon on those Counts, as Silveyra alone was committed for the false pretences to which they related, the Court directed the 17th and 18th Counts to be quashed as far as Touzon was concerned.

ALFRED LOVE . I am a clerk in the Bankruptcy Courtâ€”I produce a petition in liquidation filed by Touzon and Silveyra, jewellers, goldsmith, and ring makers, dated 26th February, 1876, and filed the same dayâ€”I also

find an order of 28th February appointing Mr. Seear receiver and manager, and another order of 21st March appointing him trusteeâ€”in the statement of affairs filed by the debtors the unsecured creditors are stated at 8,833l. 16s. 3d., and the creditors fully secured 5,408l.â€”the estimated value of the securities is 7,777l.â€”there are no secured creditors except pawn
brokers.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. With the petition there is a list of 19 creditors to whom summonses are to be sent for the first meeting, which is afterwards increased by a supplemental list to 24â€”the first meeting was appointed for 19th March, when there was a resolution to liquidate by arrangement and not in bankruptcy, but no offer was made of so much in the poundâ€”they carried also a resolution appointing Mr. Seear trustee, which was certified on 21st Marchâ€”Silveyra was in custody on 1st March, and could not have been present when the accounts were filed on 21st Marchâ€”they are signed by both, showing assets 3,221l. 3s. 11d., and estimate of surplus securities 2,366l.â€”there is no examination of either defendant, and no cash and deficiency accountâ€”there are six secured creditors.

JOHN SEEAR . I am a public accountant, of 23, Holborn Viaductâ€”I was appointed receiver and manager, and afterwards trusteeâ€”I have been through the debtors' books; their liabilities are stated at 13,400l., the exclusive debts are 8,800l.â€”the stock in trade, valued by the debtors at 526l. 11s. 1d. have not been realised., but I do not suppose they would realise more than 300l. at the outsideâ€”the book debts, 306l. 1s. 1d., are estimated by them to pro
duce 230l., but I do not think they have all come in; there is also cash in hand, 34l. 15s. 4d.; furniture at 13, Frith Street, 70l.; other private furniture, 123l. 12s. 9d.â€”the total value outstanding is 2,068l. 9s. 3d., which has not yet produced anything, and the committee have decided not to take them out of the hands of the pawnbrokersâ€”the total value of assets received is under 300l., and the stock which I have in handâ€”the deficiency according to the statement is 5,500l., presuming the surplus realises the sum put down here, but assuming this statement to be correct it would be about 8,300l.â€”they were unquestionably insolvent in October, four months previous to their bankruptcy, and as a matter of book keeping, including stock, having looked through the books I am able to state that the amount of goods they have obtained during those four months is 4,602l. 7s. 9d., and nothing has been paid in respect of thatâ€”I asked Touzon before 21st March where those goods came from, showing him this marked list (produced); it shows some of the creditors from whom the goods were obtained, but some we cannot traceâ€”he said "We pawned the goods in order to pay our bills"â€”these deposit notes were handed to me by Messrs. Lewis and Lewisâ€”I showed them to Touzon, who gave me information from themâ€”Silveyra was in custodyâ€”Mr. Dobree's are 780l.; Mr. R. Starling's, 186l.; Mr. R. C. Vaughan's, 1,100l.; Mr. Robert Attenborough's, 1,582l.; Mr. Attenborough's, of Greek Street, 140l.; and Mr. T. A. Robinson's, 829l.â€”the annual interest on deposit notes is 15 per cent.; the interest on 5,400l. would be about 750l. a year.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I have had experience of diamonds and jewellery, but do not know that I can tell their valueâ€”I occupy myself with accountsâ€”when I went in as receiver, a ledger, journal, cash book, bill book, and bankers' pass book were produced to meâ€”they are all regular books, and were kept by a book-keeper, but not well keptâ€”the particular transactions are not entered in any of themâ€”I say that an account ought to have been

opened in the ledger with the different pawnbrokersâ€”I had the deposit notes handed overâ€”I have no proof of any single article pawned of which I have not had information given meâ€”I should not like to swear that all the money raised by loans was not used for the businessâ€”I will tell you what I can trace and what I cannot trace by the pass-bookâ€”I can fix upon transactions which do not correspond with the money raisedâ€”manufactured articles are sold at a larger profit than diamondsâ€”this business began in July, 1874, but it was not at Frith Street all the time, it was partly at 17, Great Titchfield Street, that was the duration of the existence of the firm; as to Silveyra's business before he joined Touzon I have no recordâ€”I have known persons start this kind of business with no capitalâ€”I find nothing pawned in the first year; in 1875 the payments to pawnbrokers were 283l. 6s., in 1876 694l. 1s. 6d., of which 52l. was paid back; in 1877 1,430l. 19s. 6d. and 200l. 15s. paid back: in 1878, down to the failure 6,019l. 2s. and 649l. paid backâ€”Touzon was unable to say every time what the money was paid back for, but where it is stated on the counterparts of the cheques that they were paid for interest we have kept them apartâ€”there were only five pawn-brokers' names in the list instead of seven, because the three Mr. Atten-boroughs are put down as oneâ€”the 2,441l. to Mr. Attenborough, of Charlotte Street, Fitzroy Square, includes the threeâ€”I believe it is the same gentleman carrying on business in three different placesâ€”with regard to the bill-book, I verified the acceptances that have been paid in the usual wayâ€”I believe Darby brothers 634l. 8s. was the first transaction, that was in December; the next is Keller cousins; they have not had many transactions with themâ€”I am not aware of othersâ€”I have had the 34l. 15s. 1d. in cash, but the furniture has not been sold yetâ€”the private furniture, 123l. 12s. 9d., only realised 25l., as the landlord of the private house distrained, and it was valued to him for the rentâ€”the only rent down here is in respect of the manufactory, 32l. 10s.â€”I have collected about 150l. of debt, and there is more to come inâ€”the lease is soldâ€”I have not touched the goods at the pawnbrokers'.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. I have had every facility given me through Touzon for investigating the affairsâ€”he did not keep the books; he gave me information upon every point upon which I required it, but he did not know whether some of the cheques were for interest or for taking goods out of pawnâ€”I do not say that he had as much information regarding financial matters as Silveyra, but he knew of themâ€”the majority of the securities have not yet been realised, but the different merchants who supplied goods have seen them since in the pawnbrokers' handsâ€”I do not propose to go any further into realising the goods pawned, the assets still to get in are the stock in trade, which I am going to realise, and some of the book debtsâ€”there are very few debts outstandingâ€”the major portion of the assets as shown by the prisoners I do not intend to realise, as there is no interest to the estate in doing soâ€”I tabulated the statement of affairs from information given me by Touzon, who went occasionally to Silveyra in prison for in
formation which he was not able to give me himselfâ€”I find by the books that the names of creditors to the firm are limited in number, and that very large payments have been made to some of them during the five years they have been in businessâ€”I have referred to the pass-book but not to the bill-bookâ€”I find that the prisoners commenced business with a capital of only 78l.â€”I paid Touzon during my receivership while he was giving me the

information until my appointment as trustee, and there it endedâ€”Touzon was given in custody upon my affidavit of what I found on investigating the affairs after my appointment as trustee, in which he gave me every information.

Re-examined. I was employed to investigate the books and the state of their affairs, and when I found anything I did not understand I went to Touzon for informationâ€”I made my report and an affidavitâ€”from the trans
actions which are entered in the books a person would not be able to discover that they raised 5,000l. by pawnbroking, and were paying 750l. a year interestâ€”I got the duplicates from Messrs. Lewis and Lewis, who were acting for the creditorsâ€”it is considered that there would be no surplus after paying the pawnbrokers' charges, therefore it would not justify us in taking the goods outâ€”the amount of pawnings during the last four months before they went into liquidation is about 3,000l.â€”half of the whole amount is within the last four months preceding their bankruptcyâ€”if they had not met these bills their credit would have stoppedâ€”we hold a bill which the bankers have, and which will not be met till Augustâ€”the cash is only 34l. Francis Millard. I am a diamond merchant, of 8, Conduit Street, Regent Streetâ€”I have known the defendants for the last three years, and have done business with themâ€”on 23rd January this year I had outstanding bills of theirs for 428l. for diamonds purchased of meâ€”I called on them on the afternoon of 22nd January and asked how trade wasâ€”Silveyra said very good; I sold some diamonds last week, and if you come to-morrow morning I shall have some more goods"â€”I said "What time will it be convenient for you to look at them?"â€”he said "10 o'clock in the morning"â€”I went there on the 23rd and took some diamonds, but finding that they owed me about 420l. I said "I have been looking at your account; can you pay your acceptances when they fall due I because if you cannot I shall not sell you any more diamonds"â€”he said" Certainly we can"â€”I said "You are quite sure of that?"â€”he said "Yes; what makes you ask such a ques
tion?"â€”I said "I don't care to run any risk in making a bad debt; if you say you can, I will show you some more," and I took a box from my pocket and sold him some more for 154l., for which he gave me a bill, but I have received nothing on it, and never shall; there is not a farthing in the world for meâ€”I next saw my goods in the police-court, produced by Mr. Vaughan as pawned on 24th January, the day after, at least a parcel of the same size, but being unmounted it is difficult to identify them, as Silveyra had his settings in silver, and he put every stone into the silver settings, and these are the same sized stones in the parcel pawned at Mr. Vaughan's, and the same quality exactly as those I sold on the 23rdâ€”I should not have let him have them except for the statement he madeâ€”I have been selling diamonds for 34 years, and that is the first time I ever heard of diamonds bought one day being sold the next.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. In January, 1878, I sold a parcel of stones which I bought for sapphiresâ€”when I found that they were not sapphires I took them back at the same price, and lost 800l. by themâ€”they were not stained crystal, but a new compositionâ€”I took one of them to the Geological Society, in Jermyn Street, and asked them to melt itâ€”only one of them had been mounted; that was in a ring which I paid 3l. for that they might lose nothingâ€”they did not compel me to take them backâ€”I have not got my bill-book here, but I dare say it is correct that on 11th

January, 1879, I had a bill of 31l. 12s. 6d. falling dueâ€”I have got it in the pass-bookâ€”nobody was present at the conversation but Silveyra and myselfâ€”I do not know that what I am asserting to be my diamonds are diamonds pledged by Blagg and Martinâ€”this is the first time I have heard of itâ€”they are exactly the same quality as those I sold on the 23rd, and those were pledged on the 24thâ€”I have not said a word about the weight; there are more in this parcel than I sold; they had some more in stock, and they put them all togetherâ€”I cannot swear that they are not the property of Blagg and Martin.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. My transaction with the defendants during three years amount to 2,600l., of which 582l. remains due to meâ€”I have received about 2,000l. in cash from themâ€”I did not pay 2l. a carat for the pretended sapphires and sell them at 7l.â€”I knew both the defendants when they were at Clapham, employed by a firm as. journeymen at weekly wages; they got about 7l. a week or 1l. a dayâ€”I knew nothing about them starting in business for themselves.

Re-examined. It was in consequence of the diamonds being purchased on the 23rd and pledged on the 24th that I applied for a warrant against Silveyraâ€”the exact amount I sold on the 23rd was 22 carats, and the amount shown to me afterwards was 30 carats.

WILLIAM ALEXANDER JARDINE HICKS . I am a diamond merchant in partnership with Leopold Keller, in Hatton Gardenâ€”we are creditors of the defendants to the amount of 3,788l., about 1,800l. of which was incurred during the four-months preceding February 26â€”it is not in my experience in the ordinary course of trade to sell diamonds purchased for the purpose of manufactureâ€”I would not have sold goods if I knew such an idea prevailedâ€”a parcel of diamonds was pledged for 170l. with Mr. Dobree on 8th February which I believe to have been sold by me on the 4th for 450l.â€”I have not been paid for themâ€”there are five diamonds invoiced on 22nd February on approbation, pawned on 15th February with Mr. Vaughan; I do not know for what amountâ€”he elected to keep them after he had pledged themâ€”they wore sold for the purpose of being mountedâ€”we also sold a parcel of 25 carats on 1st November for 360l., of which we believe those pledged with Mr. Attenborough on 13th November to be a portion.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. We have had dealings with the defendants since 1875â€”high firms in the jewellery trade do not to my knowledge pledge temporarilyâ€”on 30th November we sold them goods amounting to 119l. 13s., but there were none between 18th October and 1st Novemberâ€”there was a bill of 330l. on 9th January, for which we found the money, knowing that it had to be met, and here is the chequeâ€”we never got the moneyâ€”part of our account is money advanced to take up our own billsâ€”the defendants never paid in cashâ€”we had no acceptance paid in Januaryâ€”the last payment to us according to this was on 30th Octoberâ€”Louis Keller and Leopold Keller are brothersâ€”goods on appro
bation are paid for at the end of 14 days, but we generally write by courtesy and ask if we may chargeâ€”the February parcel went out in Januaryâ€”I did not see Silveyra on the subject, the book-keeper came down.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. We have had transactions with them amounting to about 7,000l., and payments to about 3,400l.â€”they com
menced

business before us, but I believe we were the first people who gave them creditâ€”I cannot say that they have conducted business ever since without capital, but I believe not muchâ€”I always understood that Touzon attended to the workshopâ€”I never received any order from him personallyâ€”they have both bought of our firm, but there are four of us.

Re-examined. I have seen Touzon at our place of businessâ€”he did not come to buy a hatâ€”we have had 3,0007. odd paid by bills which have been metâ€”if they had not been we should not have gone onâ€”3,788l. is now due.

EDWARD AUGUSTUS KELLER . I am a diamond merchant, of 17, Conduit Streetâ€”at the time of the petition for liquidation the defendants owed me 509l., of which 2287. was supplied on 14th February this year, and they filed their petition on 26th Februaryâ€”I have not seen them in the pawn-brokers' handsâ€”it is not the course of business to systematically pledge goods purchasedâ€”I should not have supplied my goods if I had known that there was such a practice in their house.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I am the son of Leopold Kellerâ€”I did not know till after I had sold my goods that my father was supplying money to take up billsâ€”Louis Keller is my uncleâ€”I did not know of his giving the defendants 299l. 9s. 8d. on 16th Februaryâ€”it is not common for an honest tradesman having acceptances to meet to pledge his stock for the purposeâ€”I call them all dishonest who do thatâ€”the total amount supplied was 509l., and on 22nd January he owed 280l. only: the other was sold on 14th February.
Cross-examined by MR. JONES. I have had two transactions with the defendants to the value of 509l., and have been paid nothing in respect to either of themâ€”they only commenced in July last.

FREDERICK EDWARD KELLER . I am a diamond merchant of Albert House, Holborn Viaductâ€”at the time of their liquidation the defendants owed me 1,978l., about 1,300l. of that had been supplied to them during the four months preceding 26th Februaryâ€”I have seen a portion of it in the hands of Mr. Attenboroughâ€”the weight of them was not exactly the same, but I think the goods were the sameâ€”the value of them was 280l. 10s.â€”they are pledged for 110l.â€”I sold them on October 19th.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I represent the firm of Louis Keller-looking at this bill book I am not prepared to say whether we have an acceptance of 200l. on 13th Octoberâ€”it is "Mr. Keller only," here; nor can I tell you whether we had 200l. on 4th Novemberâ€”I have no memoranda for last yearâ€”there are so many renewals that I cannot tell you; it says here either that we found the money or a bill was paid for 200l. on 4th October. (The witness was directed to fetch his book.)

WILLIAM JAMES WILLETT . I am a diamond merchant of Golden Squareâ€”at the time of their liquidation the defendants owed me 638l. 5s. for goods sold on September 3rdâ€”I believe I saw my goods at Marlborough Street in the possession of Mr. Leopold Keller, but I believe they were produced by one of the Mr. Attenborough's.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I was paid 40l. on 8th January, and subsequently 30l.â€”the goods I saw in Mr. Attenborough's hands were some rose diamonds which I supplied in July, and on 4th July I received 40l. on a bill at six months which fell due on 4th January, and I gave Silveyra a cheque for 70l. to take it up to keep it going, and afterwards, on 8th
January, he gave me 40l.; and on 3rd February, 15l.; and on 21st January, 15l.â€”the bill would have been dishonoured but for my finding the money.
Cross-examined by MR. A. JONES. I did not know at that time that my goods were in pledge.

HENRY ROBERT ELLIS . I am manager to Mr. Dobree, of Charlotte Street, Fitzroy Squareâ€”I did not know either of the prisoners myself, but on 12th October I received 36 carats of brilliants from Adrian Broquet for 150l.; they were pledged in July, the interest is 15 per cent.; when we take interest we make a fresh deposit note; we start afreshâ€”I had a deposit note on 21st October, but the pledgings were in June, it was merely interest paid and the debt left; if the interest had not been paid we should have sold the brilliantsâ€”on 21st October there was another pledging for 100l., that has been renewed; there was also another renewing in October for 29 carats which were pledged in June; and another on 1st December pledged in June; also a pledging on 3rd December, 1878, for 100l., that was a new transaction; and another new transaction on 8th February, 1879, they were 42 1/16 carats for 170l.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I have been a long time in the tradeâ€”I have had many such transactionsâ€”it is a very usual practice of jewellers, for temporary accommodationâ€”the pledgings before December run into May, June, and Julyâ€”the interest was paid, so that the right to get out the articles was leftâ€”some of these goods were taken out, and on the same occasion others were put inâ€”it is an ordinary thing to bring other goods, and to redeem previous lots as they have occasion, so that they have our capital to work with at 15 per cent.â€”trade has been very bad for two or three yearsâ€”my experience is that pledges are less in bad times than good timesâ€”I account for that by there not being such a demand for goodsâ€”at the present time diamonds are very lowâ€”they advanced about 41. on them, and they would fetch 6l. a carat; that means 25 per cent. margin.

Re-examined. It is usual to pledge goods for temporary accommodationâ€”I should not think much of it if you pledged your pencil case to pay your cab, but it would depend how often it was doneâ€”it has often occurred to me that a man brings 150l. worth of diamonds and pledges them, but not for a temporary advanceâ€”if he wants money he comes to me to get it, but we will not have it unless we get good securityâ€”every tradesman is liable to sudden pressureâ€”it would not be carrying it to an extreme extent to supply tradesmen with capital to carry on their businessâ€”it would be highly improbable that they would do so at 15 per cent.â€”a sudden pressure is one thing, prolonged want of capital is different, but we do not set up to supply tradesmen with funds.

CHARLES BEAUMONT VAUGHAN . I am a pawnbroker, of 39, Strandâ€”on 13th February Silveyra pledged with me 20 carats of brilliants for 100l., and on 13th September 30 carats for 100l., on 30th September 30 carats more, and on 4th November 48 loose brilliants and some earrings for 200l.â€”I consider this (Looking at a deposit note) to be quite a new transaction, the first we settled by the payment of interest, And the second pledgings were begunâ€”on 16th January, 1879, he pledged 40 carats for 170l., and on 24th January a brooch and earrings and 30 carats of diamonds for 220l.â€”on 30th February some necklets, three rings, a brooch, and five loose brilliants, for 200l.â€”I gave the money to Silveyraâ€”he brought the goods personally.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I have known him from the first pledgingâ€”on 24th January there were new articles waiting for a customer, manu
factured articles, and on 13th February manufactured articles alsoâ€”I do not think Silveyra brought some articles to pledge for the purpose of redeeming other articlesâ€”Blogg and Martin asked to see the goods claimed by Mr. Miller, and I refusedâ€”they said that they sold Silveyra a parcel of the same weightâ€”it is not at all unreasonable to raise money on precious stones not manufactured into jewellery; it enables tradesmen to carry on their businessâ€”persons of the highest reputation in London do soâ€”these pledgings were not pledged up to the value of the goodsâ€”he was in each case supplied with the exact amount he asked forâ€”the margin we take differs sometimes; it may be 25 per cent., and here are some he was charged 7 per cent for where we lent 4l.â€”there has been a fall in the value of diamonds lately, and a diminution in the number of people buying themâ€”during the last 18 months there have not been so many people able to buy diamonds as there used to be.

Re-examined. I know that jewellers do pledge constantlyâ€”I represent that it is usual for manufacturing jewellers to pledge with us to take up bills to carry on their businessâ€”I do not know whether that depends on the state of their account, I only know the facts or part of themâ€”when I said 71. a carat for which we should give 4l., I qualify that by "perhaps"â€”I still hold the goods in every one of these transactionsâ€”no one can get them without paying off the percentage.

ARTHUR WILSON . I am manager to Mr. Attenborough, of Greek Street, Sohoâ€”on November 30th Silveyra pledged some brilliants and other pro
perty with me for 40l.â€”the deposit-note was made out to Touzon and Silveyraâ€”Touzon was not with himâ€”on February 6th I advanced 1001 to Silveyra on some brooches in the name of. Touzon and Silveyraâ€”Touzon was not present.

(Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Silveyra has been in the habit of pawning there for perhaps two yearsâ€”he has redeemed several parcelsâ€”there has been no forfeiture during the last four monthsâ€”the articles on November 30th were one ring and 10 carats of brilliantsâ€”he has occasion
ally pledged brilliants unsetâ€”manufacturing jewellers continually pledge their stock in order to carry on their business; very respectable housesâ€”I simply advanced Silveyra the money that he askedâ€”there was perhaps rather less than 25 per cent. marginâ€”he told me he was pledging for the purpose of meeting bills falling due.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. I have never seen Touzon. Re-examined. There is no power of forfeiture, only a power of safeâ€”it I had sold, and there was a balance, it would have been handed over to himâ€”I did not know that he was depositing with six or seven other pawn-brokers at the same time, but if I had I should have accepted the goods, con
sidering it a temporary pressure in the ordinary course of businessâ€”I asked him whether the goods were his own property, but not each timeâ€”he showed me his pass-book on several occasions, which gave me confidence in him to advance the moneyâ€”I should not have advanced it, whether they had been obtained on credit or not if they were equal to the amount asked.
EDWARD REYNOLDS . I am general manager to Mr. Attenborough, of Charlotte Streetâ€”on November 21st, 1878, Silveyra renewed one pledge

for 50l., and another of brilliants for 70l., and on November 7th, 1878, there was an original pledging by Broquetâ€”the statement is, "Deposit, A. Broquet"â€”on November 13th, 1878, Silveyra deposited 200l. worth of brilliantsâ€”Touzon was not present, and on November 14th there was a renewal of goods pledged by Silveyra in 1877â€”the same transaction had been going on at interest of 15 per cent.â€”on November 16th there was a renewal of 69l. on brilliants, and another of 50l., and on the next day of 60l.â€”on November 14th Broquet pledged 15 carats of brilliants for 140l., and some more 16 days afterwards for 200l., and on February 28th 25 carats for 100l.â€”on November 29th a renewal of 100l. for earrings; December, 1879, an original pawning by Broquet for 80l.â€”on January 9th 40l. on brilliants; on January 11th 75l., and January 23rd 100l., all by Broquet, and all original pawnings.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. The majority of pledgings are brilliantsâ€”the total amount of loan on the old pledgings is about 1500l., of which about 1,000l. was before October 21st, 1878â€”1000l. in November is for renewals, and the remaining 500l. is for brilliants, but there are manufactured goods among them, bracelets and ringsâ€”I allow 15 to 20 per cent, margin in the value of the brilliants to cover my riskâ€”there has been a great fall in brilliants during the Last 18 monthsâ€”I have been in business 25 years-manufacturing jewellers do pledge their stock constantly to carry on businessâ€”I knew that Touzon and Silveyra were manufacturing jewellers.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Touzon was never at my place. Re-examined. If I knew that a man was 4,000l. in debt and had got 200l. worth of goods on credit, I should say that it was not in the usual way of business to take those goods to a pawnbroker and raise money on them.

ADRIAN BROQUET . I am a dealer in watches at 5, Torrington Squareâ€”I have pledged a great number of brilliants for the defendants within the last four months and beforeâ€”I pledged for them the goods spoken of by Mr. Reynoldsâ€”Silveyra brought them to me, but I have sometimes given the proceeds to Touzon, and had conversations with him about themâ€”he knew how the money had been gotâ€”I have had conversations with both defendants about pledging goods before they were pledged, and they always said that it was for business only, and that their profits were so good that they would pull throughâ€”sometimes one and sometimes the other gave me that reason for pledging goods, and sometimes they have been togetherâ€”on 8th February last I got 170l. for 42 carats of plain diamonds, and gave the money to Touzonâ€”I had these conversations with Touzon six months ago.
Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I know nothing about the bookkeepingâ€”I had nothing to do with paying the money into the bank.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. I received the instructions to pawn invariably from Silveyra, and not from Touzonâ€”he was chiefly employed in the workshopâ€”I have known the defendants many years; I knew them when they were at Claphamâ€”I was a helper in their commencing business. Re-examined. I assisted them to startâ€”they sometimes came to me and sometimes I was taking diamonds to offer themâ€”I live nearly ten minutes' walk from themâ€”my services were only a matter of friendship; I never got a shilling commissionâ€”sometimes Silveyra came to my place and sometimes Touzon, and sometimes Silveyra sent a boy to my place, or I was taking goods to their office.
GEORGE CARTER (Policeman 308 E). I took the prisoners on warrants, Silveyra on 28th February and Touzon on 25th March.
Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Silveyra was at 13, Frith Street, sitting in the room with the receiver; that was on the charge Mr. Miller set on foot about the diamonds, the only charge then.

FREDERICK KELLER . (Re-examined by MR. BESLEY). On October 3rd they had a cheque for 200l. to meet a bill; on October 22nd a cheque for 200l. to meet a bill coming due on the 23rd; on January 11th a cheque of 406l. to meet a bill of 406l. 17s.; and on January 14th a cheque of 100l. to meet a payment of 100l. on January 15thâ€”they paid 100l. on October 13th, 200l. on November 4th, and also 75l.; on November 15th, 173l. 8s. 9d. and 207l. 8s. 9d.; on December 4th, 76l. 17s. 6d.; on December 13th, 181l. 4s.; on 24th January, 208l. 3s.â€”that is over 1,000l. in cash besides meeting the billsâ€”I think those were the only cases when I applied money to meet billsâ€”up to that time I do not think they had been in want of money to meet our billsâ€”we commenced business with them in 1876.

By MR. BULWER. They have paid us 1,800l. or 2,000l., and they owe us 1,900l.
GUILTY on the first 16 Counts only. â€”
Six Months' Impisonment without hard labour.

544.
WILLIAM SAWYER (57)
PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully wounding
Susan Sawyer.â€”
Judgment Respited.

545.
JOHN WATERFIELD (30)
, Feloniously forging and uttering an order for 97l. 8s. 6d. with intent to defraud.

WILLIAM GEORGE REEVE . I am now a prisoner in Newgateâ€”I pleaded guilty in January last to two charges of forging and uttering a cheque for 20l. 3s. 6d. on the Imperial Bank, and a cheque for 97l. 8s. 6d. on the City Bankâ€”in 1877 I was office boy to Dudgeon and Co.â€”I left their service in June, 1878, and went to my uncle's, and was afterwards out of workâ€”I am 16 years of ageâ€”I first met the prisoner on 19th November, 1878â€”I was standing in the street outside the Elephant and Castle public-house, Newington, when the prisoner spoke to me and said"I think I have seen your face before; where do you live and where do you work?"â€”I said "I have just left Nunhead and am out of work and have left home"â€”he said"If you like, me and you will work and live together; where are you lodging?"â€”I said "Nowhere"â€”he said"I can give you a lodging for the night," and then we went to No. 26, Parsonage Walk, Newington, where he and a woman named Hancock occupied a room togetherâ€”I slept there that nightâ€”Mrs. Rand is the landladyâ€”the next morning, the 20th, I went with the prisoner to the City, and we walked about and returned to Parsonage Walk in the evening, and we had a conversation which he beganâ€”he said"About the bank accounts; if we can write out an order for a cheque"â€”he asked me where Messrs. Dudgeon banked; I told him at first that they were my late employers, and he asked me where they kept their banking account,. and he said "If we can write an order for a cheque-book on the Imperial

Bank, and can get the cheques, we can get the money; can you sign Mr. Dudgeon's name to the cheque?"â€”I said"Yes"â€”I slept that night in the prisoner's room; the woman Hancock was there then, and on the previous nightâ€”I went out the next day with the prisoner to a coffee-shop in Camberwell Road or Kennington Lane, and he there said"We'll write out the order for the cheque-book to-day"â€”we returned to Parsonage Walk, where I wrote out an order in his presence on the Imperial Bank for a cheque-book of 100 chequesâ€”he produced the paper and pen and inkâ€”we then went to the Imperial Bank, Lothbury, and at the corner of Prince's Street he said "If you get one of the paying-in slips out of the bank it will take them off their guard, "and I went in and got the paying-in slip, and when I came out the prisoner was at the corner of Prince's Street, opposite the bankâ€”I returned with him to Parsonage"Walk and wrote there in his presence this order. (Written on the back of a paying in slip of the Imperial Bank: "Thursday, 21st, 1878. Please send per bearer a cheque-book containing 100 cheques, and oblige yours truly, A. J. Dudgeon.") The prisoner saw me write itâ€”I then destroyed the one I had previously written in his presenceâ€”I went to the bank with the prisoner and took the fresh order to one of the clerks, who gave me a cheque-book for 100 chequesâ€”tho prisoner waited for me opposite the bank, at the corner of Prince's Street, and we went back, returning to Parsonage Walk about 11 o'clockâ€”I then took out one of the cheques in the prisoner's presence and wrote the cheque produced. ("No. C. 144901. 6, Lothbury, London, Thursday, 21st November, 1878. The Imperial Bank, Limited Pay office or bearer 20l. 3s. 6d. A. J. Dudgeon.") The amount was suggested by the prisonerâ€”I gave the cheque to the prisoner and returned with him to the Imperial Bank, and he waited outside as before while I went inâ€”I presented it and got the money in goldâ€”I gave the prisoner 10l. and kept the rest myself, and we went to the Crystal Palace together at my expense and stayed till evening, when I returned with him to Parsonage Walk, and slept there againâ€”Hancock was thereâ€”this was the evening of the 21st, and I slept there till the 25th Novemberâ€”I went out during the day to places of amuse
ment with the prisonerâ€”on the 25th he said"Ain't your money nearly gone? mine is; I think we had better have some more"â€”my money was nearly goneâ€”he asked me where Dudgeon and Co. kept the company's accountâ€”the Imperial Bank was the private accountâ€”I said "At the City Bank, Finch Lane"â€”he said"Will you write out another order?"â€”I said "Yes," and he gave me the paper and I wrote out in his presence this order for a cheque-book. ("10, London Street, 25th November, 1878. Sir,â€”Please supply per bearer one cheque-book containing 200 cheques, and oblige, J. W. Cooper, secretary, Dudgeon and Co., Limited.") At the bottom is Written "Received by G. W. Richardson"â€”I wrote that when I went to the bank, and invented the name myself at the bankâ€”the order was written in the prisoner's room in his presence, and we then went together in a cab to the City Bank, Finch Lane, Cornhillâ€”I had been with Dudgeon and Co. as office boy and knew they had an account there; I used to go there with lettersâ€”I do not know if their address was printed on their letter paperâ€”we left the cab at the top of Finch Lane, and the prisoner waited at the top of Cornhill, about 100 yards distant, while I went to the bankâ€”I gave the order to one of the clerks, who gave me the cheque-book, and I rejoined the prisoner and returned with him in a cab to his room in Parsonage Lane,

where I took out one of the cheques and wrote this in his presence, he suggesting the amount ("3 J. 69203. Threadneedle Street, corner of Finch Lane, London, 25/78. City Bank. Pay yard expenses or bearer 97l. 8s. 6d. J. W. Cooper, Dudgeon and Co., Limited.") I suggested yard expenses and he agreed to itâ€”we then returned to the bank in a cab and he waited again at the same place while I went in and presented the cheque, which they cashed for me all in gold, and I rejoined the prisoner and gave him 10l.â€”this was November 25thâ€”the prisoner then proposed we should buy a pony and trap, and said he knew of one for sale in Bethnal Green Roadâ€”I agreed, and we went there together to Mr. Silverton'sâ€”the prisoner waited opposite in a public-house, and I bought the pony and dog-cart and paid 33l. 10s. for itâ€”I took it to the public-house and the prisoner got into the trap and we drove to the Elephant and Castle, where we picked up Hancock and another woman who I had seen before with herâ€”we took them in the trap to the Crystal Palace, and stayed there till evening; I paid all the expensesâ€”I carried the money in my pocketâ€”on returning in the evening we agreed to put the pony and trap up at the Artichoke public-house in the Borough Road, and the prisoner drove there with me and spoke to the ostler, and we left it there and went into the public-house, and remained there talking and drinking from between 8 and 9 till about 12 o'clock that nightâ€”we paid in turns for the drinkâ€”on leaving we returned to Parsonage"Walk and took two small bottles of whisky we had bought at the Artichokeâ€”we found Hancock at Parsonage Walk, and we bad supper in the prisoner's room and finished the whisky, and I became intoxicatedâ€”I slept there, and got up about 8 in the morning, and found there was no one thereâ€”I fetched the pony and trap from the Artichoke, and left it outside with a boy, and I went back to bed and slept till 1 o'clock, when the landlady woke me up and said something to me, and I found that I had lost 50l. from my pocket, nearly all the money I had, and the prisoner and Hancock had goneâ€”they had said nothing to me about goingâ€”the two women were with us all the time at the Crystal Palace the day before, and on returning we left them at the corner of the Elephant and Castle at 8 o'clockâ€”I saw Hancock again when we got back to Parsonage Walkâ€”I did not see the other woman again that nightâ€”on coming down at 1 o'clock I found the pony and trap still outside the door, and I took a drive, and then took it back to the Artichokeâ€”when I got up first at 8 o'clock I left the money in the room in my trousers pocketâ€”the trousers were wetâ€”I did not look for it till 1 o'clockâ€”I was arrested some days afterâ€”I found these three books (produced) in the prisoner's room, and believe they are hisâ€”I put them at the back of the pony and trap on the 26th, so that if I should be arrested it would lead to the prisoner being takenâ€”I had no authority from Dudgeon or Dudgeon and Co. to sign their name to the cheques.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You were out of employment when I first saw youâ€”I did not meet Miss Hancock in town the evening before I brought the pony and trap to Parsonage Walkâ€”I purchased her a hat and gloves on the night of the 24th, I thinkâ€”I had not the trap then, so I did not promise to bring it to take you to the Crystal Palace next morningâ€”the trap was purchased on the 25thâ€”I was never at Parsonage Walk with the trap any morning at 9.30 while you lived there, only on the morning of the 25th, and when I came from the Crystal Palace in the evening I left Miss Hancock and the other girl at the Elephant and Castleâ€”I did not leave you

there; we both went together in the trapâ€”I had my supper in your room about half-past 12 or 1 o'clock, and only you and Hancock were thereâ€”we went to the Crystal Palace in the morning before dinner on the 25thâ€”I had bought the pony and trap in the morningâ€”you were never there after the 25thâ€”I did not tell the landlady that I had lost 30l. on the 28th Novemberâ€”I was not there on the 28th; it was on the 26th I lost 50l.â€”she cannot give the dateâ€”I put up the pony and trap at the Artichoke on the evening of the 25th, when we returned form the Crystal Palaceâ€”only you and Hancock lived in the room.

Re-examined. I bought the ponny and trap, I think, on the 25th November, the same morning I cashed the cheque for 97l. 8s. 6d. at the City Bankâ€”it was the next morning, the 26th, I was at parsonage Walk with the pony and trap. When I found that the prisoner had disappeared with the 50l.,â€”it was Saturday night, I think, the 24th or 23rd, when I bought Hancock a bonnet.

By the JURY. I met the prisoner on 19th November at the Elephant and Castleâ€”he said he was a commercial travellerâ€”I have wrote an order for the cheque-book for Dudgeon and Co. beforeâ€”I have been sent by them to the back for the pass-bookâ€”I have never had to write a signature for the firm on any occasionâ€”I believe the Artichoke is in the Borough Road.

MARY RAND . I am a widow at 26, Parsonage Walk, Newington Buttsâ€”my husband was alive in November lastâ€”the prisoner and a woman named Hancock lodge with me, and occupied one room in November last for three weeksâ€”they came together as Mr. and Mrs. Waterfield, and passed as man and wife, and I did not know at first that the woman's name was Hancockâ€”the witness Reeve came there, and I have seen him coming in and going out with the prisoner several timesâ€”they came home one morning in a cab, and I have seen them out in a pony and trap togetherâ€”I recollect going into the prisoner's room and waking Reeve one morning at 1 o'clock when the trap was outsideâ€”he looked stupefiedâ€”I had a conversation with himâ€”Waterfield and the woman had goneâ€”she had left her boxes, and I have them nowâ€”the room was in confusion, and the lamp was burningâ€”I have had an application for themâ€”she is in the neighbourhoodâ€”she smashed my looking-glass, and they left without notice, and were a week's rent in debtâ€”my husband saw them there the night before they disappeared, and asked for the rentâ€”the prisoner never returned or made any communication to me.

Cross-examined. I do not know if another woman lived there with Hancock; there were people up and downâ€”I saw some woman thereâ€”my husband has spoken to Hancock about her being there, and said he would not have itâ€”I cannot remember how often I have seen you and Reeve together, or whether you were there on the morning of the 27th Novemberâ€”I said at the Guildhall"The woman went away on the Thursday morning; about 1 o'clock of the afternoon I went up into the room and found Reeve asleep in bed"â€”it was Thursdayâ€”I think there was some paper and ink there, but I left the room till my husband came homeâ€”you had no ink or paper from meâ€”I cannot say if any writing materials were thereâ€”Hancock wrote to me from Birmingham, and asked me to put all the things together and she would forward me the 8s. 6d.â€”the address she gave me had not Waterfield upon itâ€”I sent it to the police-court, and have not seen it since.

Re-examined. This is the letter and address and the envelope. (Letter addressed to"The lady of the house, 28, Parsonage Walk, Newington Butts, London. Madam,â€”You will no doubt think it strange me leaving you in such a hurry. If you will keep the box and all the things I will send for them in a few weeks' time. I left you in debt 7s., one week's rent, and broke a glass, which I value at 12s. 6d., which amounts to 19s. 6d. Put all the things together, and tell me if they are all right You oblige yours sincerely, Nelly Norman. Write and I shall know what to do." Address enclosed:"R. Norman, No. 1, back of 81, Edward Street, Parade, Bir
mingham.") I had no rent-book and kept no memorandum.

WILLIAM SILVERTON . I am a carman and contractor, at 28, Old Castle Street, Bethnal Greenâ€”in November last I had a pony and trap advertised for sale, and the witness Reeve gave me 33l. 5s. for it and took it away with himâ€”I next saw it near the London Road in custody of the police.
Cross-examined. After Reeve bought the trap I was over at the public-house, and he came there to me, but I did not see you.
Re-examined. I was in the side barâ€”I have never seen the prisoner until at the Guildhall.

By the JURY. It did not strike me as wrong to sell the pony and trap to Reeve or I should not have done so; he was smartly dressed, and looked different thenâ€”my son, a boy 14, sold him the cart and gave me the money.

ALFRED SMITH . I am foreman to Mr. Tilly, livery-stable keeper, Artichoke Mews; it is close to the Artichoke public-house, Newington Causeway, about 200 yards from Borough Roadâ€”some time in November last a man came to our yard and went away and came again with Reeveâ€”the other man was taller and older, but I could not identify him, as it was dark, and I could not see his faceâ€”he brought a pony and cart and arranged that I should keep it thereâ€”this was the 27thâ€”he took it there that night, and it remained till the following Mondayâ€”I do not remember the date when he brought the pony.
Cross-examined. Reeve was there on the 27th, but not on 25th or 26thâ€”I never saw you there with Reeveâ€”I can swear to Reeve.
By the JURY. I should say 33l. was a fair price for the pony and trapâ€”I saw Reeve with some man, but I could not say it was the prisonerâ€”I know the date, the 27th, by my book.

CHARLES CLARK . I am a glass manufacturer, at 42, Warwick Street, Blackfriars Roadâ€”I recollect finding a pony and trap in my yard on the 3rd December when I got up in the morning, since which time it has been in the custody of Police Sergeant Smithâ€”I recollect forcing open the boot and finding the books produced.

WILLIAM SMITH (City Detective Sergeant). I had Beevs in custody on 20th December, and he volunteered a statement which lei to my going to. 26, Parsonage Walk and making inquiries about the prisoner, whom I afterwards traced to Leicester and Birminghamâ€”on 12th February I received a warrant for his arrest, and was at Birmingham on 12th April at the Moor Street Police Station, and saw the prisoner, who had just been ac
quitted on a charge of felony before the Recorder at the Birmingham Sessionsâ€”I said "I am a police officer, and I have a warrant for your arrest"â€”I read the warrant to him; the prisoner pointed to the body of the warrant relating to the forging and uttering of the two cheques in question, and I

read it againâ€”no one else was mentioned in the warrantâ€”he said "I shall get over that as I have over this"â€”I said "You know who you are charged with?" he said "Oh, yes; I know all about it; I have heard of it and seen the newspapers"â€”I was in Court when Reeve pleaded guilty at this Courtâ€”no reference to Waterfield was made then, but it was mentioned by Reeve on the committalâ€”I brought the prisoner to London, and charged him at Bishopsgate Street Station on the warrant, and he made no answerâ€”I searched him and found upon him 12s. 3d.â€”I afterwards went and found the pony and cart at Mr. Hill's and the boot was forced open in my presence and by my orders, and these books found containing references to the prisonerâ€”I heard Reeve give his evidence in the Justice Room on 30th April lastâ€”he said "We went together and two women to the Crystal Palace on the 25th November"â€”Waterfield corrected him and said "No, it was the 27th.

Cross-examined. You had been employed at Birmingham as superin
tendent of the Branch Workhouseâ€”I was at Birmingham on 14th February, and the warrant was handed to the Magistrate to be "backed" or signed in case of your acquittalâ€”the man charged with you was admitted to bailâ€”I believe your home is in Birmingham.

GEORGE KIRBY . I am cashier at the Imperial Bank, Lothburyâ€”Dudgeon and Co. have a private account thereâ€”this order, dated 21st November, for 100 cheques was presented at the bank, and the cheques given were numbered 144901 to 145301, and this cheque marked D for 23l. 6s. 6d. was presented the same day and paid in goldâ€”it is the first out of the cheque-book.

ALEXANDER JOHN DUDGEON . I am a director of Dudgeon and Co., Limited, London Street, and keep a private account at the Imperial Bank, and the firm keep an account with the City Bankâ€”the order for cheques on the Imperial Bank and the cheque for 23l. 6s. 6d. are not written by me or by my authorityâ€”Reeve was employed by us as office-boy, and used to go to the bank to change chequesâ€”I had drawn a cheque about three weeks before 21st Novemberâ€”my cheque-books are generally payable to bearer.

WILLIAM ERNEST PERDUE . I am cashier at the City Bank, Threadneedle Streetâ€”this order for a book of 200 cheques was presented by Reeve, and I gave him a cheque-book numbered E. J. 69201 to 69400â€”on the same day this cheque for 971. 8s. 6d. was presented by Reeve, and I paid him in goldâ€”it is the second cheque in the book, E. J. 69202.
JOHN WESLEY COOPER . I am secretary to Dudgeon and Co., Limitedâ€”this order and cheque (produced) on the City Bank were not written by me or with my authority.
WILLIAM GEORGE REEVE (Re-examined). I left the pony and trap at 42, Warwick Street, because I had an accident with it.

p.hi: The following Witnesses were called for the Defence.

div1.p:
HARRIET HANCOCK . I lived at 26, Parsonage Walk in November lastâ€”Elizabeth Ann Johnson was staying with me from the 17th to the 27thâ€”a young man named William Cooper was in the habit of visiting youâ€”I knew Reeve two days before wo left London; he purchased the things for me and Johnson when I left the lodgings the night before I left Londonâ€”we left London on Wednesday, the 26th or 27thâ€”he also gave me two sovereigns; I do not know what he gave Johnsonâ€”he was at Parsonage Walk twiceâ€”he came one evening, and came the next morning to take us to the Crystal Palaceâ€”I have never seen him writing thereâ€”you were em
Ployd

up to the 20th November as traveller for Ferwig's, Union Street, Borough, and I told Mrs. Band that when I took the roomsâ€”Reeve has never slept in my room at night; I had a room to myselfâ€”he never stayed there all nightâ€”he had supper in our house about 7.30 or 8 when we returned from the Crystal Palaceâ€”Elizabeth Johnson was thereâ€”about 10 or 10.30 he asked to go into our room and lie downâ€”he did not stay half an hour; I went a walk, and never saw him again.

Cross-examined. I was living at Parsonage Walk with the prisonerâ€”Reeve asked me to go to the Crystal Palaceâ€”we did not have more than one roomâ€”I slept in the room with the prisonerâ€”Reeve never slept in that roomâ€”I went with the prisoner to Leicester after leaving Parsonage Walkâ€”he was out of employment from 20th Novemberâ€”we were rather in diffi
culties, but I should have paid Mrs. Rand if she had behaved herself properly to meâ€”I told her that night I was goingâ€”we lived at his aunt's at Leicesterâ€”I do not think he had any money but what I had myselfâ€”we then went to Birmingham, and stayed at his father's.

By the COURT. I went by the name of Miss Norman at Parsonage Walk, and took the room in that name, and not as Mr. and Mrs. Waterfieldâ€”I told Mrs. Rand that Waterfield was a friend of mine who called to see meâ€”Cooper used to come and have tea there.

ELIZABETH JOHNSON . I lived in the room with Miss Hancock from 17th to the 27th Novemberâ€”no one else called there to see youâ€”I did not see a young man there till the week you left London, and he spoke to me and Hancockâ€”I was in town with Hancock, and we met Reeve and went to the Rockingham on the evening of 26th November, and he bought me a new pair of boots, a black necktie and a gauze fall, and black kid gloves, and asked us to go to the Crystal Palace with him the next day, and he brought the trap about 10.30 or 11 o'clock in the morningâ€”the first time I saw him in the room was when he asked us to go home to supper after we came from the Crystal Palaceâ€”I used to go and see Miss Hancock and stay with her till night, and I never saw Reeve there until the night we had supperâ€”I have seen him several times near the Elephant and Castle since you left London, and he asked me one night if I would take him home, as he had nowhere to go, and I gave him a shilling, but I was never out driving with him since you leftâ€”you were in employment, and used to be away from 9.30 a.m. to between 5 and 6 p.m.â€”I have never seen you come in a cab.

Cross-examined. I lived there about four days, and slept two nights in the same room with Hancock and the prisoner, but not in the same bedâ€”I cannot say what nights, but it was in the middle of the week.

The Prisoner handed in a written statement, asserting his innocence, and denying that he ever saw Reeve till the evening of November 26th, when he met him with Johnson and Hancock, that they told him that Reeve had bought them some new hats, boots, gloves, &c., and had given Hancock 2l., and was going to take them to the Crystal Palace in the morning in his trap, which he did, and had supper and drink with them, when they left him there and went to Birmingham with the 2l. which Reeve had given Hancock, and they had no other money.

GUILTY .â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

546.
WILLIAM WHITELEY (29)
, Stealing a purse and 33l. 18s. 6 1/2 d., the money of
Isabella Ray, from her person.

ISABELLA RAY . I am a single lady, residing at Claremont Villas, Finsbury Parkâ€”on the afternoon of the 20th inst. I went to Messrs. Barclay, Lombard Street, my bankers, and received a cheque for 52l., which was cashed, 20l. in notes and 32l. in goldâ€”I put the notes in an envelope in the side pocket of my bag (produced), and the 32l. gold into my purse, which had in it 1l. 18s. 6d., making altogether 33l. 18s. 6d., and I put the purse in the bag on the top, and carried the bag in my left handâ€”my sister was at my right side, touching meâ€”we had just left the bank to cross the street to avoid the crush near the Mansion House, when I found my bag open a few inches, and saw the prisoner standing within a foot or so of me, with my purse in his hand, I put out my hand to take it from him and said, "Oh, you have got my purse! Give it to me," and he then ran in the direction of the crowd, and I called out.

Cross-examined. The purse was just on the topâ€”the bag was fastened, but not lockedâ€”I snapped it when I came outside the bank, and after
wards found it open, and at the same time saw the prisoner near me with the purse, and he ran awayâ€”I saw no policeman nearâ€”this was at the end of Lombard Street, near the Mansion House, at 3 p.m.â€”it was done instantlyâ€”I did not get to the Mansion House until late in the day, when I attended and signed the depositions.
Re-examined. The prisoner was looking towards me, and did not speak when I asked him for my purseâ€”I ultimately received the money from the policemanâ€”this is the purse (produced,).

JONATHAN POPE (City Policeman 622). I was on duty in Lombard Street on May 7thâ€”the last witness spoke to me, and I then saw the prisoner running amongst the traffic towards the Mansion House, I ran after him to the front of the Mansion House, between the kerb and the 'busses, and he dodged about among the vehicles, and I came up to him on the foot-way near St. Mildred Court, just as another constable caught himâ€”there was a crowd round himâ€”the other constable held him by his right hand, and seeing the prisoner put his left hand behind him, I seized it, and he said, "What have I done"â€”I pulled up his left hand in front of him, and took the puree from his sleeve, and I left him in charge of the other constableâ€”on examining the puree at the station, I found it contained 33l. 10s. in gold, 8s. 6d. in silver, and a farthing.

Cross-examined. The lady was standing near Mr. Webber's, the con
fectioner's, Lombard Street, when she spoke to me, and I was in the middle of the road directing the traffic, I saw a man running and followed him, and when the prisoner was stopped I found the puree in his sleeve.

THOMAS SMITH (City Policeman 632). I was on duty on 7th May, near the Mansion House, and saw the prisoner walkingâ€”he was just turning towards the Bank of England when I caught him by the right arm, and said "I require you for robbing a lady"â€”I saw him move his left hand in the direction of the crowd, and policeman Pope came up, and caught hold of his left hand, and I took him to the stationâ€”he gave a false address.
Cross-examined. The traffic was very thick.

p.hi: ruled that taking the money from the bag was not taking it from the person, and that it was therefore a case of simple larceny.

div1.p:
GUILTY
of simple larceny. â€”
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

547.
SAMUEL SARGEANT (33)
PLEADED GUILTY to embezzling 10l. 9s., the moneys of
Frederick Richardson and another, his masters.
He received a good character.â€”Six Months' Imprisonment .
(He was also indicted for forging an endorsement to an order for 10l. 9s.,
upon which no evidence woe offered.)

548.
HENRY BENNETT (19)
to burglary in the dwelling, house of
Edward Scott, and stealing therein two books.â€”
Four Months' Imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

549.
JOHN JONES** (34)
to stealing a watch the goods of
George Howells from his person, having been convicted of felony in February, 1872, at Clerkenwell.â€”
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

550.
JOHN WOOD** (35)
to stealing a meerschaum pipe and case, the property of
Francis Jordan.â€”
Nine Month's Imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

551.
JAMES ANDER
SON** (35)
to stealing a chain from the person of
Nicholas William Page, having been before convicted.â€”
Four Months' Imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

552.
WILLIAM WARD (23)
to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Frederick Butter, and stealing three cakes his property.â€”
Four Days' Imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

553.
THOMAS STANNARD (18) and
HENRY UNDERWOOD (18)
, Breaking and. entering the dwelling-house of
William Henry Mardon, with intent to steal.

MR. MONTAGU WILLIAMS
Prosecuted; MR. COLE appeared for Stannard and MR. PURCELL for Underwood.

WILLIAM HENRY MARDON . I live at 169, Marylebone Road, and am an accountantâ€”on Saturday, April 12 last, I returned home about 8.15 p.m.â€”there was no one in the houseâ€”I saw the prisoners at the door; seeing that I was going up the garden path they left the door, and walked down the path, met me, and would have passed me, but I stopped them, asking them what they wantedâ€”Underwood said "I want Mr. Williams, a solicitor"â€”I told him that no person of that name lived there or near, but that Payne lived next door, and another solicitor two doors off whose name I forgotâ€”he said "I know Mr. Payne, but I don't want him"â€”I said"I live here, and I don't want you"â€”they went out at the gate, and turned eastwardâ€”I had a particularly good view of their faces, because there is a street gas lamp immediately at the end of my gardenâ€”I placed my latch key in the door; it did not turn, and with a slight push the door openedâ€”the beading of the door and the catch of the lock were wrenched offâ€”there were marks on the wood as if made by a jimmyâ€”I went to the police-station and gave a descrip
tionâ€”early in the morning of 22nd April I was called out of bed by a police inspector and taken to the station, where I identified the prisoners amongst eight or nine other persons.

Cross-examined by MR. COLE. April 12th was the Saturday between Good Friday and Easter Sundayâ€”mine is a longish front gardenâ€”I did not put my hand on anybody before I identified the prisoners; about six police-men were present.
Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. The household were out of town, and had been for two or three days.
Re-examined. The door was unlatched and the lock was broken awayâ€”the house was safe when I left itâ€”a stone which had been used as a lever
was on the stepâ€”I fitted it to a dent on the doorâ€”when I identified the prisoners they were away from the police.

GEORGE KING (Inspector D). At about 9.30 on Saturday, 12th April, I went to 169, Marylebone Road, and Mr. Mardon pointed out to me his street-foorâ€”the door-post, was broken all to pieces, and there were about 13 different marks of a jimmyâ€”the beading was forced away and the lock broken offâ€”at about a quarter to 1 a.m. on 23rd April I was present in the Marylebone station when Mr. Mardon pointed the prisoners out from about seven others.

Cross-examined by MR. COLE. The others were brought from the streetâ€”they were a cluster of people standing outside a public-houseâ€”I am an old officer, and have had considerable experience with reference to identifica
tions at police stationsâ€”I have known such a thing as an innocent person Drought in from the street being identified.
Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. The prosecutor picked out Stannard and then Underwood.
Re-examined. He said, "That is one," and looked again and said, "That is the other one."

CHARLES DODD (Inspector Y).
