At about 9.30 p.m. on 22nd April I went into the Grecian Theatre, City Road, with Sergeant Otwayâ€”I had previously known the prisoners, and found them thereâ€”I had received a description from the prosecutorâ€”we took them to Somers Town station and then to Marylebone station in a cabâ€”on the road Stannard said"What do you want me for, is it for that affair with Bob Phillips 1 If so, I don't think you will do much good with that, it is too far back"â€”I said"No, it is for breaking into a house in the parish of Marylebone in the present month"â€”he said "Busting is a flat game now, I follow a better job than that, I follow Fred Archer's mounts all theyear round"â€”busting means burglary or house-breakingâ€”he then said"I have 14l. in my pocket, can you be squared? take 71. and let us out of the cab"â€”I made no replyâ€”he then said to Otway, "Take 8l., won't that do, Otway?"â€”Otway replied"Not for 80l."â€”I found on Stannard 13l. 7s. 2d.â€”I had been looking for him.

JOHN OTWAY (Police Sergeant Y). I went with the prisoners and Dodd in the cabâ€”Stannard said to me after speaking to Dodd about having 14l. in his pocket, "I have 8l., Otway, what do you say to that?"â€”I said "Not for 80l."â€”that was to get out of the cab.

WILLIAM HENRY MARDON (Re-examined). I said at the police-court that I saw the prisoners for about two minutes, and that they had dark clothes on and overcoatsâ€”when I saw Underwood at the station he had no over-coat on.

MARGARET BUCKLEY . I live at 11, Draper's Place, Euston Road, and am singleâ€”I know Stannardâ€”we went to the Princess's Theatre and saw "It's Never Too Late to Mend," the night after Good Fridayâ€”we want in the gallery, and paid 6d.â€”he met me by appointment, at 7 o'clock, at the Lon
don Spa, Exmouth Street, Clerkenwellâ€”the appointment was made at his mother's house the previous eveningâ€”we got to the theatre about 7.50â€”my sister Kate was with us, and Henry Underwood and his young womanâ€”we left the theatre at about 10.30 or 10.40â€”we went into the Rising Sun, Euston Road, and had some ale.

Cross-examined. I was not called as a witness at the police-courtâ€”Stan
nard's

father was locked up for coming up as a witness, and I was frightened to go into Courtâ€”I have known Stannard since about a week before Christ
masâ€”I am in the habit of going out with himâ€”he does not live with meâ€”he lives at 30, Vineyard Streetâ€”he does not come to my place to sleepâ€”I am his young womanâ€”the night he took me to the theatre he had a pair of earrings in his ears, which he has worn since I have known himâ€”I don't know whether Underwood is a companion of hisâ€”I had met him with his young woman before I saw him at the theatre.

Re-examined. I went to the police-court with the intention of speaking what I have spoken nowâ€”they locked old Stannard up for about half an hour at Marylebone Police-courtâ€”I think Dodd locked him upâ€”he went to give evidence in favour of his sonâ€”he is now at work in the country I think.

KATE BUCKLEY . I live at 11, Draper's Place, with my sisterâ€”the Saturday night after Good Friday I went to the Princess's Theatre with Henry Underwood, Stannard and his young woman, and my sisterâ€”we saw "It's Never to Late to Mend"â€”we met Stannard at the London Spa, Exmouth Street, about 7 o'clockâ€”we got to the theatre at about 7.50â€”we did not stop till the end of the playâ€”we all left together about 10.30â€”I recollect the day because it was a wet Saturday, and I did not go to marketâ€”I had a holiday on Easter Mondayâ€”I sell things in the streetâ€”I was at work on Good Friday.

Cross-examined. My sister is Stannard's young woman, and I believe Copman is Underwood's young womanâ€”I never saw Underwood before that nightâ€”I was at the police-court but was not calledâ€”Draper's Place is a good way from the Euston Road.

SARAH COPMAN . I live at 9, Gloucester Street, Hackney Bond, and have known Underwood about 14 monthsâ€”I went to the Princess's Theatre with him the Saturday after Good Fridayâ€”I met him at the London Spa at 7 o'clock, and we got to the theatre about 7.45 and left about 10.30 or 10.40â€”Underwood was in my company all the time.

Cross-examined. I was at the police-court, but did not give evidenceâ€”Stannard's father told me they were in custodyâ€”I have known Stannard about six monthsâ€”I am Underwood's young womanâ€”the prisoners have been several times together.
Re-examined. I did not hoar Underwood say at the police-court "I reserve my defence," or words to that effectâ€”I am intimate with Stannard's fatherâ€”he came to me in Gloucester Street.
WILLIAM HENRY MARDON (Re-examined). When I saw Stannard in my garden I noticed wires in his earsâ€”I presume they were gold.
Inspector Dodd (Re-examined). When I took Stannard he had gold wires in his earsâ€”I know the witnesses for the defenceâ€”I don't know where the wires areâ€”I did not take them from his ears.

GUILTY of the attempt. STANNARD*â€”
Seven Years Penal Servitude
and to pay 13l. towards the expenses of the prosecutiony with a view to its being given to Bacchus . (See page 144.) UNDERWOOD*â€”
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.

554.
HENRY UNDERWOOD was again indicted
for breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Ellen Tidy, and stealing a gold chain, a gold cross, and other articles, her property.

ELLEN TIDY . I live at 52, George Street, Portman Squareâ€”Miss Mary Alexander is the owner of the houseâ€”she was away on Saturday, April 12th, and I left the house on Sunday afternoonâ€”I returned about 11 o'clock, and found the place had been broken into and the box staple taken off the doorâ€”I missed a gold chain, a cross, a ring, links, and other articles, and this silk handkerchief (produced)â€”I identify it by a mark in the cornerâ€”I missed about 5l. worth of property altogether.

ALFRED RICKETT (Policeman D 184). I was on duty on Sunday, 13th April, in George Street, at 10.10 p.m., and found the door of this house broken open and the marks of a jemmy over the lockâ€”I called the attention of other policemen to itâ€”I went in and found the contents of a box turned outâ€”I saw Miss Ellen Tidy and informed her.

JOHN OTWAY . I apprehended the prisoner on another charge on 22nd Aprilâ€”he was taken to Marylebone station and searched, and in his pocket I found the silk handkerchief producedâ€”I asked him to account for its possession, and Stannard, who was with him, said that they bought two at the boatrace.
NOT GUILTY .

555.
MARY MURRAY (39),
JEREMIAH MURRAY (19), and
JOHN COLLINS (16)
, Robbery on
Charles Sullivan, and stealing from his person 1s. his money.
(The Prosecutor did not appear.)

WILLIAM JACKSON . I live at 85, Ellington Street, Pimlico, and am a provision store keeperâ€”I was in Westminster on 11th May at 1 a.m., and saw the prisoners in Peter Street at the corner of Worcester Groundsâ€”I saw Jeremiah get hold of the prosecutor, and they shook him, and said "We will have a shilling"â€”Mary Murray got hold of him by the throat, and Jeremiah Murray put his foot out, and put the prosecutor down, and Collins got his knee across the prosecutor's breastâ€”I ran a little way, and told the policeâ€”the prosecutor in the meantime to defend himself got his plyers out and they thought it was a knife, but he never struck themâ€”I saw some coppers in the prosecutor's handsâ€”I don't know where he isâ€”the female was the worst of the lot.
NOT GUILTY .

556.
JOHN COLLINS was again indicted
for assaulting
William Butler, a police officer, in the execution of his duty.

WILLIAM BUTLER (Policeman B 297). I went to assist the constable in the last case to the prisoner's house, Worcester Ground, where I found B 298, the prosecutor and the last witness and six or seven other personsâ€”I did not see the prisoner thereâ€”I assisted the other constable with Murray out of the room, and got to the comer of Peter Street, when the prisoner ran across the street, and gave me a violent blow over the eye with this belt with a brass ring (produced)â€”Jackson ran after him, and the prisoner threw him downâ€”he was then charged with stealing a shilling and assaulting me.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I saw you hit me with the belt. By the Court. I did not attempt to interfere with him, nor did the other constableâ€”I was taking Murray on a charge of felony.

JOSEPH SIMMONS (Policeman B 298). I had Jeremiah Murray in custodyâ€”â€”the crowd tried to rescue himâ€”I saw the prisoner strike Butler across the face with something; I cannot say whatâ€”he then ran away, and was followed.

Prisoner's Defence. B 297 was taking Murray, and there was a crowd followingâ€”the policeman who took me in custody let go, and another policeman took his place, and he took out his staff, and would have hit another young man, and then he turned round to me, and said, "You had better go home. "I said, "I am going home." He said, "Go along home, or else I will give you some of this if you don't go off."
WILLIAM BUTLER (Re-examined). I did not draw my staff at all.

GUILTY .â€”
Three Months' Imprisonment.

557.
GEORGE PRICE (35)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Julius Balcoe, and stealing therein 29 pairs of trousers, his property.

JULIUS BALCOE . I am a tailor, of 65, Chambers Street, Whitechapelâ€”on the morning of 6th May I lost 29 pairs of trousers, worth about 18l.â€”this is a portion of the property (produced)â€”they were safe on my premises at 12 o'clock the night before; I locked the house up at 11.30â€”I was awakened by a dog barking at about 4.30 a.m.â€”I went down into the workshop, and missed the goodsâ€”I dressed myself and went into Great Prescott Street, where I saw the prisoner in custody and a black bag containing the propertyâ€”I charged the prisonerâ€”I went out by my front door, which was unboltedâ€”the workshop window was openâ€”the workshop is not separated from the dwelling-house.

WILLIAM THOMPSON (Policeman H 84). I was on duty about 4.30 in Chambers Street, Whitechapel, and saw the prisoner come out of the prosecutor's front door, and close it behind himâ€”he was carrying a large black bag and a bundle under his armâ€”he saw me coming in the opposite directionâ€”I followed him into Great Prescott Street, stopped him, and asked him what he hadâ€”he said "Goods"â€”I said, "What goods?"â€”he said, "Clothes I am going to take to the tailor"â€”I asked him to give me an account of them, and said I should have to take him to the station for unlawful possessionâ€”Balcoe came up and said, "That man has broken into my house"â€”I went back and examined the premises, and found the prisoner had climbed over a wall between 7 and 8 feet highâ€”there was a broken pane of glass, and a brick torn out of the wall where he had climbed up.

p.hi: The Prisoner handed a written statement to the Court.

div1.p:
GUILTY .** He was further charged with having been convicted of felony in November, 1865, in the name of
Henry Rose, to which he

PLEADED GUILTY, he being still on ticket of leave.â€”
Twelve Months' Imprisonment, to commence from the expiration of the former sentence.

558.
ROBERT HUBBARD** (22)
PLEADED GUILTY to stealing 201b. of beef, the goods of
Solomon de Leeuw, having been previously convicted of felony.â€”
Two Years' Imprisonment.

559.
WILLIAM JONES (18)
, Robbery with violence, with other persons unknown, on
Robert Crawford, and stealing a chain, his property.
MR. TAMPLIN Prosecuted; MR. FRITH Defended.

ROBERT CRAWFORD . I have an office at 4, Chapel Street, Mayfairâ€”about midnight on 26th April I was in Long Acre with a friend, Mr. Macgregor, going home towards Piccadilly, when six or seven boys came towards me, some on the pavement and some in the road, so that I could not pass, and one of them struck at my face with his fist, but I kept off the blow with my arm, and at the same moment the prisoner, who was the tallest of them, butted at me with his head and snatched my watch chain, and broke it off at the swivelâ€”I felt the tugâ€”the watch remainedâ€”I then knocked the prisoner down in front of me, but was knocked down myself, so that I could not hold himâ€”he got up and somebody else got between us, and I had to fight my way through themâ€”he ran away and I followedâ€”he ran into a doorway and stood straight up with his back against the doorâ€”I caught hold of his arm, and a policeman came upâ€”I never lost sight of the prisonerâ€”my chain was worth 30s. or lessâ€”Mr. Macgregor was close behind me, and I broke my stick in the struggle and called to him for his.

Cross-examined. I had been to a friend's house in Torrington Placeâ€”I had nothing to drink on my way back, and was perfectly soberâ€”I charged the prisoner with stealing ray watch, but found it safe in my pocket after at the stationâ€”I said at the police-court "I tried to follow the man who ran into me, but the others dodged in between us and I got knocked down several times"â€”that is correctâ€”Mr. Macgregor was behind meâ€”the door-way is round the cornerâ€”I did not speak to the prisonerâ€”I might have told the police sergeant that I had lost my watch and chain in a fight, but I do not rememberâ€”when I gave the prisoner in charge I said "That is the boy who has taken my watch"â€”I did not say I thought he was one of them, but was not sureâ€”at the police station I said I was sure he had taken my chainâ€”I heard Mr. Macgregor swear to the prisoner being the man who took itâ€”I was not hurt.

Re-examined. I was butted in the stomach and my hat' driven over my head, and I was knocked down by a blow on the top of the head, but was not hurtâ€”I saw the prisoner all the time and saw him knock me downâ€”I did not examine the inside of my pocket until I got to the police station.

WILLIAM MACGREGOR . I live at 3, Queen's Gate, Westminster, and was with the prosecutor at midnight on 26th April walking down Long Acre, on our way to Piccadilly, when six or seven boys came up and stopped usâ€”the prisoner was one of themâ€”I was standing by the prosecutor's side when the prisoner rushed at him and struck at him about the head, but he kept off the blowâ€”one of the others then rushed behind the prosecutor and took I hold of him by the collar, and the prisoner rushed in and butted him in the stomach and tried to take his watch, and the prosecutor called out "He has taken my watch"â€”wit was dark; I did not see him take the chainâ€”I did not notice a lamp nearâ€”we then chased him for about two minutes, and did not lose sight of himâ€”I have no hesitation in identifying him.

Cross-examined. I do not know that neighbourhoodâ€”we did not run farâ€”I heard the prosecutor complain of losing his watch, and when the policeman came up he found the chain had been broken offâ€”we had not been out to supper, and had nothing to drink on our way from Torrington Placeâ€”I am not a medical student.
JAMES MACKINTOSH (Police Sergeant E 10). I was on duty in Long Acre about midnight of April 26th, and saw a crowd of men and boys at

the corner of James Street and Long Acreâ€”I went up and saw the prose
cutor and the prisoner and the last witnessâ€”the prisoner was standing in the crowd, and the prosecutor charged him with stealing his watch and passing it to some one in the crowdâ€”I took hold of him and he said, "If I have got your watch, you had better go to the station"â€”on the way to the station the prosecutor said, "I have still got my watch, the chain only is gone"â€”the prisoner, when charged at the station, said it was merely a got up affair.

Cross-examined. The prosecutor told me he had been attacked by the prisoner, and he had taken his watch and chainâ€”he did not say he had lost it in a fightâ€”the prisoner went quietly to the station and was searched, and no watch or chain found on himâ€”the chain was gone altogether from the watch.

GUILTY of the assault with intent to rob. Recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of his youth.
He
PLEADED GUILTY**(â€ ) to having been previously convicted of felony at the Marlborough Street Police-court on December 19th, 1877, in the name of
Patrick Leonard.â€”
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.

560.
HENRY HAYDAY (22),
WILLIAM EWING (22),
RALPH ROBERTS (20), and
JAMES FINNIS (18)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Winter, with intent to steal.
MESSRS. M. WILLIAMS and GILL Prosecuted; MR. D. METCALFE defended Ewing, and MR. GEOGHEGAN Defended Finnis.

JOHN WINTER . I keep a watchmaker's shop at 285, Globe Roadâ€”on the night of May 6th my back window was fastened with a catch insideâ€”I fasten up the premises, and am the last up, and it was safe between 9 and 10 o'clockâ€”the next morning between 1 and 2 o'clock I was aroused, and the officer drew my attention to the window being raised two or throe inchesâ€”a knife would spring the catch back, but they could not get inside, because there was an iron shutter.

Cross-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN. There was an iron shutter inside, and close to the window, and they could not get into the room without opening the shutterâ€”it is fastened inside the room, and could not be opened from the outside by fair meansâ€”the catch could not be moved without the knifeâ€”the knife could not open the shutterâ€”it could be removed by a jemmy.

RICHARD WILDEY (Police Inspector K). At 12.40 a.m. on May 7th I was in Cambridge Road, and saw there the four prisoners with another manâ€”I was not in uniformâ€”I watched them and saw them walk up Green Street, three on one side and two on the other side of the wayâ€”I saw Hayday and Ewing or Roberts and the fifth man go through Victoria Park Square, through Sugarloaf Walk into Globe Road, where Finnis and Roberts, or Ewing, joined themâ€”they then all turned down Sugarloaf Walk again.â€”I had three sergeants with me then, Rolfe, Smith, and Murrell, all in plain clothesâ€”the fifth man came towards us, and on seeing us he ran away up Globe Roadâ€”Rolfe and myself followed the other four men through Sugar-loaf Walk after I had given instructions to the other two sergeantsâ€”Sugar-loaf Walk is a narrow passage with a wall on one side and palisading on the otherâ€”we went through this passage into Victoria Park Square, where we saw Smith and Murrell on the ground struggling with Hayday and Finnis, and Rolfe assisted Smith and Murrell to take them in custody, and from

what Smith and Murrell told us we went back to Sugarloaf Walk, where I assisted Rolfe on to the wall of the houses at Globe Road, and after search
ing the backs of the houses for about three quarters of an hour, I saw Roberts and Ewing in custody, being brought from the back of a house facing the Victoria Park Squareâ€”they were found on the roof of an out-houseâ€”I searched about there and found in a gutter this knife (produced)â€”it had two streaks of paint upon itâ€”it is just such a knife as would open a windowâ€”I then examined the window sash at 285, Globe Road, about 150 yards from where the knife was found, and found the catch had been put back, and there were marks on the paint of the sashâ€”the gardens of the houses meet back to backâ€”this jemmy (produced) was handed to me next day by James Gosnel, and the four prisoners were charged with attempting to break into 285, Globe Road, a jeweller's shopâ€”Ewing said, "I am a stranger myself; I deny it was a jeweller's shop"â€”the other prisoners made no reply to the chargeâ€”the knife was found in the gutter of the roof of an outhouse at the back of one of the houses in Victoria Park Square.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. When I saw the two men join the other three in Victoria Park Square, I did not know which was Ewing and which was Robertsâ€”I knew them and had seen them before, but we were obliged to keep some 50 or 60 yards away, and at that distance I could not tell which was Roberts or Ewingâ€”I did not see them taken into custodyâ€”I found the knife myself, and there were two slight streaks of paint across itâ€”I wrapped it in paper and took it to the police-court, and when I took it out the marks were goneâ€”there is a ropeyard at one side of the Sugarloaf Walk, and near 185, Globe Roadâ€”the yard where Ewing and Roberts were found adjoins the rope-yardâ€”no fault was found with the police at the police-courtâ€”on the first hearing no depositions were taken, but merely a note to remand the prisonersâ€”I have no doubt I said a window was broken, but I believe it had been broken previously, and fastened up with paper, and the paper was brokenâ€”it was not stated then that the window was brokenâ€”I do not think the evidence about it being forced open was omittedâ€”I gave evidence, but said nothing about itâ€”I have not said that I found the window open, but that I found the marks on the window and the catch pushed backâ€”that would be between 2 and 3 o'clockâ€”I do not think the prosecutor had seen it then.

Cross-examined by Roberts. I might have said at the police-court that there was a window brokenâ€”I said nothing about puttyâ€”at the station I said the knife found was one used to take putty out of a windowâ€”the marks upon it were dried paint.

Cross-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN. I do not know Hayday's age, or who his father isâ€”I was alone when I first saw the prisonersâ€”Rolfe joined me at the end of Cambridge Road before they separated into two parties, and he was present thenâ€”I saw the two sergeants and the two prisoners struggling or fighting on the ground, and I went to their assistanceâ€”they were all on the ground turning over and overâ€”there is a urinal in Cam
bridge Roadâ€”the passage runs between Victoria Park Square and Globe Roadâ€”there are houses on one side the square, and the other side is the Bethnal Green Museumâ€”where I saw Hayday and Finnis was in the square between the Museum and the housesâ€”I first saw the prosecutor's window between 2 and 3 o'clock, and examined it carefullyâ€”I saw the iron shutter. Cross-examined by Mr. Metcalfe. I was present when Ewing gave his

name and the address of the Three Bulls lodging-house, Brick Laneâ€”I made inquiries, but he was not known by name thereâ€”it is a large placeâ€”they are very reticent at lodging-houses in giving information to the police.
Re-examined. I had to keep a distance away from the two prisoners, because they knew meâ€”we could identify them and pick them outâ€”nobody was working at the rope-walk.

JOHN SMITH (Detective Sergeant K). I was with Wildey on the night of May 6th, and saw the four prisoners in company with a fifth man, and I watched them, in consequence of the directions Wildey gave meâ€”I saw the five men together several times within half an hour, and saw them pass Burnham Square, near where the offence occurred in Globe Roadâ€”they walked backwards and forwards at different parts of the roadâ€”I next heard a noise in Sugarloaf Walk of some one getting over a fence, and of some one runningâ€”I was at the end in Burnham Squareâ€”I ran round by Victoria Park Square to the other end of the passage, and just before I got there I heard a whistle, and saw Hayday and Finnis standing in Sugarloaf Walk, looking through the garden fence of 285, Globe Roadâ€”it was not necessary to get over a fence to get to themâ€”I said, "What are you two doing here?"â€”they both answered, "Nothing, sir," and that they had nothing about themâ€”I told Hayday I should take him in custody, and that I was a police officerâ€”he became very violent, and threw me downâ€”Wildey came up and assisted me, and Finnis and Hayday were taken into custody.
By the COURT. The fence is at the back of No. 293â€”the prisoners were in the Parsonage Walk at the backâ€”the struggle was in Victoria Park Square, a thoroughfare.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. I was in the urinal in Cambridge Road before going in the passage, and saw all the prisoners come in and pass by me, but they did not appear to notice meâ€”I was not in uniform.

Cross-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN. The fence is in Sugarloaf Walkâ€”I do not think Murrell fell on the groundâ€”I was downâ€”Rolfe was with me and assisted Murrellâ€”the four policemen and two prisoners were there to
getherâ€”I did not hear Murrell ask Finnis any questions other than what I have statedâ€”when I caught them at the fence I did not let them goâ€”it is a rough board fenceâ€”the prisoners were standing with their backs to me at first, and when they heard us approaching they faced us and walked towards us.

RICHARD WILDEY (Re-examined). We saw them in Sugarloaf Walk, at the Victoria Park Square endâ€”it runs at right angles from Victoria Park Road to the Squareâ€”the fence is in Sugarloaf Walk, and runs the whole lengthâ€”293 is the corner houseâ€”we went in at the Globe Road endâ€”where the prisoners were looking through the fence is 100 yards from the house in Victoria Park Square, where the other two prisoners were found on the outhouse.

By the COURT. The rope-walk adjoins the corner house, and runs the same sideâ€”there is a fence on both sides of the walkâ€”they were in the thoroughfare of Sugarloaf Walk, looking into the garden at the rear of the house at the corner of Victoria Park Square.
GEORGE MURRELL (Detective Sergeant K). On the night of the 6th or the

morning of the 7th I saw Hayday and Finnis standing in Sugarloaf Walk, about six yards apart from each other, looking through the fencing at its junction with Victoria Park Squareâ€”Smith asked Hayday what he was doing thereâ€”ho replied, "Nothing, I have got nothing about me"â€”he said that at once, without any question about itâ€”I then caught hold of Finnis and asked what he was doingâ€”he said, "Nothing; I have nothing about me"â€”I put ray hand to his pocket outside, and felt something, and I then put my hand in and found this gun wrench (produced)â€”I said, "What do you call this?"â€”he said, "It is a toothpick"â€”I said I should detain him, and he became very violent, and we struggled together and fell on the ground, and Wildey and Rolfe came up, and we took the prisoners into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN. Smith and myself were together, and I could hear what he said to Hayday, and he could hear what I said to Finnisâ€”when I asked him what he was doing there, Finnis said, "Nothing, I have nothing about me"â€”I can swear thatâ€”I gave evidence at the police-court, and my deposition was read over to me, and I signed itâ€”I said, "I caught hold of Finnis and asked him what he was doing, and what he had about him. He said nothing."

WILLIAM ROLFE (Police Sergeant K). I was with the other officersâ€”after Finnis and Hayday were in custody I was lifted on to a wall 10 feet high by Inspector Wildeyâ€”on getting on to a shed I saw Ewing and Roberts at the prosecutor's back windowâ€”I shouted, "What are you two doing there?"â€”they instantly ran from the window in a stooping position towards meâ€”I was on a shed 20 feet highâ€”Roberts then threw something at me which I thought was a piece of wood, but this crowbar (produced) was afterwards picked up thereâ€”I said, "You cowards, you cannot get away"â€”they came towards me and got on to the ashbin, and then on to a brick wall five feet high with wooden palings on the top about 3 feet highâ€”they broke down the wooden palings and jumped into (he timber-yard adjoining and ran along on their hands and kneesâ€”I ran along three different roofs after them, and then lost sight of themâ€”I called for the policemen to bring their lamps and get assistanceâ€”K 132 brought his lamp, and after searching for nearly three quarters of an hour I saw two posts in the builder's yardâ€”I climbed up and found Roberts and Ewing crouching together on the roof of an outhouseâ€”they said, "You are too strong for us, we will go quietly"â€”K 132 was with meâ€”I found this knife (produced) near the prisoners, under the tiles of the roofâ€”the distance of the prosecutor's house to the place where the jemmy was found is not more than 30 yards.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. The yards are not pavedâ€”the crowbar fell on the ashes and would make no noiseâ€”the walls of the shed slant inwards, coming to a pointâ€”I got on the topâ€”it was between 1.30 and 2 o'clock, a moonlight night, and light enough to see the men in the yardâ€”the shed was about 15 yards from No. 285, where I saw the two prisoners with their backs towards meâ€”I said,. "What are you two doing there?" and they turned round and came towards meâ€”they could not get out of the yard any other wayâ€”285 is the third house from the corner at the junction of Globe Road and Sugarloaf Walkâ€”the corner house is a little chandler's shopâ€”it was about three-quarters of an hour before we found them.
Cross-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN. I was with Inspector Wildey at the beginningâ€”it was three quarters of an hour after he lifted me on the wall
that I arrested Ewing and Robertsâ€”I have seen implements like this gun-wrench, but do not know that they are sold in the shops and in the streets at 2d. eachâ€”it might be used for anything.

JAMES GOSNELL . I live at the chandler's shop, No. 279, at the corner of Globe Road and Sugarloaf Walkâ€”I found this jemmy on May 7th, about 12.45 p.m., at the end of my yard near the dust-binâ€”there is a high wall at the back of the yard, and another separating it from the backs of the houses in Victoria Park Road.
Cross-examined by Roberts. I found the jemmy over the dust-bin on the rafters of a fence three feet from the groundâ€”the fence is between my premises and the next door.
Roberts's Defence. I have never seen that iron before.

GUILTY of the attempt . HAYDAY** and ROBERTS**â€”
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment each . EWINGâ€”
Nine Months' Imprisonment.

FINNISâ€”
Six Months' Imprisonment.

div0.p: OLD COURT.â€”Thursday and Friday, May 29th and 30th, 1879.

div1.p:
561.
ADAM ADDISON (39) and
MARY JANE BOYCE (39) were indicted for
the wilful murder of
Mary Ann Robinson. In a Second Count Addison was charged as a principal and Boyce as an accessory after the fact They were also charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with the like murder.

MESSRS. POLAND, MONTAGU WILLIAMS, and HORACE AVORY Prosecuted; MR. EDWARD CLARK, with MR. SAFFORD, appeared for Addison, and MR. FULTON for Boyce. The details of the evidence in this case (one of procuring abortion), were of a nature unfit for publication.

ADDISONâ€”
GUILTY
of manslaughter. â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

BOYCEâ€”
GUILTY of manslaughter, and as an accessory after the fact .â€”
Two Years' Imprisonment.

div0.p: NEW COURT.â€”Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, May 29th, 30th, and 31st, 1879.

div1.p:
562.
EDWARD LAWRENCE LEVY (53) was again indicted
(See page 68) for feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of 29l., with intent to defraud.
MR. GORST, Q.C., and MR. A. B. KELLY Prosecuted; the SOLICITOR-GENERAL and MR. BESLEY Defended.

LORD DORCHESTER. In November, 1876, an application was made to me in writing by, I believe, some one named Fisher in Leicester Square; but I am speaking from recollection, for an account that had been owing by the Hon. Mrs. Carltonâ€”I have searched for it, but have not found itâ€”in consequence of that I sent this cheque in a letter, to the best of my belief, and it was acknowledgedâ€”I have not found the receipt yet, but I can swear to having had itâ€”I have not found it for reasons which I can give. (The letter was dated 23, Leicester Square, November 23, 1876, from J. C. Fisher and Co., and stated: "My Lord,â€”We beg to hand you a receipt for your cheque for Mr. Worth's account; we are at a loss to conceive the reason
of your lordship complaining that her ladyship is not to be trusted, &c.," and complaining that the cheque was drawn 10d. short, as no interest hod been asked for.)

CHARLES FREDERICK WORTH . I am a dressmaker, of 7, Rue de la Paix, Parisâ€”I do not personally take any part in the financial part of my businessâ€”my regular financial manager is Mr. Mantel, who has been with me 21 years, and my son Gaston takes an active part in the businessâ€”I never saw the prisoner and never gave him authority to sign my name on cheques or billsâ€”my initials are C. F., and this signature C. J. Worth on this cheque is not mine; nor did I ever give any one authority to place it thereâ€”the letters which passed between my firm and the defendant were not written or signed by meâ€”the general course of business was for the letters to be signed by Mantelâ€”this letter, dated Paris, 1st September, 1877, is mine, (This was in French, addressed to Mr. Levy, requesting him to hand over all matters' and papers to Mr. Andrews, of the firm of Andrews and Mason, 78, Iron-wonqer Lane, with a detailed account of all proceedings taken, signed C. F. Worth.)

Cross-examined by the SOLICITOR-GENERAL. Mr. Mantel made the arrange
ment with the prisoner on his own authority as to conducting my affairsâ€”I personally knew nothing about itâ€”I was not consulted in any way.

GASTON WORTH . I am a son of the last witness, and am in business with himâ€”I remember negotiations taking place in the summer of 1876 between our house and Fisher and Co.â€”they were in writingâ€”I saw this letter after it arrived, but I did not myself transmit any accounts to Fisher and Co. for collection, or receive moneys transmitted by them to usâ€”I remember going with Mr. Andrews to Leicester Square in the first week of October, 1877 we saw Mr. Levy and one of his sons, Mr. Daniel Levy I believeâ€”I asked Mr. Levy for an accountâ€”he said "I cannot give it to you now"â€”I believe I went on a Wednesdayâ€”I said, "When can you give it to me?"â€”he said "Next Friday"â€”I asked him to give me an approximate account at onceâ€”he got into a temper and used hard words, and said "Do you expect I shall give you an account of 1,400l. or 1,600l. in a minute?"â€”I said, "Haw you not a ledger, and cannot you tell me in a second, as I would myself, what you owe me and what I owe you?"â€”he said, "I don't keep a ledger, I have to look all over my books for two years, and I cannot do that in a second"â€”I asked him to be faithful and give the account on Friday next, as I was obliged to go to Paddington, and I begged him to send it to Mr. Andrews at onceâ€”ho promised faithfully to do so on the Fridayâ€”Mr. Andrews said nothing that I rememberâ€”Mr. Daniel Levy was presentâ€”I did not hear from Levy then or at any other time anything about Lord Dorchester's cheque.

LOUIS PHILIPPE MANTEL (Through an Interpreter). I am financial agent to Mr. Worth, of Paris, holding a power of attorneyâ€”all correspondence on commercial matters passes through my handsâ€”I had an introduction to the prisoner in the autumn of 1876, and had negotiations with him as to his undertaking to collect debts in England for Mr. Worthâ€”as the result of my negotiations I received this English letter of 23rd August from Mr. Levyâ€”the arrangement in it was not changed afterwards; it was confirmed; this letter, dated 19th October, 1876, was written by one of the clerks in my office by my authority, and he signed it after I had read it (This being translated, enclosed 12 accounts amounting to over 1,0001. to Mr. Levy,

among which was one due from the Hon. Mrs. Carleton of 29l. 0s. 10d., re
questing him to obtain payment for them with costs in case of non-payment. Signed,"Blancherdet") All sums which have been received have been acknow
ledged, and we can prove that by copies of the acknowledgmentâ€”if the defendant has not received our acknowledgment for the amount due from Mrs. Carleton, then we have not received itâ€”I have got my books hereâ€”I never received this cheque (produced)â€”the name on the back of it is not written by me nor by my authorityâ€”the defendant called on me in February, 1877, and handed me a sum of money, giving me at the same time the names of the persons from whom the money had been receivedâ€”I have the names here, but Mrs. Carleton's name is not oneâ€”Levy did not tell me then or at any time that he had received a cheque from Lord Dorchesterâ€”I did not see Levy again in May, 1877â€”I did not give him authority to endorse Mr. Worth's name on a cheque.

Cross-examined by the SOLICITOR-GENERAL. I took a note in writing of the sums paid; this is our cash-book; it contains all the items which have been written in; a clerk wrote these items before meâ€”this is another cash-book with the summary of all the receiptsâ€”this item of 17th February, with the total sum was written by me, it is headed "par Levy"â€”it is a general summary consisting of many debtors, but here is the name in the margin, of the sum which Levy paid; the last line is not in my writing, it is written by Blancherdet by my authorityâ€”he is not here, because he has not been asked to comeâ€”he gave me this account which he received; there was 1,500 francs in money, and a cheque for 8,368 francs, or 297l. 10s. 5d., for the balanceâ€”this is Levy's account (produced)â€”there is a sum of 5,000 and odd francs to be added to itâ€”it is on a piece of paper torn from a block-book which I keep for the purpose; it was written in my presence in the office by Mr. Levy, who gave me at that time a cheque for the balance on the block-note 297l. oddâ€”no book is kept in our establishment which will show in what form a clerk has received money; it would simply be in franc money. no. sayin. th. nature o. itâ€”i. th. cler. receive. an English chequ. o. an English banker he would enter the equivalent in Frenc. moneyâ€”. ca. tel. by th. bloc. not. tha. thi. 1,500 franc. wa. receive. i. English money and the rest in a chequeâ€”that block note is produced by Mr. Levy, and you must see that the sums correspondâ€”if there was no block note I could tell by the dossier in what form we received this money; this (produced) is the letter which shows when Mr. Levy began; we believe we had to do with Mr. Levy and we always corresponded with him in that nameâ€”this is endorsed to Mons. Levy, not to Fisher and Co.; this produced is the first book of notes of accounts; the cash book which you have seen will show the receipts of February 16th, the cheque proves that the clerk received the 297l. 10s. 5d. by chequeâ€”he gave it at the' same time as he gave the 1,500 francs, and I recollected it myself, it took place in my presenceâ€”I received the sums, and Blancherdet entered them in my presenceâ€”the cheque was immediately transferred from English money into French and credited in French; the first book relative to that is the cash-book; we are able also to show the memoranda of the purchaser of the cheque; it was M. Rodrigues frere, a gentleman to whom we commonly give cheques for that purposeâ€”this is my signature on the back of itâ€”I have produced my power of attorney as representing Mr. Worth, for that purposeâ€”Rodrigues no

doubt sold it to Belperre, whose name is on it; we do not know the other names on it, we only know Rodrigues, who changed it for us; there are two names on the block note which do not appear in the book, you will find Malcom at the top in the large book, his name was entered in another book because it was carried to the bad debtors' account; it was considered as a bad debt, and for the sake of the regularities of the books it has been carried to the account of the bad debtorsâ€”the reason that this 565 francs is not entered in the small cash-book is because Malcom has been entered among the bad debtors, and when money was paid on his account it had to be entered in the large book; all the sums are there; you will see the total of the sums of 16th February there, and all those sums total are entered by myself in this large cash-book, and consequently all the large sumsâ€”there is also a large ledger in Paris which will show how this large total is made upâ€”the gross total of receipts on 16th February, by the large book, is 25,997 francs in money, and 294 francs in paper, but there is to be a deduction of 565 francs for Malcomâ€”Malcom was entered under date of 15th February for the regularity of entries in the book, because on the 15th there were three different items to be entered, and that was included. Q. Is it the fashion in France to enter the receipt of a sum of money before it is received? A. It is not exactly a regular piece of business, but it hat been done to make one total sum of the different sums receivedâ€”the big book was made up on the same evening, 16th February. Q. Do you mean to say that making up the books on 16th February you actually wrote on purpose that it had been received on the 15th? A. Possibly it may be an error in dateâ€”I came over here to give evidence before the Magistrateâ€”I gave evidence about 16th Octoberâ€”I cannot say whether the prisoner com
plained that it had been arranged by the Magistrate that the case was not to be taken on that dayâ€”I don't know that it was promised on my behalf that I should come back again to be examinedâ€”I was not served with a subpoena that dayâ€”I don't remember receiving a summons to reappearâ€”I think Mr. Hall was with me in the streetâ€”I do not recollect being served with a subpoena to attend, and being cross-examined on the prisoner's behalfâ€”I came over twice, but I was not in Courtâ€”I was in Londonâ€”this is my sig
nature on this cheque, not Mr. Worth'sâ€”it has been sold and cashed in the same wayâ€”it is rather difficult for me to say whether this produced is a piece of my block noteâ€”the pieces resemble each other very muchâ€”I don't think Mr. Levy has received credit for this 40l.â€”I sent him over this cash, order producedâ€”if this 13l. and 40l. are not entered they have not been receivedâ€”the cheque which was passed through our changers, Messrs. Rod
rigues, and signed by me, resembles the other certainly; but we have no entry of the receiptâ€”the signature resembles mine, but that of Mr. Rod
rigues does notâ€”I cannot say that "Belperre" resembles his signature because I only know Rodriguesâ€”Mr. Levy came on 24th February and took away 40l. in cash and gave this chequeâ€”he said "Take that cheque and give me that 40l. in cash for my journey; "but this block note is falseâ€”I first suggested that it was not Mr. Rodrigues's writing because there are two brothers, and the other brother has signed itâ€”there are only the other witnesses, the employes, the clerks who were present, and Rodrigues, who have a memo
randum of account at the timeâ€”I must ask them to give me itâ€”I have not got itâ€”I say that this "C. Worth" is my writingâ€”I believe this 13l. was paid on my behalf by Mr. Levy, but I must look at my booksâ€”I must

see the ledger, and that is in Paris. (The authority was here read:â€”" Paris, 14th November, 1876. Mr. Levy,â€”I beg to inform you that I yesterday handed Mr. George Seamer and Co. of London an order on you for 13l., which please be good enough to exchange for this order. You will deduct this sum from the first remittance you may have to make to me. Blan
cherdet for Messrs. Worth.") I have said before that I must look at the large book to see whether I have received credit for that 13l., and that book is in Parisâ€”the cash order seems to me to be a receipt by his handâ€”I do not contest it at all, but I contest the receipt of the two sumsâ€”Mr. G. Seamer is a silk merchant in Londonâ€”I do not know whether I owed him any more than 13l., but it was to settle an account which I owed himâ€”he has never asked me for it since, but I cannot recollect it because we have had other transactions with him sinceâ€”I beg to remark also that the date has nothing at all corresponding to the order in November with the payment in Februaryâ€”this cash order was Novemberâ€”I saw Levy on 24th February when he came and brought the cheque, and asked me to give him the moneyâ€”I said no doubt before the Magistrate "In February, 1877, the defendant called on me in Paris at our office; I do not recollect seeing him again since. I saw him again in May, when he said he did not come on our business, but he had other business to transact; at the interview in February Levy handed me certain sums of money. I have a list of those sums; the figures in the list produced were written from the books by M. Blancherdet in my presence:" but seeing this cheque causes me to make an explanation which I hope the Court will allow me to makeâ€”it is true that I saw him in May; very likely it was a slip of memory when I said that I did notâ€”on 16th February he brought me the five sums which have been mentionedâ€”on the 24th he came again and asked me to take the cheque and give him 1,000 francs for his travelling expenses, consequently that cheque has nothing to do with our accountâ€”he may have left Paris between the 16th and 24th and came back againâ€”I did not see him between those datesâ€”this cheque reminds me of the transaction, it was in exchange for moneyâ€”there is no book here which will show that trans
actionâ€”Mr. Levy cannot prove the receipt of the 40l.â€”the large book would show the transaction of 16th February, but there is no book in existence which would show a transaction of this kind, which is only an exchange of moneyâ€”M. Blancherdet never received money in the ordinary course of things, but in my absence from Paris payments would be made to him; but he would immediately certify me of it, and hand me the money overâ€”all letters are filed and kept in the archive room.

Re-examined. In the small cash-book the entry of February 24, 1877, is Blancherdet's writingâ€”it might be done in my presence or notâ€”I was present when the cheque of 40l. was given to him, and I gave Levy the cash for itâ€”if these two amounts, Dorchester and Crocker, had been paid at that time they would immediately have been entered to the credit of those personsâ€”there is no such entry on the 24th Februaryâ€”this is Mr. Worth's letter-book (produced)â€”this letter of 6th June, 1877, is an im
pression from Blancherdet's writingâ€”I read all the letters (looking at it); this was written by my ordersâ€”all the letters are sent off every evening by a servantâ€”I cannot recollect whether I received this letter (another) but if I did it ought to be on the dossierâ€”it resembles Mr. Levy's signature. (The Solicitor-General stated that he admitted it to be Mr. Levy's writing, and it was put in and translated; it was dated 7th June, 1877, from E. Levy to Mr. Worth, stating that Mr. Crocker had written to ask him to accept his conditions, which he could not do, not being able to depend upon his word, and was therefore taking measures to have him declared bankrupt.) When I paid the cash for the 40l. cheque Blancherdet and another clerk were presentâ€”I did not receive a letter relating to Lord Dorchester's cheque about 19th December, 1876â€”I do not think Mrs. Carlton's name is written in the bad-debt ledger, but I must consult the big book for that purposeâ€”no sum corresponding with the two amounts of Carlton and Crocker is entered on the 24th in either of these two cash-booksâ€”any sum paid in respect of the bad-debt ledger would be entered specially.

EZRA LIVERMORE . I am manager of the Covent Garden branch of the London and County Bankâ€”on 12th October, 1876, an account was opened there by the defendent in the name of Fisher and Co., 28, Leicester Squareâ€”the drawing signature was given as J. C. Fisher and Co., and the name of the individual partner John Cambridge Fisherâ€”I should say that at that time I did not know that the defendant's name was Levy; I thought it was Fisherâ€”I know now that he is the man who opened the account; he signed J. C. Fisher, and it was operated upon by the same signature and no otherâ€”on 23rd November this cheque of Lord Dorchester's for 29l., endorsed C. J. Worth," was paid in to the credit of J. C. Fisher and Co. in a total of 54l. 17s. 8d.â€”I have the paying-in slip here.

FREDERICK THOMAS HALL . I am one of the firm of Denton, Hall, and Barker, 15, Gray's Inn Squareâ€”in December, 1877, I received a communi
cation from Mr. Worth in Paris, and addressed this letter on 17th December to Mr. Levy: "Sir,â€”Yourself v. Worth. Enclosed we send you a copy of a power of attorney which has been sent to Mr. Worth of Paris to our Mr. Hall to require you to give a full account respecting the debts which he placed in your hands to collect, and Mr. Hall will call upon you at 28, Leicester Square, on Wednesday next. &c. Signed, Denton, Hall, and Barker." That letter enclosed this list of the debts in question (produced) with blank columns oppositeâ€”it contains among other entries "393, Hon. Mrs. Carlton 29l.; amount remitted to Mr. Worth. 355, J. Crocker, 130l.; carried out 3,250 francs; amount remitted to Mr. Worth" I had some correspondence with Levy as to a personal interview, and on 3rd January I had an interview with him at 28, Leicester Squareâ€”I made a memorandum of what took place immediately afterwardsâ€”I showed Levy the original receipt from Mr. Worthâ€”the left-hand side consists of the debts, of which I had previously given him a list, and the right side the payments or credits, which Messrs. Worth gave him, and he produced a copy of another account which had been sent him with the questionsâ€”this is what I had to go byâ€”among other entries here is "Nov. 16: Ch. Seamen par M. Levy pour notre compt 13l. 325f."â€”I showed them all to himâ€”next day, January 4, I wrote him this letter, and enclosed a copy of this' side of the account. (This informed Mr. Levy that it was necessary to put in writing the exact position in which affairs stood, reminding him that Messrs. Andrews and Mason had been unable to obtain from him the particulars of his receipts and payments for Mr. Worth, who had therefore executed a power of attorney to Messrs. Hall, under which they demanded to know whether certain sums due to Mr. Worth had been collected or not, and the nature of all proceedings them pending.) I received the following

answer. (This was dated Jan. 7, 1878, from the defendant to Benton and Hall, stating that his refusal to account was by Mr. Worth's admission untrue, and that he was about to take proceedings in Paris against Mr. Worth for his breach of agreement, and that his agent would be instructed to deliver to Mr. Worth direct particulars of the account, and stating that Fisher and Co. had not to his knowledge received any moneys for Mr. Worth except such as he (Levy) had sent to him, or such as would be credited to him in the account then being made out.) In consequence of that I made a communi
cation to Lord Dorchester, and received from him the cheque which has been produced to-day.

Cross-examined by the SOLICITOR-GENERAL. I was at Bow Street when M. Mantel was in the witness boxâ€”I don't know whether I was there the whole timeâ€”I believe Mr. Edward Lewis, the attorney, was defending Mr. Levyâ€”I believe no promise was made that M. Mantel should come back again to be cross-examinedâ€”I believe, on the contrary, that an application was made that he should come back, and the Magistrate refused to grant itâ€”Mr. Wontner was conducting the prosecution, and I was there to assist himâ€”he has a letter from Mr. Levy to me of 2nd February, 1878. (This being produced stated: "In reply to yours of yesterday's date, you must be aware how absurd your demand for 512l. 2s. 6d. is in pursuance of the particulars delivered to me, inasmuch as I personally paid at Mr. Worth's part of the items which you set out. You may adopt any proceedings against me in bankruptcy that you may think lit, but I give you this notice for your Mr. Hall, that I hold him personally liable for any injury I may sustain by reason of these malicious proceedings, &c. E. L. Levy.") The 29l. is included in that list, but I should prefer seeing the letter to which that is a replyâ€”(Looking at it) yes I presume Mrs. Carleton's or Lord Dor
chester's name was included in itâ€”I received Lord Dorchester's cheque about 10th January, 1878â€”the letter is dated 9th January, from Coxail; the postmark is January 10â€”I had a long correspondence with Mr. Levy and received many letters from him in 1878â€”I thought the C. Worth on the cheque in question was not Mr. Worth's natural writingâ€”I thought it was his writing, but what I did think was that it was the same nameâ€”it looked like an imitation of a French signature; it has a tail which the French generally put to their signatures, but which Mr. Worth only puts to a limited extentâ€”I think it is Mr. Levy's writingâ€”in July, 1878, I pro
ceeded in one of the Courts at Westminster and annexed this cheque to an affidavitâ€”I know that in July or August Mr. Fisher diedâ€”I do not know when this charge was first preferred against Levy, but I presume it was shortly before Mr. Wontner communicated with meâ€”I first saw in the papers that Mr. Levy had been charged with some other offenceâ€”I have never been charged with forgeryâ€”I have heard of Madame Valentineâ€”you were my Counsel in that matterâ€”I should like to explainâ€”as solicitor I had in the course of the proceedings to put a document in in evidence; the solicitor on the other side, Montague Leverson, took the extraordinary course of giving me in charge and afterwards accusing me of tendering a document which was forged, not of forging itâ€”the merits of the case were tried before the Lord Chief Justice for a whole week, and it was decided that the docu
ment was genuineâ€”the prosecutor was first charged with the offence in October, I believe, and he was acquittedâ€”I believe Mr. Montague Leverson was articled clerk to the prisonerâ€”I was only tried on one indictment, but

there were threeâ€”it was in the Queen's Benchâ€”after a six days' trial the Jury were not out of the box 20 minutesâ€”it was the 13th June, 1867â€”I wrote the letter of 4th January for the purpose of putting upon record what had taken place, because I knew what kind of man I had to deal with; and for the same reason I took the note which I have here, because I knew he was connected with Leversonâ€”Leverson did not prosecute me; he had been the solicitor, but he absconded next day, and has never come back.

p.hi: The following Witnesses were called for the Defence.

div1.p:
LOUIS FONTENOY (Through an Interpreter). I am an embroiderer in gold, and live at 385, Rue de Pyreneesâ€”I remember going with Mr. Levy to Mr. Worth's in 1877â€”I met him on the Boulevardsâ€”I knew him beforeâ€”he told me that he was going to see Mr. Worth, and I asked him to intro
duce me, believing that he would want some embroidery doneâ€”it was at the end of February, but I cannot say the day we went to Mr. Worth'sâ€”I did not know the name of the gentleman who was there; all I can say is, that Mr. Levy had to do with a man who took snuffâ€”he was about my size, but he was sitting down, and therefore I did not remark him muchâ€”he was looking over some papers, and Mr. Levy took off something from what is called a block note, I think, and wrote something on it and gave it to the gentleman, and Mr. Levy took out his pocket-book and took out of it what I believe to be a cheque, which he filled up and handed it to the gentleman, and in exchange for it a large sheet of paper was given to him, on which the signature of Mr. Worth was requested by Mr. Levyâ€”I believe I heard it mentioned that the cheque was for 40l.â€”it was the same shade of colour as the one producedâ€”of course I don't know what Levy's business was; all I know is that they were laughing a great deal, and 1 heard it mentioned about a Lord, whose Lady ordered some goods and would not payâ€”when Mr. Levy asked for the signature they said that Mr. Worth was absent, but that Mr. Levy was to continue to act as he had previously done for the interests of the house, and the paper was not signedâ€”when we went out Mr. Levy said, "Since I have been in Paris, I have already paid over 10,000 francs"â€”one or two other persons were present in the room be
sides me and Mr. Levyâ€”this paper is the sort of thing on which Mr. Levy wroteâ€”it had been detatched from the little bookâ€”I did not see any money given to Mr. Levy by the gentleman there, in paper or cashâ€”I shook hands with Mr. Levy at the corner of the Rue Neuve des Petits Champs, and he said that he was going back that night.

Cross-examined by MR. GORST. I first stated the tale I have told to-day when Mr. Levy's son called on me in February last, begging me to come and speak for his fatherâ€”Mr. Worth was not at home, and therefore he could not introduce meâ€”I have never seen Mr. Worth in Paris, and never had any business transactions with himâ€”I first made Mr. Levy's acquaintance in October, 1876, at the Hotel Berger, Rue Bergor, Parisâ€”one of my relatives procured me some work, and Mr. Levy undertook the recovery of the moneyâ€”I handed him several invoices at the hotel which were due to me in London; one was from a lady called Burt, who lived at 40, Circus Row, but the acquaintance was through a relative of mine, M. Bayard, who is now in Parisâ€”I don't think he gave evidence at the polioe-courtâ€”I know that it was in February. 1877, that Levy and I went to Worth's because my brother-in-law wrote to me and told me to go and see Mr. Levy at this hotelâ€”I have not got my brother-in-law's letter, but I know it was in

February, because I know it was cold weather, and it was at the end of a monthâ€”he told me to meet Mr. Levy at the Hotel Bergerâ€”we went from the hotel along the Boulevards to Mr. Worth'sâ€”I have sot recognised any one to-day who saw us when we went thereâ€”I do not know M. Mantel.
Re-examined. That is not the gentleman who took snuff and sat down, he was a broad-chested gentleman, showing a great deal of white shirt.

LOUIS PHILIPPE MANTEL (Re-examined). I do not take snuff, only some
times when I want to sneeze.

ALFRED LAVIGERIE . I am a teacher of languages at several establish
mentsâ€”I have no establishment of my ownâ€”I have sent it over to a company for three or four monthsâ€”I was formerly in the prisoner's employ, not as a clerk, but for the purpose of writing letters in French and trans
lating themâ€”I left him at the beginning or middle of March, 1877; I am certain it was before the 20thâ€”here are two letters on this page of the press letter book which are in my writing; the one on the left is dated 18th December, 1876; I wrote it at the time it bears date and posted it to Mr. Worth at Parisâ€”this is the posting book produced, it was kept by myself; here is my writing here and the name of Messrs. Worth, and my initialsâ€”I have some recollection of some matters of 'mine which I had to do on that day, that is how I remember it; having read the letter I called to mind the circumstances under which it was writtenâ€”I called on that day at the office as usual, and I was instructed to write a letter; it was rather late and I was going away; I was called back when I was on the staircase, by the prisoner, who said "You must write another letter, and quick," and he gave me the substance of it, which I pencilled out, and wrote it at once and sent it offâ€”it was not part of my duty to copy it, but he said "Will you copy it? which way are you going?"â€”I said "To Camberwell"â€”he said "Will you post it at Charing Cross?" and I did soâ€”I copied it; I had some pressing business that evening at Camberwell, and not being used to the copying press, here are two or three words which, though it is my writing, I cannot read, because it is rather blotted, and that makes me remember I had to do it in a hurryâ€”I have no interest in Mr. Levy or connection with him, I never saw him more than once after I left, there is no friendship between usâ€”I am under a subpoena to prove this letter. (The letter was translated as follows: "18th December, 1876. To Monsieur Worth, 7, Rue de la Paix, Paris. I see that my son in writing to you to-day sending you cheque for Gagner has forgotten (notwithstanding I had told him to do so) to inform you that Lord Dorchester (Carleton) had sent a cheque for your account at the end of last month, and that I had endorsed it and passed it to your credit, having paid your draft upon us for Seaman. We will balance our account when I am in Paris, I think at the end of next month. I thought you had been advised of this receipt by my son, and I regret this in
voluntary omission the more so as his Lordship wrote that you were not to give further credit to his wife. Accept, &c, E. Levy." I had written another letter for him before that day.

Cross-examined by MR. GORST. The entry in the posting-book is "Messrs. Worth, 6.40, Charing Cross"â€”that is my writing in here, or my initials; I made that entry on leaving the officeâ€”I meant to say that I made that entry on 18th December, 1876, before I leftâ€”I stopped till the following mailâ€”I have said that I was called back again; a clerk was in the office when I left, and the prisoner was in his room; I cannot remember whether

Daniel Levy was thereâ€”I have posted a few letters, but it was not a part of my dutyâ€”I don't know M. Mantelâ€”I never had any private correspondence with himâ€”I do not know any other M. Mantel besides the one at Mr. Worth'sâ€”I cannot say whether I ever posted another letter to M. Mantel in that way at a late hour in the evening unless my initials are to the letterâ€”I posted a very few letters, and when I did I put my initialsâ€”I don't think I ever wrote one to him, if I did it was in French, but I did not write the whole of the lettersâ€”this entry of the letter on 11th December to M. Mantel "6.30, Charing Cross," is my writingâ€”this letter of 11th December to M. Mantel (looking at the letter-book) is my writingâ€”I had to write several letters to him in Frenchâ€”I am satisfied that I posted it, because my initial is thereâ€”I wrote two letters on 18th December; I wrote the first in the office; I have no room there; I used to sit in the office, or go into Mr. Levy's roomâ€”I had no place fixed; this letter was copied by me immediately after it was written, and it is soiledâ€”I do not know whose charge the letter-book was in, it was always left in the officeâ€”I wrote those two letters that day with ink from the same pot, I think with copying inkâ€”I am certain I was first spoken to at Bow Street nearly six months ago about giving evidence about the letter; I cannot say the day; the posting-book used to be on the shelf; the clerk in the office would be the party in charge of itâ€”I was told to make the entry of what time I should post it, and I did so, and put my initialsâ€”the case was commenced when I was asked to give evidence, because I remember reading of Mr. Levy being brought before the Magistrate, and a few days afterwards I was called upon, and asked to attend the Court, which I did.

Re-examined. I gave my evidence, and had my depositions taken, after being kept a long timeâ€”(Notice to produce the letter of 11th December having been given and not complied with, the Court permitted the Solicitor-General to give secondary evidence of it, and it was read to the witness in English)â€”that is a correct translation.

DANIEL LEVY . I am the prisoner's son, and a clerk in Messrs. Fisher's officeâ€”I remember M. Mantel being examined at Bow Streetâ€”Mr. Lewis, the solicitor, was not present that day, and M. Mantel was not cross-ex
aminedâ€”there was no one there to do it.

LOUIS PHILIPPE MANTEL . I have seen Louis Fontenoy to-day for the first timeâ€”I did not see him or anybody come to Mr. Worth's with Levyâ€”I have read the press copy of the letter of 11th December, and I do not recollect ever receiving it, and I am sure I never received the letter of 18th December.

Cross-examined by the SOLICITOR-GENERAL. I am quite sure I never received the letter of llth December; it would not be addressed to me, but to Mr. Worthâ€”he never wrote to me personally, except on one occasion, and that was when I wrote a very feeling letter to him saying that I was responsible for what happened, and hoped he would render an account faith-fully; he answered that to me personallyâ€”I did not look for a letter of 11th December, because it is useless to do soâ€”this letter of 28th October, 1876, was written by Blancherdet, and received by me; it says" Would it not be possible in cases of simply demanding payment from those ladies, you should write your letters on private paper without a heading of your house of business. It would not frighten so much. It would only be after

many ineffectual attempts that you should use your headed paper"â€”I not only wrote that, but I told him verballyâ€”I would not have authorised him to have paper with that headingâ€”I was to act as private agent, not as solicitorâ€”I say that he could not have written such a letter to me just because he acted as solicitorâ€”he did considerably wrong and that was the way we found it outâ€”he did not pay us the money he receivedâ€”he was written to, and told not to act as solicitor: he was only to sue people or take proceedings, with our consent (A letter from the defendant to Mr. Worth, dated 30th October, 1876, was also put in, alleging a conversation with Mr. Worth in Mr. Mantel's presence, in which he said that he would not charge for his expenses, and that he adhered scrupulously to his engagements.)

GUILTY .â€”
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.

563.
HENRY KELLY (25)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
Henry Yates. He was also charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with the like offence.
MR. RAVEN Prosecuted; MR. MONTAGU WILLIAMS Defended.
JAMES RICHARDSON CLARK . I am house surgeon at the London Hospitalâ€”I was there when the deceased Henry Yates was admittedâ€”I believe it was Saturday evening, 3rd Mayâ€”I attended him till he died.

PHILIP PRICKETT (Policeman M 259). I took the deceased to the hospital and was present when Mr. Bushby took his deposition at the hospitalâ€”the prisoner had the opportunity of cross-examining him. (The deposition of Henry Yates was here read:â€”" I met the prisoner in a public-house and he asked me to go to the theatre with him, and I said 'Very well, I will go to the Britannia with you. We went there and sat down for some time, and Fred Andrews went and fetched some beer and bread and meat, and we used prisoner's knife to eat the bread and meat with. I did not use the knife. Lee and Andrews, who were with us, went down, and the prisoner and I stopped up there, and after a time the prisoner Kelly and I went down into the bar and had some beer. We went up again, and on the stairs we met Andrews, and he bid us good nigh. I stood on some steps looking at the performance, and he (prisoner) stood below and kept on saying, 'Why don't you come down here?. I said, 'I am all right here; I 'll come down in a minute. In a little time I went down, and he said, "You are a pretty sort of fellow to stop up there I said, "You need not be so fast. I hardly know what passed, not two or three words, and he said, 'I shall stick a chiv into you,' and I said 'If you did I should hit you.' and I knew no more than that I get it in my leg, and I know no more than that I was carried downstairs. He stuck the knife into my leg twice. It is the knife that is now shown me. They took me to the police-station and then to the hospital here. I did not hit him before he hit me. I had had a drop, but I knew what I was doing till I was struck. He had been drinking a great deal in the afternoon. I gave him no reason that I know of for it.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. It is not true that when I get a drop of drink I say to him I 'll punch you.' and I have not done so. I may have been surly when he asked me to come down off the steps, but I did not hit him in the nose or in the neck. I did not give him the least provocation that I know of. I have often been told by him that he does not want my company. I did not strike him in the nose and neck. He was not using the knife to eat the bread and meat; that had all been eaten half an hour before.
ELIZA MANN . On the evening of 3rd May I was at the Britannia

Theatre with a man named Andrews, and saw the prisoner and Yates sitting on the next seatâ€”I saw the prisoner take this knife (produced) out of his pocket and open it; he swung his arm round and stuck it in Yates's legâ€”I should think it was below the kneeâ€”I had not heard any quarrellingâ€”I saw Yates stabbed two or three times, and he fellâ€”I saw no blows struck by either of them with their fists.

Cross-examined. None of them seemed particularly soberâ€”the prisoner was eating some bread and cheese with the knife half an hour before, and lending the knife to the othersâ€”they seemed good-tempered.
By the COURT. I saw him take the knife out of his pocket and open itâ€”they were not drunk, but they had been drinkingâ€”they were not at all noisy.

WILLIAM HART . I live at 40, Appleby Street, Shoreditchâ€”I was at the Britannia Theatre sitting next to the prisoner, on his right; but I had not gone there in his companyâ€”a girl was on his leftâ€”they had had enough drink, they came in about 10 minutes after meâ€”I heard two or three words which I cannot remember, and saw the prisoner draw the knife from his breast pocket, open it, and swing it round; it caught me on my arm and stabbed itâ€”he then stabbed Yates below the knee two or three timesâ€”I fainted and saw no moreâ€”I was taken to the hospital.

Cross-examined. My stab was accidental, he did not know that he had done itâ€”they did not seem to be quarrelling, their voices were not raised, they appeared to be jokingâ€”he drew his arm from his breast and caught me on my arm, or else it would have caught Yates in his side.

HENRY CLARE . I was at the Britannia Theatreâ€”when I first went in, the prisoner and Yates were on a seat in front of meâ€”they were strangers to meâ€”they went out of the theatre and came back, and sat four seats lower down to the left; there were three young men and one young womanâ€”Yates and Kelly rose up, and Yates seemed so eager towards Kelly that he opened nil shirt, and as he did so he gave Kelly a punch on his head with his left handâ€”when Yates opened his chest he went towards Kelly daring him to fight him as I thinkâ€”when Yates struck Kelly, Kelly pulled a knife out of his pocket and bobbed down and struck Yates two or three times on the legâ€”I heard no words, I only saw the attitude.
Cross-examined. I was behind them on the top seat at the top of the gallery, and they were four seats lowerâ€”I did not see Hart sitting next themâ€”there seemed to be no dispute between them.

JAMES RICHARDSON CLARK (Re-examined). Yates was suffering from a stab in his leg below the knee 2 1/2 to 3 inches deep, it had evidently passed between the bones into the calfâ€”there was a second wound just below his knee, and another on the upper surface, which came out on the under surfaceâ€”the knife apparently had run under the skin and had not gone through the flesh, there was very little bleeding and it was superficialâ€”there were also two wounds on each wrist, mere scratchesâ€”he was very weak from loss of blood and nervous depressionâ€”he went on very well till the next evening, Sunday, 4th May, when I was called to him at a little after 9 o'clockâ€”a severe hÃ¦morrhage had occurred in the wound in the calf of his legâ€”he was put under chloroform to find the artery, and the wound was pluggedâ€”erysipelas set in shortly afterwardsâ€”I then cutoff his leg and he diedâ€”the wounds might have been done with this knife (produced)â€”there are ap
parently stains of blood on it, and if so considerable force must have been used.

PHILIP PRICKET (Re-examined). I was in the gallery of the theatre on that evening and took the prisoner; he did not say anythingâ€”he was drunkâ€”this knife was picked up and given to meâ€”the deceased was lying on the floor of the charge room, and the prisoner said to him "You bâ€”â€”sâ€”â€”I meant this for you a long time ago, and I have done it now"â€”I charged him and took Yates to the hospital.

Cross-examined. When he said that he was drunk, but I think he knew what he was aboutâ€”the charge then was maliciously cutting and woundingâ€”I have been in the force some time, and I say that he was drunk.

GUILTY. Recommended to mercy by the Jury. â€”
Six Months' Im
prisonment.

564.
WILLIAM TUCKER (65)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
Henry Henley, with intent to murder him.

HENRY HENLEY . I live at 16, Fitzroy Place, Euston Roadâ€”the prisoner also lived there, and his daughter, and the landlady of the houseâ€”on Good Friday night I went home at 11.30 and opened the door with a latch key; as I went upstairs I knocked against somebody on the stairs, it was a young chap and the prisoner's daughterâ€”I said "Who is here?" there was no answer; I asked again and he said "All right, it's only me"â€”I knew his voice and said "You have no business here, you know you have a wife and little children," and I opened the door and let him out, and said "Good night"â€”I told the daughter that she ought to be ashamed of herself, and the landlady said that she would not have a bawdy house made of her placeâ€”the prisoner came out of his room and said that he did not encourage his daughter to make a bawdy house of his placeâ€”a good deal. of bad language was usedâ€”the conversation lasted about five minutesâ€”I went up into my room, and had undressed myself all but my trousers and boots, when he called the landlady bad namesâ€”I went down again and told him it was not his place to call her out of her name, because she had been a good landlady to himâ€”she is my mother-in-law, and when I took her part the daughter laid hold of us and the prisoner stuck a knife into my neck, my elbow, my left ear, my right hand, and my left sideâ€”he said nothingâ€”Scanlan came to my rescue and put me into his room and I was taken to the hospitalâ€”I did not strike or wound the prisoner at all.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not call your daughter all the whâ€”â€”s I could lay my tongue to, nor did you say "What do you mean by calling my daughter those names?" you never spoke to meâ€”I did not cut you. (The Prisoner showed a large scar on his arm.) I did not hear "Murder" and "Police" calledâ€”I know nothing about your being taken to the hospital and being there a fortnightâ€”you were brought there about an hour after meâ€”all I say is you were the cause of it all and you have ruined me for lifeâ€”I never touched you; I am paralysed in both hands and cannot hurt anybodyâ€”I only do a little workâ€”I do not know how you got hurt.

MICHAEL SCANLAN . I live at 16, Fitzroy Placeâ€”about 11.10 on Good Friday night I opened the door and let in a young man and the prisoner's daughterâ€”Henley came in soon afterwards and halloaed out "Who's there?" and I showed a light and showed the man outâ€”I heard several words between Miss Tucker and, Henley, and then went back to my room

and closed the doorâ€”a few minutes afterwards I heard a scuffle on the stairs, and on opening the door saw Henley bleeding from several placesâ€”I pulled him into the room and shut the doorâ€”he said that he should faint and his boots were full of bloodâ€”he only had on his boots, trousers, and shirt.

By the COURT. I heard the scuffle and saw the prisoner there, but I did not see whether he was cut till Henley was taken to the hospitalâ€”I did not see how he got cutâ€”he was taken to the hospital about an hour afterwards.

HENRY AYRES (Policeman E 451) I was called at 11.45, and assisted in taking Henley to the hospitalâ€”I went back to the house about 12 o'clock and found the prisoner lying down with a knife at his sideâ€”he was cut across the armâ€”I sent for the divisional surgeon, and the prisoner was taken to the hospital.

MILTON POLLARD . I am house surgeon at University College Hospitalâ€”Henley was brought there on Good Friday at 11.50 p.m.â€”his clothes were saturated with blood, and I found a wound across the left side of his throat three inches long; not deep enough to cut the main artery, but over it; a wound over the seventh rib which had struck it, and did not penetrate the chest; a wound two inches long above his left elbow, down to the muscles; a wound at the back of his neck about an inch long, of no importance; a cut on his hand, and a bit of a graze behind one earâ€”the wound on his throat was in a very dangerous place, but not deep enough to be dangerousâ€”the wound on his chest might have been dangerous if it had gone into his chest instead of striking a ribâ€”the prisoner was brought to the hospital about 12.45 the same nightâ€”he had lost a great deal of blood, and was very collapsedâ€”I found a wound on his wrist cutting through one of the musclesâ€”I took him into the ward and put some questions to himâ€”he said "I will tell you the truth; I had been drinking with a friend; I had gone to bed, when a man came to my room; I said to him "If you come in here I will cut your throat"â€”I said "Well, did you cut his throat?" he said "I do not know"â€”I said "How did you get this wound?" he said "I did it myself."

By the COURT. He had lost a great deal of bloodâ€”the wound had divided an artery, and he might have bled to death if it had not been looked toâ€”it was on the inner side of his left wrist; it will not injure him permanentlyâ€”I have examined Henley's hands; they are not absolutely paralysed, but he has very little power; it is what you call wrist drop.
The Prisoner. What he has stated I have no recollection aboutâ€”I wish my daughter called.

LOUISA TUCKER . On Good Friday I was out at work all dayâ€”I came home and Mrs. Henley was in my room drinking with my fatherâ€”I had said that I should be home at 8.30â€”I went to the public-house, and the young man came inâ€”Mrs. Henley was with me, and she drank with him alsoâ€”my father went home very drunk and went to bedâ€”Mrs. Henley left me, and the young man asked me to have another glass; he said "I am going your way home"â€”I knocked at the door just after 11, and Mr. Scanlan opened itâ€”I stood talking at the door with the man, and Mr. Henley came up and pushed by and called me disgusting namesâ€”I said that I was not a bâ€”â€”wâ€”; I worked hard for my living, and when I went up
stairs he repeated the same words, and my father rushed outâ€”I never held him; it is not likely that I should hold a man while my father stabbed himâ€”I saw no stabbingâ€”I do not know what my father had in his handâ€”his

head has been affected, and he has had fits since my sister's death; some
times he has three fits a dayâ€”I called for help, but nobody came.

Cross-examined. I did not see Henley covered with blood; I did not see him at allâ€”there was no light in my roomâ€”I only saw the policemanâ€”I was not on the landing when the policeman cameâ€”I have had no home for seven weeks.

GUILTY
of unlawfully wounding. â€”
One Year's Imprisonment.

565.
ANNIE READDON (24)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
John Morris Readdon, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.â€”MR. LILLY for the Prosecution offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

566.
WILLIAM BROCK (49)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
Clara Quaife.

LOUISA DUDLEY . I live in Payne Street, Barnsburyâ€”the deceased was my sister; her name was Clara Quaife; she lived with the prisoner for a number of yearsâ€”on Easter Tuesday she came to me between 1 and 2 o'clock, and asked me to go and have a cup of tea, but I did notâ€”she had no wound thenâ€”I saw her again at a little after 4, when she came from the hospital with her head dressed, and in the evening I saw her againâ€”she was very poorly from that time, and said that she felt very ill and complained of pains in her headâ€”I saw her on Saturday, 3rd May, on the bed very ill, and complaining of pains in her headâ€”she died on the Tuesday after.
Cross-examined. The prisoner had lived with her sixteen years, but she worked for herselfâ€”she went to the Kensal Green Cemetery on Easter Mondayâ€”I saw her every day in Easter week.

ELLEN EVANS .
