I am the wife of Alfred Evans, of 5, Albert Terraceâ€”on the Tuesday in Easter week the deceased came to me between 3 and 4 p.m. with a towel round her forehead, and a wound as long as my finger, it was bleeding; I put a cloth on it, and went with her to the Great Northern Hospital, where the wound was dressedâ€”I saw her once after that on the same day, but not afterwards.

HENRY NASH . I live at 32, Denmark Grove, Barnsburyâ€”the prisoner and the deceased lived in my house for about 4 1/2 yearsâ€”on Easter Tuesday afternoon Brock came home intoxicatedâ€”the deceased was out, but she came home afterwards; I heard something fall, and immediately afterwards she called out "Oh, you have cut my head open"â€”she came down imme
diately and showed me the cutâ€”Brock was upstairs at the top of the house and she at the bottomâ€”it was across her forehead about two inches long, and was bleeding very muchâ€”the fall was a loud crack; it sounded some
thing like a chairâ€”it was something coming in contact with the floorâ€”I had seen her the day before I thinkâ€”there was no cut on her forehead then.

Cross-examined. She went to the cemetery on the Mondayâ€”I believe he found the door locked when he came homeâ€”I don't know whether he laid down on the floor and went to sleepâ€”I am in the house every dayâ€”the deceased went out as usual I believe after 15th Aprilâ€”I saw her go out sometimesâ€”I was told that she had an apoplectic fitâ€”that was on the Saturday before she diedâ€”she was sober I believe when she came home.
CHARLES JAMES LEAR . I am potman at the King of Denmark, Clondesley Roadâ€”on Saturday, May 3rd, I saw the deceased going down Chapel Street

â€”she complained of her head, and when I came back I saw her at the King of Denmark sitting on a formâ€”I asked her where she livedâ€”she said she could not tell moâ€”I got assistance, and she was taken home, and I put her on a sofaâ€”I have known her a year and a half, and never saw her the worse for liquor.

Cross-examined. I saw her well at a little after 10 o'clock going down Chapel Streetâ€”she was taken ill at the top of Chapel Streetâ€”I saw her again in the public-house at 10.45; she was then apparently in a fit, and the governor was giving her a glass of cold waterâ€”she was unconsciousâ€”I carried her home and left her in the care of the people of the house, and told them to send for a doctor.
Re-examined. I do not know the names of the people of the houseâ€”I don't think they are here.
NOT GUILTY .

567.
FRANCIS PELLIER (30)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Mary Ann Atkinson, with intent to steal.
(The evidence was interpreted to the Prisoner.)

LUDIN HORTIN (Policeman Y 197). On the morning of May 12th, at about 12.30, I was on duty at West Hill, Highgate, and went to the back of Mrs. Atkinson's premises, where I saw the prisoner half way in through the back kitchen windowâ€”when I got into the area towards the prisoner he withdrew himself from the window and I seized himâ€”we struggled, and he got away and fell down some steps and broke his collar-boneâ€”I pursued him and again seized him, and he resistedâ€”I ultimately secured him and took him to the stationâ€”the front gate of Mrs. Atkinson's house I know was locked about 10.15 the previous nightâ€”I had some special directions with regard to this matterâ€”I subsequently examined the premises and found a large bar in the garden, and also this hammer (produced), which belongs to Mrs. Atkinson.

ELIZABETH GROSE . I was cook to Mrs. Atkinson on 12th Mayâ€”I was the last. person up in the house on the night of the 11thâ€”the house was closed and secured at 10.40â€”I closed the back kitchen window and fastened the shuttersâ€”the bars of the windows were in their places, fastened on the wooden frame of the windowâ€”in the morning I found one of the bars taken outâ€”this hammer, I think, was in the greenhouse the night beforeâ€”I know nothing of the American clothâ€”it does not belong to usâ€”I never saw the prisoner before I was taken to the station.
Cross-examined. The bars were fastened with screws; I think they were secureâ€”there is a housemaid in the house besides me.

The Prisoner's Defence. My intention was not to steal, but simply to go in the kitchen. I have seen that lady in the kitchen, and I wanted to go in and eat something. I left Paris only on the 6th April last. I started from Clapham on the morning of the day. I had great difficulty in getting something to eat, because I could not speak to make them understand. I was rather bad off. The little I had was something I had pawned. I certainly did go to the bar, because the bar was rather loose, and presented no difficulty in my pushing it aside.
LUDIN HORTIN (Re-examined). I found several matches in his pocket, 10s. in silver, and 3 1/2 d. in bronzeâ€”he could not speak any English.

GUILTY .â€”
Three Months' Imprisonment.

568.
WILLIAM JOHNSON (27) and
EDWARD JENNINGS (38)
, Unlawfully being found by night having housebreaking implements in their possession without lawful excuse.

MR. AUSTIN METOALFE
Prosecuted; MR. THORNE COLE Defended Johnson.

JAMES ARMSTRONG (Detective N). I was patrolling with Detective Fletcher on the morning of the 13th May, about 4.45, when I saw the two prisoners together in Dalston Riseâ€”I followed them, and saw Jennings go into the garden of a gentleman's house, and Johnson stood outside the gate until Jennings came outâ€”we followed into Stoke Newington Road, and Fletcher took Jenningsâ€”Johnson ran away very sharplyâ€”I ran after him, and called out "Stop thief" and "Police"â€”Police-constable Baker ran after him, and I returned to the station, and searched Jenningsâ€”in his trousers pocket I found this mortice chisel (produced)â€”it would be used to go under a window to prise up a sashâ€”I asked him to account for it, and he said "Find out; I am a carpenter"â€”I asked him where he worked, and he said "Find out"â€”I asked him where he lived, and he said "Find out; I shan't tell you nothing, I am not such a mug as that."
Cross-examined by Jennings. After three or four times you said you resided at a coffee-house in Gray's Innâ€”you did not tell who your master was.

JAMBS FLETCHER (Detective N). I was in company with Armstrong when we saw the prisoners watching the houses as they were going alongâ€”Jennings went into the front garden of a gentleman's house in Amhurst Roadâ€”Johnson stood outside watching, and he came out again, and joined Johnson, and they walked very sharply up into West Hackney, by the church, and looked round, and when they saw us they walked off very sharply down Stoke Newington Road, and there we pursued themâ€”I took Jennings, and Johnson ran awayâ€”I was present when Armstrong searched Jenningsâ€”when the chisel was found he said "Oh, that is nothing!"â€”we asked him to give an account of himself, and he said "Find out."

JOHN BAKER (Policeman N 42). I was in plain clothes about 5 a.m. on the morning in question when I heard cries of "Stop thief," and I saw Johnson runningâ€”I ran after him for about two miles, and caught him getting over the railway walls on to the railwayâ€”he said nothing.

WILLIAM CHAPMAN (Policeman N 42). I went to a Mr. Hogg's house in Lordship Road, Stoke Newington, and took this chisel with meâ€”I found a window had been forced openâ€”it had marks on it which I found by comparison exactly fitted the chisel.

Jennings's Defence. I met Johnson a little after five o'clock, and asked him the road. He said he was going the same way, and would show me. We turned the corner of Amhurst Road when two detectives charged us. I did not run at all, and they shouted out to a constable to stop the pair of us. It is an ordinary mortice chisel which I bought at an iron-monger's stall for 6d., and I took it and put a handle to it When I was taken in custody I said, "I am a carpenter, and have several others in my basket."

GUILTY . They also
PLEADED GUILTY to having been previously convicted, Johnson in 1873 and Jennings in 1872. Five other convictions were proved against Johnson. JOHNSON**â€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude. JENNINGS**.â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

569.
PATRICK LYNCH (33)
, Feloniously wounding
Catherine Lynch with intent to do her grievous bodily harm.

CATHERINE LYNCH . I am the prisoner's wifeâ€”I was married eleven yean ago last March, and have four children by him livingâ€”he left me eleven months ago, and I have been living with my mother at 2, Pipemakers' Alley, St. Martin'sâ€”he lives at Castle Lane, Westminsterâ€”about 10.30 or 10.45 p.m. on 25th April I went to him with three of my children, my eldest daughter being oneâ€”I found my husband in and the woman he is living withâ€”I asked him if he would give me a little money to go to market to support the childrenâ€”he said "I have some money, and if you will wait till the morning I will give you some"â€”.I slept in a chair in the room with the womanâ€”she never spoke to me or I to herâ€”I did not sleep, but I kept in the chairâ€”in the morning I asked the prisoner if he intended to give me anything, and he said I accused him of being a returned convict to a woman that lived in the same streetâ€”I said "I will go with you to the woman and prove I have not said such a thing"â€”we both went to the house together, and he knocked at the doorâ€”she was not in, and we both went back to his room, and I said to my little girl, "It is no good our waiting; we will go"â€”with that he gave me a blow in the face with his fist as I was sitting in the chairâ€”I said "Come on, never mind; let us go"â€”I rose, and he said "Perhaps you will have something to go with," and he made his way to me and kicked me on * * *â€”I said to my little girl, "I am bleeding, Polly; take me out or else I shall die"â€”I fell on to the floor, and she got me out, and I lay on the pavement bleeding till a cab came, which the prisoner fetched, and went with me to the hospitalâ€”he told me not to say it was him that done it, "for while you lie up I shall be as kind as I can to you"â€”the other woman was in the room asleep when it happenedâ€”I had not been drinking with her that night.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I was not drunk when I went to youâ€”I did not abuse youâ€”I have never lived with another manâ€”I have a baby by you a year and five months old.

MARY LYNCH . I am getting on for 10 years oldâ€”I went with my mother to my father's house, where I saw him and the woman he is living withâ€”my mother asked the prisoner for some money to go to market withâ€”he said he had not it in his hand, but had it upstairs, and he said "If you will wait till the morning I will give you some"â€”I had my sister and little brother with meâ€”my mother sat in a chair all nightâ€”in the morning my mother asked him to give her some moneyâ€”he said "Wait a minute," so mother said "Come on; he won't give us nothing"â€”he said" Perhaps I might give you something to go with"â€”he kicked my mother, and she fell off the chairâ€”she said "Oh, Polly, I am dying"â€”I lifted up her skirt, and she was bleedingâ€”the woman he was living with locked my mother in the roomâ€”I opened the door and pulled my mother out, and put her on the pavementâ€”she said "Oh, be quick, Polly, or I shall be dead," and then the cab-came which my father had fetched, and took them to the hospitalâ€”I had not heard ray mother call my father any names.
Cross-examined. My mother has not sold the things off me for drink, but for some grub.

WALTER ARTHUR . I was house surgeon at Westminster Hospitalâ€”I saw the woman on the morning of the 23rd, the morning after her admissionâ€”she had been previously treated by the assistant house surgeonâ€”she presented the appearance of a woman who had lost a considerable quantity of bloodâ€”she was rather blanched, and had a feeble pulse and the appearance of prostrationâ€”the hÃ¦morrhage had been arrestedâ€”I found a wound on the internal labia about an inch and a half long, a jagged sort of woundâ€”there was also some bruising externallyâ€”such injuries might be inflicted by a kick, or by falling on some blunt surface, not on the floor, such a thing as a pokerâ€”they were consistent with having been produced by a kick with a boot onâ€”we kept her in bed quiet, and she remained in the hospital until the 28thâ€”I have not seen her sinceâ€”I then prescribed a tonic medicine for herâ€”whether she has since attended as an out-patient, and seen any of the other surgeons, I cannot sayâ€”a wound of that sort might by attended with serious consequences.

WILLIAM SMITH . I am a cab-driverâ€”the prisoner fetched my cab and I took the woman to the hospitalâ€”she was lying on the pavementâ€”I helped to put her into the cabâ€”there was a great deal of blood on the pavementâ€”all I could hear her say was "My God, make haste and take me there; I shall bleed to death."

CHARLES MILES (Policeman B 273). I was called to Castle Lane about 10.30 a.m.â€”I found no one in the streetâ€”I saw blood on the pavementâ€”I had looked in the room on the ground floor, where I found traces of bloodâ€”I saw the doctor at the hospital and then the prisonerâ€”I told another con
stable to take care of himâ€”he' said "It was not me that did it, it was another man"â€”the woman's clothes wereâ€”saturated with blood.

Prisoner's Defence. I did not mean to do what I did do. I am very sorry. She aggravated me and spit in my face two or three times, and she was going to take a basin up to strike me with and I made a kick at her to get out of the way of the basin.
CATHERINE LYNCH (Re-examined). I did not spit in his face nor attempt to strike him with a basin.

MARIA ROBINSON . I am single and live with the prisonerâ€”his wife and children came to see him on the evening of 21st April and stayed all nightâ€”in the morning me and the prosecutrix went out drinking together at 5 o'clock at the King's Headâ€”we stopped there a long time and then we took some beer home to drinkâ€”after that me and the prisoner and the prosecutrix went out drinking againâ€”then we went home and I went to sleepâ€”I awoke at 4 p.m. and missed them from the room and I looked in the public-house to see if they were thereâ€”I was in several public-houses in the morning with themâ€”at the Stag public-house we had rum and beerâ€”she blackguarded him and spit in his face three or four timesâ€”I did not say that before because I thought I should be askedâ€”I have lived with him for five and a half years.
CHARLES MILES (Re-examined). The last witness was not in the room when I went inâ€”I looked under the bed.
CHARLOTTE BYRON . I am the wife of a horsekeeper and live in the same house as the prisonerâ€”I do not know his wife beyond seeing her come there on

the night in question with her little girlâ€”I did not see the other childrenâ€”I did not see the parties in their roomâ€”I know the person who stopped there all night made use of very bad language to her husbandâ€”I did not interfereâ€”she called him a wâ€”â€”'s son; a wâ€”â€”'s dropper, and a wâ€”â€”'s meltâ€”I could not sleepâ€”it was something dreadful.

SARAH PLAISAN . I live in the prisoner's house with my husband and sisterâ€”I have understood Maria Robinson to be the prisoner's wifeâ€”I only know Catherine Lynch by seeing her come to the house night and morningâ€”I was at the street door when she came in with the prisoner and the other womanâ€”I also saw her come with her little girlâ€”her language was dreadful and she insulted me too at the doorâ€”I was glad enough to go into my room and get out of itâ€”I have heard bad language beforeâ€”I did not see anything that happened in the room.
The Prisoner. I am very sorry for what I have done, and I beg for mercy for the sake of my little children.

GUILTY .*â€”
Two Years' Imprisonment.

570.
GEORGE HENRY PETTY (26) and
WILLIAM WINK (46)
, Stealing four dead fish, the goods of
Felix Spiers and others.

MR. STUART WHITE
Prosecuted; MR. GILL appeared for petty and MR. D. METCALFE for Wink.

WILLIAM SAUNDERS (City Policeman 672). On 3rd May I saw the prisoners in conversation in Lower Thames Street, by the dry archâ€”I was in plain clothes on the footway, and I saw them enter the Steam Packet public-houseâ€”I saw this basket standing on the footway, and the smaller one by the side (produced)â€”I went up to the larger basket and looked in and saw some whiting in itâ€”I then went to the top of the bridge and watched, them for a few minutesâ€”I then saw Petty was in charge of one of Spiers and Pond's covered vans, and Wink then went up and touched the handle of the basket to pull it up close, as it was open a little distanceâ€”he then went towards Billingsgate Market, leaving the basket behindâ€”he was absent about 30 minutes; he had nothing with him, and returned with nothingâ€”he stood on the pathway looking up and down the streetâ€”Petty then got out of the van, holding something wrapped in paper under his apron by both hands, and stood over the basket and dropped the parcel inâ€”Wink was about four yards from the basketâ€”I told another officer to follow me down the stepsâ€”I lost sight of the prisoners for about a minute, and when I went to the steps Wink was standing over the basket apparently taking something from the paper and placing it down at the bottom of the basketâ€”Petty was standing close byâ€”I went up and told them I was a police officer, and wished to know what was in the paper he had put in the basketâ€”they made no replyâ€”I looked in the basket and found it contained four pairs of soles and five pairs under the paperâ€”I told Petty I should take him in custody for stealing the solesâ€”he replied "All right, Sir"â€”I told. Wink I should take him in custody for receiving the soles well knowing them to be stolen.

Cross-examined by MR. GILL. I have since heard that Petty was for five years in the employ of Messrs. Spiers and Pondâ€”I heard it stated at the police-court by a person in their employâ€”I am not aware that Spiers and Pond have anything to do with this prosecutionâ€”the manager stated that they would leave it in the hands of the Courtâ€”they have not instructed

their solicitors in itâ€”when I looked into the basket I was standing where any one could see meâ€”I had no occasion to open itâ€”I looked in at the endâ€”I went on the bridge and remained there 35 or 40 minutesâ€”Petty then went into the public-house with some of the portersâ€”I could not see Petty when he was in the covered vanâ€”the basket was about four yards from the vanâ€”I was watching to see if anything was placed in the basketâ€”the side of the van was towards where I was standingâ€”the horse was standing with his head towards the South-Eastern Railwayâ€”Petty took in the fish at the front of the vanâ€”I lost sight of Wink for about a minuteâ€”the other constable was six or seven yards behind meâ€”they were very fine soles, worth about 2s. a pairâ€”I left the van in charge of an officerâ€”I did not see the soles in the vanâ€”I don't know that the soles bought that day were slipsâ€”I saw some soles in the shop, but I do not know whether they were purchased that dayâ€”I was told that only two pairs of soles were missed from the vanâ€”I was not told that they were small solesâ€”I charged them at the station with stealing nine pairs of solesâ€”I did not see the buyersâ€”the charge was made at the station before I saw Mr. Stovellâ€”I saw a gentleman in Spiers and Pond's employ at the fish establishmentâ€”the bridge from which I was watching was about 20 yards from the van.

Cross-examined by MR. D. METCALFE. I don't know whether Wink could see me look into the bagâ€”I think he mightâ€”I have made inquiries about Winkâ€”he gave me a correct address, 11, Marshall Street. Golden Squareâ€”I have heard that he supplies restaurants with fish.
Re-examined. I find Wink hawks fish in a basketâ€”I don't know that he has ever done anything else.

JAMES THOMAS LOWE (City Policeman 839). From what Saunders said to me I followed the prisoners down the steps in Lower Thames Streetâ€”Wink was standing over a basket and Petty at his sideâ€”I looked in the basket, and saw soles in a paper and some underneathâ€”when they were charged Petty said "All right"â€”Wink made no reply.

Cross-examined by MR. GILL. I was about six yards behind Saundersâ€”I have not gone over my depositions this morning with Saunders, nor have I spoken to him about this caseâ€”it is about six yards from the bottom of the steps to the dry archâ€”Saunders had got up to them before I got to the bottom of the stepsâ€”I could just see into the basket when I got up.

JAMES STOVELL . I live at 49, Packington Street, Islington, and was at this time manager at Messrs. Spiers and Pond's fish depotâ€”I went to market in the morning and bought 120 pairs of soles at one marketâ€”I missed two pairsâ€”I bought another lotâ€”Petty was in charge of the vanâ€”I counted the second lot, about five dozen, and they were all right.

Cross-examined by MR. GILL. Both lots went into the vanâ€”the 120 pairs were what we call middle sized, not large solesâ€”they cost 10d. a pairâ€”the people in the market counted them in the van about an hour after the prisoners were takenâ€”the Van was still standing in the streetâ€”there are often mistakes to the extent of two or three or four soles in the counting in in the marketâ€”I said at the police-court that on counting the soles I was three shortâ€”I gave evidence on the remandâ€”I said that Petty had been with us four years, and his conduct during that time had been very goodâ€”Messrs. Spiers and Pond were not represented at the police-court.
Re-examined. I took the van homeâ€”it was in charge of a constableâ€”when mistakes have occurred in counting they have generally been rectified
â€”I was not present when the prisoners first appeared before the Magistrateâ€”I don't know who this prosecution is instituted by.

By the JURY. The 120 pairs of soles which I say fetched 10d. a pair would not be of the same value as those the policeman describes as being worth 2s.â€”that would be about the value of the five dozen lot, which were much largerâ€”I missed the two pairs from the 120 pairs.
NOT GUILTY .

571.
GEORGE WOODBURNE (45)
, Unlawfully attempting to steal the goods of
Frederick William Tabois.

JOHN GIBNEY (Policeman Y 520). On 12th May, about 12 at night, I was on duty at Swain's Lane, Highgate, and saw the prisoner standing in the prosecutor's garden close by the front window, and when he saw me he ran out into the roadâ€”I overtook him and said, "What were you doing there!"â€”he said "I was doing nothing"â€”I took him to the station, and then went back and called up Mr. Tabois and examined the place with himâ€”I found the putty had been cut away from the bottom of the lower panes of the window at which the prisoner had been standingâ€”there are two panes in each part of the window, and large enough for a man to get throughâ€”the glass was ordinary window glassâ€”I then returned to the station and searched the prisoner, and found upon him this, farrier's knife (produced)â€”he de
scribed himself as a shoeing smith.

FREDERICK WILLIAM TABOIS . I am superintendent of the Highgate Cemetery, and live in a detached house in Swain's Lane adjoining the cemeteryâ€”between 12 and 1 a.m. on the 13th I was aroused by Gibney, and by the light of his lamp I saw that the putty had been cut away from the bottom of the lower pane at the right-hand side of the windowâ€”it appeared to have been recently done; the broken putty was on the window sillâ€”it is a large pane, and a man could get through into the room if the glass had been removedâ€”there are not many houses nearâ€”the house is on the top of a slope, and the garden is on the right and left of the steps leading up to the front door and to this windowâ€”it is very easy of access.

p.hi: The Prisoner in his defence read a statement that he was a hard-working man with a wife and seven children, and had met with two serious accidents, the second being that of a broken jaw by a kick from a horse he was shoeing in December last; that by the doctor's advice he had been in the country, and, was walking from Finchley, where he had been working, and he met the policeman, who asked where he was going, and on being told he was going to the Kent Road he said, "I know you won't; you will go with me," and arrested him.

div1.p: FREDERICK WILLIAM TABOIS (Re-examined). There is a small slope from the roadway up to the gate, and eight steps up to the plateau on a level with the window, and no outer palings.
By the JURY. There is a gateway, and there would be no other way out except over the hedgeâ€”it is eight yards between the garden and the window.
JOHN GIBNEY (Re-examined). He ran down the steps, and I stopped him by the gate.
NOT GUILTY .

572.
MICHAEL BURKE (17) and
FRANCIS ROBARTY (14)
, Robbery with violence from
Fritz Hundheim, and stealing from him a cork-screw and bunch of keys and 3s. 8 1/2 d.
MR. GROGHEGAN Prosecuted; MR. PURCELL Defended.

FRITZ HUNDHEIM . I am a waiter and live at 2, Porter Street, near Leicester Squareâ€”I was walking through Porter Street on 9th May, about 11.40 p.m., and saw five men standing by a public-house on the opposite side of the streetâ€”I had my keys in my hand and three shillings, a sixpence, and twopence halfpenny in bronze, and a corkscrew in my trousers pocketâ€”the prisoner Robarty came to my right side and said "Old man, are you going home?"â€”I said "Leave me alone; do not speak to me"â€”I had seen him before many timesâ€”Burke came on my left and struck me on the nose, knocking me downâ€”the blood cameâ€”I got up and caught hold of him and called "Police!"â€”it was all done in a momentâ€”three other men came up and they struck me behind and before, and the prisoners took from me my corkscrew and keys and 3s. 8 1/2 d.â€”I held them both, but had to let them goâ€”the other men said "We will kill you if you don't let them go"â€”I told a man to fetch a policeman and I gave the prisoners in custody in a fried-fish shop, distant about six minutes' walkâ€”I had had something to drink, but knew what I was aboutâ€”I had often seen the prisoners about before, nearly every day, and they are the men who attacked me.

Cross-examined. I was coming from the Crown Hotelâ€”I was quite soberâ€”I had been drinkingâ€”I drink ale or stout every dayâ€”I do not remember at the police-court saying "A few nights before I had charged a man with stealing from me"â€”he was not taken in custodyâ€”I do not remember charging a man before with robbing me and the policeman refusing to take him because I was drunkâ€”the live men were near the public-houseâ€”the public-house was openâ€”the prisoners were taken half an hour after the assault sitting in a fried-fish shop eating fish, about five minutes' walk from where the assault took placeâ€”there are four compartments in the shopâ€”I looked into the compartment where the prisoners and other men were sitting and then passed on to another compartment to look for the other three men, and then returned and said "These two are the men"â€”I do not know Mary Ann Crowderâ€”my money was all in one pocketâ€”the prisoners took hold of me one on each side and put their hands in my pocketsâ€”I said at the police-court "Burke came from the right and caught hold of me, and Robarty from the left"â€”I might have made a mistakeâ€”I am not quite lure which was on the left and which was on the right.

Re-examined. I leave business very lateâ€”there is a little court off Porter Streetâ€”they would have to pass by that court where the corkscrew was found to get to the fried-fish shopâ€”I can swear to the corkscrew, it has the name "Pickel" upon it (produced)â€”that is itâ€”the fried-fish shop is in a public thoroughfare leading to Seven Dials.
By the COURT. I was hurt all overâ€”my employer told me to go to a doctor, but I did not like to goâ€”I feel the pain still.

WILLIAM MORTIMER (Policeman C 94). On 9th May, at 11.55, the prosecutor came to me in King Street, Sohoâ€”he was drunk, but knew what he was aboutâ€”his nose was bleeding and his mouth cutâ€”in consequence of what he said I went with him to a fried-fish shop in Grafton Streetâ€”there were about ten people there and the shop has three or four compartmentsâ€”he walked into the first comparmen' an I looked in, and then Went to the outside

of the next compartment and looked in thereâ€”he then turned back and said "These are the two"â€”they were sitting in the first compartmentâ€”he said "I charge them with stealing 3s. 6d. and assaulting me"â€”the prisoners both said they knew nothing about itâ€”another constable was fetched and they were taken to the station and searchedâ€”on Robarty was found threepence and a penknife, and on Burke four shillings and a pennyâ€”I do not know the court where the corkscrew was found.

Cross-examined. The fried-fish shop is about three minutes' walk, (150 or 200 yards), from where the robbery took placeâ€”there is a good deal of trafficâ€”I know nothing of Robartyâ€”I have made inquiriesâ€”I do not know Mr. Woolley, card maker, High Holborn; or Mr. Hatchett, wholesale stationer, Strandâ€”he said he had been working in the Strand, but would not tell me whereâ€”I know Burke as an associate of thieves, but I do not think he has been convicted before.
Re-examined. I know the public-house, and the nearest way from there to the fried-fish shop would be to go by Newport Court or Prince's Court.

WILLIAM SPOONER (Policeman C 86). On Saturday morning, 10th May, I found this corkscrew (produced) at the end of Prince's Court in the gutterâ€”you would have to go to Newport Court and Prince's Court to get into Grafton Street to the fried-fish shopâ€”I do not know if it is the nearest way.

MARY ANN CROWDER . I work at home with my mother since I left my placeâ€”my father is a lithographic music printerâ€”I saw the prosecutor in Porter Street on Friday or Saturday night, about 11.30 or 11.50â€”I was coming from the public-house where he worksâ€”my father and mother use the house, and I went there to look for themâ€”I saw five young chaps round him; I know them by sight, and can swear to them all; I also know the prisoners by living about the neighbourhoodâ€”the five lads laid hold of the prosecutor, and knocked him down on the kerbâ€”the two prisoners were not there, nor either of themâ€”I can swear they were not in the street when the robbery was doneâ€”I was not at the police-court; my mother would not let me go.

Cross-examined. The prosecutor works at the Cranbournâ€”I was then that night, but did not see him thereâ€”I saw him in Porter Streetâ€”it was about 11.30 or 11.50 when I was returning from the Cranbournâ€”I know the prisoners by living about the neighbourhood, but have never seen them together beforeâ€”the other five lads come up and dawn Prince's Court, bat do not live in the neighbourhoodâ€”Burke lives at 23, Prince's Roadâ€”I do not know where Robarty livesâ€”Prince's Road is the next turn from Porter Streetâ€”I do not know the names of the other five lads, but know them by sightâ€”they came all together upon the prosecutor, and not two first and three afterwardsâ€”I did not see any one put his hand into the prosecutor's pocketâ€”I saw his nose bleedingâ€”I could swear to the five men and have given the police a descriptionâ€”one was tall and dark with a pepper and salt suit; another had corduroy trousers and a frock coat; another had a light suit; another a black suit, and another had a pair of light fustians.
Re-examined. I was on the opposite side of the street when the assault took place.
NOT GUILTY .

573.
MICHAEL BURKE was again indicted
for stealing a purse and 7s. 1 1/2 d. from the person of
Minnie Deeks.
MR. RAVEN Prosecuted; MR. STEW WHITE Defended.

ELIZABETH, DEEKS . I am the wife of William Deeks, 12, North Street, Manchester, Squareâ€”on 25th March, between 3 and 4p.m., I was walking in the, Seven Dials, and had my daughter with me 15 years of ageâ€”I went into a bird-seed shop, leaving my purse with my daughter, who was just handing it back to me as I came out, when two men came between us, and snatched it out of my hand, and ran away together into a court in Porter Streetâ€”I followed them, but a crowd got between us, and I left themâ€”before they took the purse they had followed us for some distance, and I saw the prisoner so as to recognise him, and pick him out amongst several others at the police-stationâ€”I saw nothing more of himâ€”from the description I gave of him I was taken to identify him at the police-stationâ€”I have no doubt he is one of the men who took my purse and 7s. 1 1/2 d. and a box-keyâ€”I knew him again directly I saw himâ€”the key has not been recoveredâ€”he had been following us; I noticed them before I went into the shop.

Cross-examined. The purse was between us, and I had just got hold of it as it was snatched from my handâ€”my daughter had my purse, and was waiting for me, and looking into the window, and I had just come out of the shopâ€”I did not look in at the windowâ€”there were several people pass-ingâ€”I do not know much about the Dialsâ€”I can swear the prisoner is one of the two youths who took my purseâ€”I followed them into a court in porter Street, and they went into some bouse and banged the door, and a lot of people were there and said, "You can't find them"â€”I identified the prisoner about a fortnight ago at Marlborough Streetâ€”he was with about 15 or 20 others in a long rowâ€”there were several like the prisonerâ€”they looked about bis age and size.
Re-examined. I had noticed the prisoner and somebody else loitering behind us, and had noticed them sufficiently to identify the prisoner.

WILLIAM BISHOP (Detective). On March 25th complaint was made to me of a robbery, and I afterwards fetched the prosecutrix to the station and placed the prisoner among a number of other lads from the streetâ€”he was dressed at now.
Cross-examined. I have beard the last witness's evidenceâ€”I did not count the lads; there were 12 or 13â€”some of them were dressed very nearly like the prisoner.

GUILTY .(â€ )â€”
Fifteen Month' Imprisonment.

574.
GEORGE GARROD (25)
, Feloniously marrying
Henrietta Seymour, his wife being then alive.

JAMES BUXTON (Police Sergeant). I took the prisoner coming out of Coldbath Fields Prison on April 26th, where he had been undergoing a sentence of three months' imprisonmentâ€”I charged him with marrying Henrietta Seymour, while his wife Margaret was aliveâ€”he said, "I heard she was dead"â€”I had seen her a night or two previouslyâ€”I never saw Henrietta Seymour until at the police-courtâ€”I knew the prisoner's wifeâ€”whilst he was in prison undergoing seven years' penal servitude she lived with another manâ€”the prisoner was liberated in 1877.

CATHERINE MELANEY . I am a single woman, at 89, Beaufort Street, Fulham Road, and was present at the prisoner's marriage with his first wife at Christ Church, Marylebone, and signed the register as a witnessâ€”the prisoner is the man.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I said at the police-court I had great doubts as to whether you were the manâ€”I had doubt about you at firstâ€”you lived at Old Park, Paddington, when first marriedâ€”I have seen you four or five times sinceâ€”the last time was at my niece's, about six months ago, it might be moreâ€”I did not know you thenâ€”I might have said in my de positions that I had not seen you for five or six years, but I have forgottenâ€”I have seen your first wife a fortnight agoâ€”I wrote your letters, and wrote letters to her fur youâ€”I do not recollect when I wrote last, and did not know that a letter was written to the Governor of the Prison, in which she declined to have anything more to do with me, or that a letter was written to the chaplain saying that she was deadâ€”I did not see her for a long time until this case was pending, and did not know how she was livingâ€”she is living with another man.

JAMES BUXTON (Re-examined). I produce a certificate of marriageâ€”I examined it with the original at the church on 1st March. (This certified a marriage at Christ Church, St. Marylebone, March 11th, 1871, of George Garrod, bachelor and carpenter Shirley Place, to Margaret Farren, of full age, spinster.)

HENRIETTA SEYMOUR . I live at 24, Pond Place, Chelseaâ€”I was married to the prisoner on August 12th, 1877, at Christ Church, Chelsea, after a courtship of about five monthsâ€”he represented himself as a carpenter, and to be a single man, and I believed him to be so up till a fortnight before he was given into custodyâ€”I never heard of his former wife or received any letter from herâ€”I received information about six weeks ago that his wife was then aliveâ€”he has been a good husband to me, and a good father to my child, very kind and hardworking, and it is. not my wish that this prosecution should be madeâ€”I never heard him speak of his former wife, and had no idea he was marriedâ€”this is the certificate of my marriage, and this is my signature and the prisoner's. (This described George William Garrod as a bachelor.) I received a letter from some person with no signature.

p.hi: The Prisoner in his Defence read a statement, acknowledging both marriages, but stating that during his imprisonment a letter signed Am Sullivan had been sent to the prison, stating that his wife was dead, and that he married again, believing his wife to be dead.

div1.p:
GUILTY. Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury. â€”
Six Month' Imprisonment.

575.
ALEXANDER AMBLER (14) and
EDWIN MADDEN
PLEADED GUILTY
to setting fire to certain heath grass and furze on Stanmore Common.â€”
To enter into recognizances to come up for judgment when called upon.

576.
SAMUEL BLACKWELL (39)
PLEADED GUILTY to stealing a post letter and 60 penny stamps while employed under the Post Office.â€”
Judg
ment Respited.

577.
JOHN THOMAS (38)
PLEADED GUILTY to stealing a brooch and I thermometer from
John Aycock, an opera glass and cameo of
Clara Archer and
to stealing three rings, value 23l., and a table cover value 1l., the property of
Arabella White, in her dwelling house, having been previously convicted of felony.â€”
Two Years' Imprisonment. And

578.
WILLIAM HINGLEY (23)
also to burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Honey, and stealing therein a book and concertina; also
to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Jane Jones, and stealing therein five bedgowns and other articles; and
to stealing a hamper and 48 jackets, a coat, and five skirts, the goods of the
South-Eastern Railway Company.â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

579.
BENJAMIN MARTIN (36) and
FREDERICK COVILL (36)
, Breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Robert David Peebles, and stealing therein four pairs of boots.

GEORGE TAYLOR . I live at 14, George Road, East Greenwich, and am gardener to Mr. Peebles, at Crath Nithen Lodge, St. John's Road, Blackâ€”heathâ€”I was left in charge of the house in his absence during May, and went away at about 6.50 a.m. on the 7th, leaving the house secureâ€”I returned about 8 or a little before, and found an entrance had been forced by the area door, and that three pairs of boots had been stolen from behind the door of a spare bedroomâ€”I had seen them safe beforeâ€”I did not miss anything else.

REUBEN TOMPSETT . I am coachman to Mr. Peeblesâ€”I recognise the boots producedâ€”I know them by their general appearance, being used to them, having cleaned them for the last 15 monthsâ€”I produce a similar pair, which have not been usedâ€”we also missed some American, Austrian, and French coins.

GEORGE BARR . I am assistant to Mr. Mumford, Nelson Street, Green
wich, pawnbrokerâ€”Martin came at about 9 a. m. on the 7th May and pledged this pair of spring-side boots for 5a. in the name, I think, of William Brown, and they were taken out on the 8th by Covill, who said "Are the boots worth the money that was lent on them?"â€”he did not mention the amount; he had got the ticketâ€”I said "I think they are," and he redeemed them, but brought them back next morning and repledged themâ€”I know both the prisoners as customers of ours.
Cross-examined by Martin. You have frequently bought clothes from us and sold things to usâ€”I know you deal in secondhand clothes.
By the COURT. He takes a barrow round, and will buy anything.

Cross-examined by Covill. You said "I have bought a ticket; are the boots worth the money, 5s.?"â€”I said they were, and then you said "What is the interest?"â€”I said "1 1/2 d."â€”you said "Will you lend me the same on them?" and you came back on the 9th and repledged themâ€”you might have said they were too big for you, but I do not recollectâ€”you then asked me what the ticket was worth, and I said 2s. or 2s. 6d., and you said "Then I am not much out, because I gave la. for the ticket."
By the COURT. He said that after he had pledged theâ€”he gave me 5s. for them when he took them out the first time.

HENRY PHILLIPS (Inspector R). I visited the house of Mr. Peebles on the 8th May, and found that an entry had been made by pushing open the kitchen door, breaking off the lock (produced); no jimmy was usedâ€”from information received I sent an officer to the pawnbroker's, and discovered that the boots had been pledged, and the names and descriptions of the persons were given to me on the 9th May about 10 a.m.â€”I saw the prisoners on the 9th seated on a costermonger's barrow on Maze Hill, Greenwich Parkâ€”I said to them, "I want you with reference to some boots that have been pledged at Mumford's at Greenwich; I believe them to be the proceeds of a case of housebreaking"â€”Covill said "All right, I can soon answer that; I bought a ticket of a pair of boots of a man; I took them out; they did not lit me, and I repledged them," at the same time handing me this ticketâ€”I took them to the station, and read the charge to them after the boots had been identified by the servant, and they made no replyâ€”Martin gars no explanation before his statement at the police-court.

Cross-examined by Covill. You said immediately, you had pawned a pair, and gave me the ticket after you were separated at the police-stationâ€”I know you are a muffin and crumpet makerâ€”I said "You had better tell me who you bought the ticket from"â€”you said "A man," and on my repeating the question you said "I bought them of Martin"â€”the prisoners get their living by buying and selling bottles, rags, and refuse.

HENRI GOODWIN (Police Sergeant R). I was with the last witness when the prisoners were apprehended, and I took Martin to the stationâ€”he did not speak until I was putting him in the cell, when he said "I can prove where I got those boots; I bought them."
Cross-examined by Martin. You did not tell me you bought them in Petticoat Lane.

The Prisoners' Statements before the Magistrate. Martin says: "I know nothing of the robbery; I bought the boots." Covill says: "I bought the ticket of this man Martin and gave him a shilling for it."

MARTINâ€”
GUILTY .*â€”
Nine Months' Imprisonment.

COVILLâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

580.
JOHN COUSINS (42)
, Feloniously abusing
Louisa Smith, aged 2 years and 10 months.â€”MR. TICKELL Prosecuted.â€”
GUILTY of the attempt .â€”
Two Years' Imprisonment.

581.
FRANCIS GEORGE LOTT
(21), Stealing a jacket, a pair of trousers, and a waistcoat of
Henry May.

HENRY MAY . I am a pawnbroker of 162, Deptford Lower Roadâ€”on 1st May, about 8.55, I missed a boy's suit of jacket, waistcoat, and trousers from outside the shopâ€”I had seen them safe about 8.45â€”I have informa
tion to the policeâ€”my errand boy brought the jacket into the shop.

ISAAC WILLIAM DRISCOLL . I am assistant to Mr. Mayâ€”on the evening of 1st May, about 8.45, I was carrying some goods from outside the shop to the inside, and I saw the prisoner running from the shop, about 20 yards offâ€”I ran after him and saw him chuck a jacket over into a gardenâ€”I am quite sure he is the man, I had seen him pass the shop two or three times
â€”next evening I was taken to the station, and picked him out from I tight or nine others.

JAMES FOLEY (Detective R). I received a description from Driscoll and took the prisoner on the 2ndâ€”I took Driscoll to the station and he was shown the prisoner with five or six others, and he identified him in a momentâ€”when I told the prisoner the charge he said "You make a mistake, I know nothing of it"â€”I had seen him about 100 yards from the shop on the 1st, near on 9 o'clock, just about the time the things were missing.
Prisoners Defence. The boy is swearing false to me; the person he saw is now doing one month at Wandsworth, and he sold the things for 6s.
NOT GUILTY .

582.
MARY LETTON (22)
Stealing a purse and 11l. 10s. of
Peter Goodall, from his person.

PETER GOODALL . I am a printer and live in Molyneaux Roadâ€”on Saturday afternoon, 19th April, about 5 o'clock, I was in Woolwichâ€”I had two 5l. notes, 1l. in gold, and some silverâ€”I went into the Coach and Horsesâ€”I did not go there with a womanâ€”I do not recollect any particular persons there except a man calling himself Newton, who introduced himself as an old friendâ€”this money was in one purse, I was using another purse for what I was spendingâ€”I missed the purse and money later in the evening, near 10 o'clock, as I was going home in the ferryâ€”I was in another public-house after leaving the Coach and Hones; in felt myself I was in such a state I did not wish to be in the streetâ€”previous to going there I went into an eating-house and had some tea, and I believe the prisoner was there, so I have been toldâ€”on the Monday a policeman showed me my purse in which the money had beenâ€”I was in no house but the eating-house with a woman, or in front of the bar, not for any immoral purpose.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I do not recollect wanting you to go home and live with me; or wanting to buy you a pair of bootsâ€”I do not remember putting the purse into your hand and asking you to stay with me till Mondayâ€”there was another woman in my company before you; that was a long time previousâ€”my drunkenness came on all of a moment, from what cause I don't know.

GEORGE FLEW . I am landlord of the Coach and Horses, in High Street, Woolwichâ€”on Saturday afternoon, 19th April, I saw the prosecutor and prisoner there in company with a man who said his name was Newtonâ€”they were there 10 or 20'minutesâ€”the prosecutor was drunk, the prisoner was soberâ€”I served him with some ginger-beer, I would not let him have anything else; he wanted something elseâ€”they all three left together; Newton went to the right and the prisoner and prosecutor went about 30 yards across the road to some dining-roomsâ€”in about three-quarters of an hour the prisoner cam. back to my houseâ€”she' showed me two 5l. notes and asked me whether they were good; I said I believed they wereâ€”she said would I change oneâ€”I said "How did you come by them?"â€”she said "The gentleman you saw me with a little time ago gave them to me"â€”I said "You fetch the gentleman and I will change one"â€”she did not bring him and I did not give her any changeâ€”I handed the notes back to her.

ENOCH HUNT (Policeman R R 34). I received information and about 11 o'clock that same evening I met the prisoner in High Streetâ€”I told her I should take her into custody for stealing two 5l. notes and some gold from the prosecutorâ€”she said "What about notes, I have seen none?"â€”I said "Yes you have, you must accompany me to the police-station"â€”she then said "I had the notes, they were no good, I broke them up and burnt them"â€”the prosecutor was with me at the time, she pointed to him and said "That is the man I had the notes from"â€”the prosecutor was quite stupefied.

SUSAN CRONIN . I am female searcher at the Woolwich Police-stationâ€”I searched the prisoner when she was brought thereâ€”I found in her bosom this purse containing 1l. 9s. 4d., and 15s. 7d. in her stockingâ€”I gave it to the inspector and the prosecutor identified it.
NOT GUILTY .

583.
HENRY BASTABLE (36)
PLEADED GUILTY to feloniously marrying
Henrietta Reason, his wife being then alive.â€”
One Month's Imprisonment.

584.
HENRY WILLIAM BURCHELL (29)
PLEADED GUILTY to forging a certain Hackney carriage licence.â€”
Four Days' Imprisonment.

585.
FRANCIS EAGLES (29)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Allen, and stealing therein two coats and other articles.

MARY ALLEN . I live at 10, Methley Street, Kennington Parkâ€”at 5.45 on the 23rd April I was aroused by the policeâ€”I went downstairs, and missed stockings and boots, two coats, and a pair of spectacles, which were all safe in the kitchen at 12 o'clock on the previous nightâ€”the kitchen window was shut at nightâ€”I went to bed at 12.30â€”this coat (produced) is a part of the property.

FREDERICK COLE . I live at 14, Methley Streetâ€”at the time in question I was in bed, and was aroused by a heavy footfall in the yardâ€”I lifted the corner of my blind, and looked out, and saw the prisoner on the wall which divides the two houses, with a sack in his handâ€”I slipped on my trousers and a pair of slippers, and went downâ€”I missed the landlady's whitewash brushâ€”I went out and saw the prisoner in Mrs. Allen's garden crouching down by the flower bedâ€”I asked him what he was doing in the garden that time of the morning, and he said "Nothing"â€”I said "You be dâ€”â€”d for a tale; you are doing no good in the garden this time of the morning"â€”he climbed over the wall, and I ran along the wall at the end of our garden, and running along Mrs. Allen's wall I did not notice the glass on the wall, and I cut my foot, and I had to take the glass out, and lost sight of the prisonerâ€”I afterwards went to Kennington Cross, and spoke to a constable off duty by a coffee stallâ€”we found the sack in one of the gardens, contain
ing bacon, dripping, butter, eggs, and several other articles, which the police took possession of.
WALTER NEWPORT . I am assistant to Mr. Scudamore, pawnbrokerâ€”this coat was pledged on the 23rd April in the name of John Levy for 3s.â€”I do not remember the person.
JOSEPH CHEKE (Policeman P 264). I apprehended the prisoner on the 3rd inst. at 3, Lion Street, New Kent Roadâ€”I found four duplicates on him, one relating to this coat.
Prisoner's Defence. People buy tickets of others. How can I speak on my own behalf. I have no one to call.

GUILTY .** He also
PLEADED GUILTY to having been convicted of felony in May, 1873.â€”
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.

586.
HENRY ALLCROFT (25)
, Feloniously and carnally knowing and abusing
Elizabeth Watkinson.
NOT GUILTY .

587.
HENRY STANBOROUGH (38) and
ABRAHAM DOWNTON (54) were indicted,
Stanborough for unlawfully selling divers property, the goods of his creditors, and
Downton for aiding and abetting him. Other Counts for conspiracy.
MESSRS. BESLEY and TICKELL Prosecuted; MR. HORACE AYORY Defended.
Stanborough and MR. FULTON Downton.

HENRY ALFRED STACEY . I am Superintendent of Records to the Bank
ruptcy Court, Lincoln's Inn Fieldsâ€”I produce the bankruptcy proceedings with reference to Henry Stanboroughâ€”the petition is dated 2nd November, 1878, by Brown and Sons, of Half Moon Passage, Whitechapel, provision merchantsâ€”Stanborough is described as late of 119, High Street, Peckham, and 7, Middle Street, Sumner Road, Peckham, cheesemongerâ€”the peti
tioner's debt is 80l. 16s. 8d. for goods soldâ€”the act of bankruptcy was departing from his place of business, with intent to defeat and delay his creditorsâ€”he was adjudged bankrupt on 8th November, 1878â€”there is a transcript of the examination of Stanborough on 13th January, 1879, and of Downton on 22nd January, 1879â€”a statement of affairs, dated 27th November, 1878, filed by the bankrupt on 13th January, 1879â€”the assets are nil and creditors unsecured 294l. 16s. 1d.â€”Downton's name is not in the list of creditors.
Cross-examined by MR. AVORY. The trustee was appointed on 27th November, 1878.
Cross-examined by MR. FULTON. It nowhere appears on the proceedings when these debts were contracted.

Re-examined. There are 19 creditors disclosed altogether, making 294l.; 17 of them are under 257.; the debt of Brown and Sons is 80l. and Ford's 60l.â€”Brown's was for goods supplied in September, 1878. (Charles Leggatt Barber and Michael McCart, shorthand writers, proved the exami
nations of the defendants at the Bankruptcy Court.)

FREDERICK HARRIS . I am clerk to Messrs. Keen and Marsland, solicitors, of Mark Laneâ€”they are solicitors to Mr. Fordâ€”I produce the writ and judgment in an action of Ford v. Stanboroughâ€”the writ is dated 9th October, 1878, and the judgment the 22nd October, 1878, and the amount of the judgment is 60l. 1s. 6d.â€”the claim was in respect of a bill of exchange given for goods soldâ€”the Sheriff seized, and 8l. 2s. was realised.

GEORGE CHESMAN CORRY . I am traveller to Messrs. George Brown and Sons, provisions merchants, of Half Moon Passage, Whitechapel, who appear in the fist of creditors for 80l. 16s. 8d.â€”the goods were supplied in

August and September, 1878â€”on 23rd October, 1878, between 12 and 1 in the day, by my principal's instructions I went to 110, High Street, Peckhamâ€”I found the shop closed; I endeavoured to get admission, but could notâ€”at that time about 20l. or 30l. was owingâ€”in consequence of inquiries I made I went to 7, Middle Street; I saw a van at the door; that was the removal of the furniture under the marriage settlementâ€”I could not ascer
tain where the bankrupt was on that occasion.
WILLIAM PRAGNALL . I reside at 56, Marlborough Road, Peckhamâ€”I am manager of the business of Robert Angel Freeman, who has since died.

(The deposition of Mr. Freeman was read which stated that he had purchased from Downton for 50l. the stock and fixtures of 119, High Street, Peckham.) I was present when the contract was madeâ€”it was arranged that I should go in and manage the business for Mr. Freemanâ€”I have since paid Mr. Graham, the landlord, the rent.
Cross-examined by MR. FULTON. I have known Downton seven or eight yearsâ€”I never knew anything against himâ€”he was traveller to Lascelles, Merry, and Co.

EDWIN CHARLES GARNHAM . Stanborough took possession of the shop under this agreement, and opened it as a cheesemonger'sâ€”I allowed Mr. Freeman to become the tenant from Octoberâ€”I saw the stock taken away and the shop closed.

FREDERICK WOOD . I live at 9, Short's Buildings, Clerkenwell, and am carman to Mr. Tripp, a master carmanâ€”I went to 119, High Street, Peckhamâ€”I don't know on what dayâ€”I met Downton and some gentle
men at the gateâ€”Downton engaged meâ€”it was about 10 or 11 o'clock when we startedâ€”we did not go to 119, High Street; we stopped at the public-houseâ€”I did not go to the front, I went to the back, up a court out of the High Streetâ€”Downton showed me the way to goâ€”I saw Stanborough while I was thereâ€”the things were brought down the passage and put in the van, and we took them to Mr. Sutton's, in St. John's Lane, and the goods were unloaded in his shop.
Cross-examined by MR. AVORY. Stanborough said nothing to me about any goods.
Cross-examined by MR. FULTON. The goods were taken out the back way for convenience, because they should not interrupt customers in frontâ€”I never went to the front at all.
By the COURT. Stanborough saw the goods come out.

GEORGE FREDERICK SUTTON . I live at 11, Madras Terrace, Liverpool Roadâ€”I am in the provision tradeâ€”I was living in St. John's Laneâ€”I occupied it for about six monthsâ€”I gave it up two or three months sinceâ€”I have no other warehouseâ€”I am a lodger, at present, out of businessâ€”I frequently saw Downtonâ€”I think I saw him the day the goods were deliveredâ€”after they had been delivered I saw him nearly every day; he spoke about some cheesesâ€”I was under the impression that he was going to send me some goodsâ€”he said, "When you have seen them you can put a price on themâ€”he did not tell me to whom they belongedâ€”I thought they belonged to himselfâ€”they were brought in a van on October 22ndâ€”I sent a copy, of the goods I bought to Messrs. Carter and Bell (the total amount of this was 57l.178. 2d.)â€”I agreed to buy at that priceâ€”I paid nothing on that occasionâ€”the goods were left with meâ€”I gave him a cheque for 10l. on account a weekor 10 days, afterwards, and another for 2l.10s.â€”I think he had two cheques and two bills, making 57l.â€”I have not paid any money in respect of the bills; they were due on March 1stâ€”they were drawn on October 26th at four monthsâ€”they were presented for payment when I was outâ€”there is no drawer's name to one of them.

Cross-examined by MR. AVORY. I did not dishonour the bills on account of the informality of their being drawn on February 29th; I had not the meansâ€”the bill that has no drawer's name to it is for 20l. 0s. 8d.â€”I think Stanborough said that was to be paid at Messrs. Lascelles, Merry, and Co.

Cross-examined by MR. FULTON. I knew that they were Downton's employersâ€”I had done business with them through Downton several timesâ€”he had been in the habit of calling on us for themâ€”I have done lots of business with Downton besides this itemâ€”I think he told me when he gave me the bills that part of the money was due to himself and Stanborough, and part was due from Stanborough to Lascelles, Merry, and Co.â€”I know the bill was to be paid at Lascelles's, and that was the reason the blank was left, in order that Lascelles might fill in the name as drawers.

GEORGE WILLIAM LOUIS BUCKLAND . I am clerk to Messrs. Lascelles, Merry, and Co., provision merchants, 49, Lombard Streetâ€”Downton has been acting as a servant of theirs close upon a yearâ€”I have known him for the last five years; he was some years previously in the employ of Merry and Son, and he was taken on by Lascelles and Merryâ€”I have heard that he bought goods on his own account and sold themâ€”on 1st October, 1878, there was a debt due by Stanborough to our firm of 20l. 0s. 8d.â€”this bill was never formally given over into our hands, but we knew of its existenceâ€”when we heard that Stanborough was going wrong I spoke to Downton, and he said he held a bill for us; that was about the end of Octoberâ€”he said he had taken means to secure our debt, and that he would bring the money for it as soon as a certain bill became dueâ€”I told him to hold the bill till it became dueâ€”I did not know at that time that he had closed his shop and moved his furniture, or that there was a petition in bankruptcy and a seizure by the Sheriffâ€”I heard that Stanborough had filed his petition; that was all I heardâ€”I did not get any money on 1st Marchâ€”I have never had possessoin of the bill; except in Downton's hands acting as agent for us we did not prove in bankruptcyâ€”we have not had the money.

ROBERT FORD . I am the trustee of this estateâ€”I was plaintiff in an action of Ford v. Stanborough for goods supplied to him on 2nd August, 1878â€”in payment for those goods he gave me this acceptance for 59l. 18s. 8d., on which I brought the actionâ€”since I have been trustee he has not handed over to me any goods or property whateverâ€”the first time I heard of the stock being removed and the lease being sold was at the examination at the Bankruptcy Courtâ€”he has given me no books or invoicesâ€”I have not applied for invoices since the examinationâ€”I visited the shop on Saturday, the 18thâ€”I then saw him doing business there; a good many persons were in the shop, and as far as I could judge there was stock there worth from 60l. to 80l.; I passed by it three times.

Cross-examined by MR. AVORY. The Sheriff levied on the furniture for us; I have no knowledge of what he recovered; our solicitor said that about 2l. would be coming to me after the expenses were paidâ€”I have not had the 2l. yetâ€”I was appointed trustee on 27th Novemberâ€”I have no parti
cular reason to believe that Stanborough ever had any booksâ€”the stock was sold far 57l. to Mr. Suttonâ€”I would not say it was worth more.

Cross-examined by MR. FULTON. I did not inform Downton that if he paid 107l. 15s. I should be satisfiedâ€”I never instructed such a communica
tion to be made to himâ€”Carter and Bell were solicitors for the bankruptcy, not my solicitors, but being trustee I suppose they were nominally acting for meâ€”I know of no letter of 3rd January, 1879, from them to Downton; I suppose they were acting for Brown and Sons, the largest creditors.

WILLIAM CARTER . I am one of the firm of Carter and Bellâ€”we are solicitors to Messrs. Thomas Brown and Co., and have acted in the bank
ruptcy proceedings from the time the proceedings were taken in the Bankruptcy Courtâ€”we are acting as agents for the Treasury in this prosecu
tionâ€”there is no foundation for any suggestion that there was at any time any desire or intention to take money from Downton to stop the prosecutionâ€”after his examination, and the disclosure of the 57l. 15s. 5d. and 50l. we required payment of the money, and did not get it.

Cross-examined by MR. F. FULTON. Downton's examination was on the 22nd of Januaryâ€”this letter is signed by me for my firm. (Read: "30th January, 1879. Sir,â€”Re Henry Stanborough. The trustee is advised that the steps you took in relation to the business of the bankrupt as to selling the goodwill for 50l., and the stock for 57l. 15s. 5d., were not lawful as against the creditors, and we have therefore to apply to you for the pay
ment of 107l. 15s. 5d., and if not paid to move the Court in respect thereof. Will you be good enough to say whether you are prepared to pay this to the trustee, or any part thereof? Signed, Carter and Bell.") Mr. Cooper Willis advised that the money belonged to the creditorsâ€”the trustee is not informed of every step taken in bankruptcy; we hold his retainer, and we do what is necessaryâ€”the letter was written in consequence of Mr. Cooper Willis's adviceâ€”Mr. Downton was first examined at great length, and then on the 30th we wrote that letterâ€”the order for this prosecution was dated the 7th March.

Re-examined. This is the answer to our letter of the 30th January. (Read: "4th February, 1879. Messrs. Carter and Bell, re Stanborough. In reply to your request for the payment of the sum of 106l. 15s. 5d. by me to the trustee of the above estate, I beg to say I am not prepared to pay that or any other sum. A. Downton.") The application to the Court was by the advice of Mr. Willis to apply in the Bankruptcy Court to get the moneyâ€”on getting Downton's letter we proceeded to the Court, and took their directions upon the whole matterâ€”there was no view at all of getting money for the purpose of stifling the prosecution.

GUILTY . STANBOROUGHâ€”
Three Months' Imprisonment.

DOWN
TONâ€”
Two Months' Imprisonment.

588.
EMMA LEONARD (13)
, Feloniously setting fire to a house belong
ing to
Frederick Laughton with intent to injure him, persons being therein.
MR. HIND Prosecuted; MR. LILLEY Defended.

FREDERICK LAUGHTON . I am a railway clerk, and live at 47, Bird-in-Bush Road, Peckhamâ€”the prisoner was in my employâ€”I had been to church on Sunday evening, May 11th; I came home about 9 o'clock with some friends, and there were other persona in the houseâ€”when we got home the prisoner and her sister, and my wife and Mrs. Dawson, Mr. and Mrs. Morton, and Mrs. Fitter and her childâ€”they came to supper

with me, and when they were about to leave, a smell of burning was dis
covered, and one of them went upstairs to a bedroomâ€”I then went up, and saw the bed in flames, and the room full of smoke; I called for water; the prisoner brought it, and with assistance I put the fire out; no fire had been lighted in that roomâ€”two of my friends then left, and about an hour afterwards some drawers were found burning in the breakfast-room; they were extinguished, and about an hour or an hour and a half afterwards a third fire was discovered in the breakfast-room in the book-case; Mr. Morton and I put it out, and about a quarter of an hour afterwards a fourth fire was discovered; some wadding was burning: that was extinguished, and about half an hour after that a fifth fire was dis
covered by the side of the breakfast-room; two table napkins were found to be on fire, that also was extinguishedâ€”about 9.30 a. in. a sixth fire was dis
covered in a bedroom, some ladies' wearing apparel was on fire, and the shelvesâ€”that was extinguished by the Rev. Mr. Hazell, and no further fires occurredâ€”the prisoner was sent out once on the Sunday evening, but not by meâ€”she was in the house on the Monday morningâ€”I asked her on the Sunday evening if she knew whether there were any candles in the houseâ€”she said "No"â€”I did not say anything to her about the fires on the Sunday evening.

Cross-examined. I did'not go out at the same time as she did, but Mr. Morton didâ€”she went to church and returned about 8.30, or probably a little later; she returned before me with her sisterâ€”I had been in the house two hours before an alarm of tire was given, that brought it up nearly to 11 o'clockâ€”Mrs. Dawson was the first person to go upstairs and discover the fireâ€”I had two men in to help extinguish it, and gave them some refresh
ment and some moneyâ€”I gave them two bob and said that I would give them two more when I got the insuranceâ€”I was up all night, and the persons I have mentioned were all there except Mrs. Fitter and the childâ€”the prisoner went out for a policemanâ€”I do not know who sent herâ€”I have heard that she is only 13 years oldâ€”there has been no altercation between her and I, nor with my wife to my knowledgeâ€”I had not lighted a fire myself in the grate in the breakfast-room when I came home from church, and I do not believe that there was one then, but there was one about 4 o'clock in the morningâ€”I recollect coming down and finding the prisoner apparently asleep in the room filled with smoke, and I said to her "There is another fire, and in another five minutes you would have been suffocated, and you would have looked a pretty dear"â€”I told her about 8 o'clock in the morn
ing to go and empty the slops in my bedroom, I was then in the breakfast-roomâ€”I did not stand on the stairs while she went upâ€”my bedroom is on the first floor; there is a second floorâ€”I told her to empty the slops as quickly as possible and to come down to the kitchenâ€”I told her at some time in the morning to go to bedâ€”she came down again before 8 o'clockâ€”I don't think she said she was so frightened she could not sleepâ€”my wife was upâ€”I do not know, whether the prisoner spoke to my wife during the nightâ€”I had told her from time to time to keep a look-out in case there was another fire, and to have a pail of water in readinessâ€”Mr. Morton, I believe, went out for a policeman about 3 o'clockâ€”I removed the burning wadding into the garden, saying that I was afraid of it; I said "This is the stuff that is doing the fire"â€”the prisoner slept at the top of the houseâ€”she had a lamp in her room which she used to light when she got up thereâ€”I provided her with the same kind of matches which I useâ€”I sent her to bed
before 7, and she came down about 8â€”I did not observe the time, she was upstairs, but about three hoursâ€”I laid down in the drawing-room, but did not go to sleep, at the time she was sent to bed.
Re-examined. Mr. Morton and the prisoner went out for a policeman at the same time, and they came back together.

ROBERT MORTON . I live at 168, Camden Grove, North Peckham, and am an outfitter's managerâ€”on Sunday evening I went to Mr. Laughton'e house after churchâ€”I know the prisoner, her sister is in my serviceâ€”we had supper about 9.30, and when I was leaving, about 10.45, Mrs. Dawson called outâ€”there was an alarm of fireâ€”I ran upstairs and found the bed on fire and the room full of smokeâ€”I called out for Mr. Laughton and to the prisoner to bring some waterâ€”she brought some, and with the assistance of some men who came on hearing the shouts, we extinguished the, fire; the men went down and had some refreshment and leftâ€”in about an hour after
wards we were downstairs in the breakfast-room, every one except the prisoner, who, I believe, was in the kitchen, and there was the smell of burnt paperâ€”I found a cupboard in the basement in flames, the flames were coming from under the doorâ€”I called to Mr. Laughton, who was at the top of the house, to make haste, as there was another fireâ€”I got a pail of water and threw it under the door; he opened the door and throw a second pail of water inâ€”we put the fire outâ€”a muslin dress was burning, to the best of my judgmentâ€”after that every one but the prisoner went upstairs to the parlour, and while we were sitting there the prisoner's sister left, and I sent to tell the prisoner to go to bedâ€”on my return I saw more smoke coming from the breakfast-roomâ€”I ran upstairs and saw the prisoner sitting in the breakfast-room near the fireplaceâ€”the room was full of smoke, and a flame was coming from the book-caseâ€”I believe she had been told to light a fire in the breakfast-room, but I do not know; that fire was put out, and Mr. Laughton and myself said to the prisoner "You had better have some water about the place in case any other fire should break out"â€”she went to the right and I to the left, and when I returned she went downstairs and then called out, "Oh, here is something burning"â€”she was then in the break-fast-roomâ€”I ran down, and some wadding was burning in a cupboard in the breakfast-roomâ€”I threw some water over it and put it outâ€”the breakfast-room is in the basementâ€”a few minutes afterwards she gave the alarm that another cupboard was burning in the same roomâ€”I ran down, opened the door, and saw a blaze and smokeâ€”I poured some water into it, and after it was out we discovered two or three table-napkins which had been used during the day, burningâ€”the shelf was burned, and so was the doorâ€”a pail of water soon extinguished that, and I said in the prisoner's presence, "This is a very serious affair, have you any idea of the cause of these fires?"â€”she said, "No; I know nothing about it"â€”I said, "Do you think somebody set fire to the house?"â€”she said, "I don't know"â€”I said, "What do you think ought to be done to them?"â€”she said, "Their place ought to be set on fire"â€”I said, "Supposing they have no place to set on fire?"â€”she said, "Then they ought to be in prison"â€”I went out again for a constable, and brought one back to the house.
Cross-examined. I did not return from church with the prosecutorâ€”I went in with my wife about 8.40â€”the prisoner was then there.

By the COURT. I do not know whether the prisoner was shamming to be asleep; she was sitting with her back to meâ€”I thought possibly she might before what made me say "apparently "was, Mr. Laughton shook
her, and if she had been awake I think she would have called outâ€”I did not intend to convey the impression that she was shamming.

REV. JAMES HENRY HAZELL . I live at the Vicarage, Bird-in-Bush Road, peckhamâ€”the prosecutor is one of my parishionersâ€”on Monday, 12th May, at 9 a.m., he called on me, bringing a message from Mr. Laughton and asking me to go and see himâ€”I went, and Mr. Laughton took me in and explained about the fires, and then showed me the destruction in Mrs. Laughton's bedroomâ€”I went down to the basement and found Mrs. Dawson and her sister sitting at breakfastâ€”I examined various cupboards and remained in the house about 20 minutes, during which time the door of the breakfast-room was open, also the kitchen door on the opposite side of the passageâ€”the prisoner was in the kitchen, and Mr. Lawson, who appeared very agitated, kept saying "Now I must keep a good look-out; get water ready"â€”the prisoner went upstairs, and I believe before I left, returned to the basementâ€”about 9.30 I was leaving, and Mr. Lawson showed me upstairs and we found the house filling with smokeâ€”I ran and got water, went to Mr. Lawson's bedroom, and found a fire in the hanging cupboard and some dresses on the shelf were burningâ€”the fire was on the shelf and the Wood was burning, but it had caught the dresses hanging belowâ€”we managed to put it outâ€”there was nothing to show how it had caught fireâ€”I did not notice whether there were any ashes on the shelf.
Cross-examined. Mrs. Dawson was in the breakfast room the whole timeâ€”when I went upstairs I think the prisoner had come down, and there was nobody at the top of the house at all.
By the COURT. I saw her go upstairs and heard her move about upstairsâ€”I cannot say whether she went higher than the room above me.

GEORGE YOUNG (Policeman P.R. 3). On Monday, 12th May, about noon, I went to 47, Birdi-n-Bush Road, and saw Mr. and Mrs. Lawson, Mrs. Dawson, a policeman, and a firemanâ€”I examined the premises and found several fires had occurred in different parts of the houseâ€”I saw the prisoner there and asked Mr. Lawson in her presence whether he was sure no one had been into the room except the prisoner when the last fire occurredâ€”he said he was sure notâ€”I searched the prisoner's room and found about 20 burnt matches on the floor and tableâ€”she was not there, she was dawn in the breakfast-roomâ€”I went down and said to her "When you went up into the rooms did you see any fires?"â€”she did not reply for some con
siderable time, and then she said "No"â€”she was then charged, and On the way to the station she said "I was sitting up with Mr. Morton to see if any more fires would break out; I know nothing about it."

Cross-examined. I did not say before the Magistrate that she was a con
siderable time before she answeredâ€”she was given in custody about midday on the Mondayâ€”I did not see a lamp in her room.

THOMAS DURRANT (Policeman P 45). On May 12, about 1 o'clock, I went to 47, Bird-in-Bush Roadâ€”I found this box on the table in the prisoner's bedroom and these matches partially consumed, and in the prosecutor's bed-room, where the last fire occurred, one match partly consumed under the foot of the iron bedstead at the centreâ€”that is a front bedroomâ€”I took the box down stairs, showed it to the prisoner, and said "I found these in your bedroom," opening the boxâ€”she said "Yes, I know those matches were there; I have been in the habit of placing them there after I have lighted my lamp at night when I go to bedâ€”she was then taken in custody.
Cross-examined. I saw no match-box in the room.

GEORGE DUCK . I am an officer of the Metropolitan Fire Brigadeâ€”I was called at 10.13 a.m., and found that there had been six distinct fires, but could find nothing to connect themâ€”the prisoner was brought up, and I asked her if she had been into any of those rooms with matches, and she said "No"â€”I said "Did you do anything in your master's room that morning?"â€”she said "No, I have not been there"â€”I said "Have not you been there to empty the slops I"â€”she said "Yes, but only with the pail"â€”I said "Did you go to the cupboard for anything"â€”she said "No"â€”I asked her if she had been into the room where the fire was, on the previous night with a candle, as I believed the fire originated with the bed curtains. and I wanted to find out whether she had been there with a candle to look for anythingâ€”she denied having been there at allâ€”I then left the house.
NOT GUILTY .

589.
THOMAS SIMMONDS (34)
PLEADED GUILTY to a conspiracy with
John Simmonds, and obtaining goods by false pretences from
Patrick Flinn and others.â€”
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.

590.
GEORGE THOMAS RUSSELL (50)
, Indecently assaulting
Clara Brown , and
attempting suicide.â€”MR. CUNNINGHAM Prosecuted.â€”
GUILTY. Recommended to mercy on account of his inebriated condition. â€”
Four Months' Imprisonment.

591.
THOMAS RICHARD RICE STACK (40)
, Feloniously marrying
Ann Caroline Adlum,
Elizabeth Ann his wife being alive.

RICHARD FAUGHT . I have been clerk and sexton of St. James's Church, Dublin, since 1846, and was present at the marriage of Thomas Richard Stack and Elizabeth Ann Lynch at that church on 19th May, 1863â€”the prisoner is the manâ€”I have examined this certified copy with the registerâ€”it is correct (Read).

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I knew you shortly before your marriageâ€”I first heard of this some few months ago when you were in custodyâ€”a correspondence was carried on with the vicar, the Rev. Mr. Tomlinson, and myself, I understand by your second wifeâ€”I visited the asylum about 30th April with the policeman Flanaghan and Mr. Lynch, and saw the woman who was pointed out as your wife, but I could not recognise herâ€”she was brought out aloneâ€”Mr. Lynch did not seem to have any difficulty in recog
nising herâ€”I recognised you in the cells at Lambeth Police-court, and you recognised me and shook hands with meâ€”I came alone to see you by my own requestâ€”I believe Lynch was not brought over to identify you, and I do not think he asked me about youâ€”we had no conversation about the caseâ€”I saw you at my own requestâ€”you asked me at Dublin if I ever heard anything against your character, and I said that you bore the character of a respectable man.
Re-examined. I know nothing personally of him since he was at Dublin.

JAMES FLANAGHAN (Policeman L 23). I went to Dublin and obtained from the Registrar General's District Office, South Dublin, the copy certificate produced, which I examined with the Register, and it is correct. (This certified the marriage of Thomas Richard Shark, a bachelor, and Elizabeth Ann Lynch, spinster, at St. James's Parish Church, Dublin, on May 19th, 1863.)

EDWARD LYNCH . I live at 26, Lower Gardner Street, Dublin, and know the prisoner by sightâ€”he was married to my sister, Elizabeth Ann Lynch, and I saw him with her shortly afterwardsâ€”I was then living at 69, Marl
borough Street, Dublinâ€”I think my sister wrote to say that she would call and introduce her husband, and she did soâ€”I saw them afterwards on two or three occasions walking together in Dublinâ€”on 30th April last I went to the lunatic asylum at Brookwood, Surrey, and there saw my sister alive and in bodily healthâ€”she was living at Dolphin's Barn, Dublin, after her marriage.

Cross-examined. I shall be 52 next Julyâ€”I first heard of this case on April 28th, but the first correspondence was three or four months agoâ€”I do not know in what name the letter was signedâ€”I understood it to be from your second wifeâ€”I am a solicitor's clerkâ€”I cannot remember the writer of the letter I receivedâ€”my sister Was not with other women when I saw her at the lunatic asylumâ€”I said to her, "Elizabeth, don't you know me?"â€”she turned her head an. evidently recognised meâ€”she said nothingâ€”I did not tell her I was her brother Edward, because I saw she recognised meâ€”I had no difficulty in recognising herâ€”I knew by conver
sation or by letter from her that my sister lived at Dolphin's Barn with you after your marriage, but do not know how longâ€”I never visited her there, and have not those letters with meâ€”I believe I saw you at my house with my sister three or four days after your marriageâ€”I cannot give the dateâ€”I saw you together in the streets three or four times afterâ€”I might possibly be mistaken as to your being at my houseâ€”I saw you last near the Bank of Irelandâ€”I have been to the Treasuryâ€”I could have picked you out from 20 menâ€”I was not in London when Mr. Faught went to see youâ€”I was with him at Lambeth Police-court, but was not asked to go and recognise you and did not volunteer to goâ€”I do not think you have been in my company more than 20 or 30 minutes, and then you had a conversation with meâ€”I knew nothing of Caroline Adlum before I left Dublin.

ANN CAROLINE ADLUM .
