I am now staying at 72, Regent Street, Lambeth Walkâ€”I was married to the prisoner on March 21st, 1878, at the Parish Church, Kennington, Surreyâ€”he told me that his wife had been dead 10 1/2 years, and that he had a boyâ€”he left London and went to Cambridge, and I went there in October last, and ascertained that he was a married manâ€”I at once communicated with him, and subsequently obtained a warrant for his arrestâ€”I sent to Ireland to make inquiries, and subsequently com
municated with the Secretary of State for the Home Department, and he referred me to the Treasury.

Cross-examined. I live now at 72, Regent Street, Lambeth Walkâ€”I have not finally left Stetchworthâ€”your property is at 72, Regent Street, Lambeth Walk; I do not refuse to give it upâ€”I did not give it up when demanded because it was not demanded in a proper wayâ€”I wrote to you offering to forego this trial if you would acknowledge the woman as your wife, and you would not accept itâ€”the letter has been handed to the Treasury and is in Courtâ€”your answer was "The poor helpless lunatic you have seen has no claim upon me, and if she has she will never be able to exercise it"â€”when I wrote to you in Cambridge prison I did not give you

the Christian name of the woman at the asylum, but I told you I had found the Dublin paper among your books containing the announcement of your marriageâ€”I had no difficulty in finding itâ€”the box was always open and had no key, but I was not supposed to go to itâ€”I did not know there were three, or four Mrs. Stacks at the asylumâ€”I have your letter of 23rd April, 1879. (This letter contained an assurance that he believed his former wife to have died in a lunatic asylum, and begged the second wife to withdraw from the prosecution.) I produce a certificate. (This certified a marriage at the parish church, Kennington, on 27th March, 1878, between Thomas Richard Mice Stack, widower, and Ann Caroline Adlum, spinster.) You crime to my house on 11th February, 1878, and inquired for lodgingsâ€”you were then engaged at Doughty Street Schoolsâ€”you came next day, and the marriage took place about five weeks afterwardsâ€”there was a marriage settlement at my wish, settling the property on meâ€”I first heard your wife was living in July, 1878â€”you told me you were a widower' with one boy in his twelfth yearâ€”you said you were a widower 10 1/2 years, and your child was 15 months old when your wife died in childbed in Ireland, and that she and the baby were laid out togetherâ€”your only words were not "I am a widower, and my boy lost his mother when he was 15 months old"â€”nobody was present but my son, eight and a half years oldâ€”the only reason for our getting married so soon was that you were living in the houseâ€”I deny any other reasonâ€”I was known by the name of Mrs. Bartlett, and lived with a man of that name six yearsâ€”he wag 61 when he died and I was 35â€”he died at 72, Regent Street, Lambeth Walkâ€”my mother and family were ignorant of my connection with him till within a few days of his deathâ€”I went to my mother's as a married womanâ€”I knew Bartlett six or nine months before I lived with him; he was on board a ship at "Woolwich, and I was living at the West End, but cannot recollect the placeâ€”your six months' imprisonment was not on my accountâ€”I know nothing about a quarrel on 17th Juneâ€”I have no correspondence about itâ€”I went to Cambridge on 9th August with bail to take you outâ€”I told the jailer I did not believe the chargeâ€”I had not seen the evidence thenâ€”I went to the prison on 1st November and received 12l. from youâ€”I do not remember what I said about your wife being livingâ€”you said I was to have the 12l., and I spent it and put your child into the workhouse a few days after receiving the moneyâ€”I had no other moneyâ€”I remember going to the prison on 16th April last at Bedfordâ€”I did not tell the governor I was pennilessâ€”I gave you a bad character because you deserved itâ€”I wished to have you in safe custody so that I might be freed.

Re-examined. Before my marriage I told the prisoner of my connection with, Bartlettâ€”I procured bail for him at Cambridge and legal assistance to defend himâ€”he was charged with an indecent assault and convicted.

MARIA JULIEN . I keep a grocer's shop and private lodging-house, at 15, China Walk, Lambethâ€”you have lodged at my house frequentlyâ€”you told me in 1869 that your wife was in a lunatic asylum, but I have never seen herâ€”I knew the late Mr. Croudiss, and have seen him at my house with you, and have seen you go off in a cab together onceâ€”you were particular friends, and I have known you to go to the lunatic asylum several timesâ€”I remember your coming to London on a day's excursion in 1872 and spending the evening with Mr. Croudissâ€”I do not remember the month or where you wentâ€”I did not see you again till January, 1877, and I had not known

you visit the asylum after you came lastâ€”you told me in 1877 your wife was deadâ€”I often advised you to get married, and you said you did not care about it after the firstâ€”I remember your getting a telegram on a Saturday evening in January, 1877, while at my house, and you had to travel on the Sunday in consequence, and took the child with youâ€”I saw the telegram, but do not know where you had to go toâ€”I do not remember whether it was to a school in Sussexâ€”you were at my house on your return and complained of being illâ€”I do not remember whether you were absent from London the greater part of 1877â€”I have known you about 10 years, and have always found you straightforward, honest, and respectable.

JAMES STURGE BIGGS . I am the superintendent and physician of the Surrey County Lunatic Asylum, Wandsworthâ€”I have been there more than 20 years, and have been superintendent nearly seventeen yearsâ€”I remember Elizabeth Ann Stack being admitted in November, 1869â€”there were two other Mrs. Stacks there at that time, and both named Mary; but none were admitted after that I rememberâ€”one of them came from Horsemonger Lane Gaol, and the other was the wife of James Stack, a policeman at Camber
well think I have seen you at the asylum some years ago, and have received a great many letters from you making inquiries about your wife's healthâ€”the last I have any record of was in 1872 when your address was altered from Droughton-in-Furness to Bilton, Rugbyâ€”I do not remember your calling in 1872 and asking me to allow your wife to have a little wineâ€”I do not remember your complaining of not getting replies to your letters in 1870, or my telling you to go to the post-office about it; I intent have done soâ€”you enclosed a stamped directed envelope with your letters, and done very particular in your inquiries about your, wife's healthâ€”I do, not remember seeing Ann Caroline Adlum at the asylum in 1878 inquiring for your wifeâ€”the last letter I remember receiving from you was from Bilton, Rugby.

JAMBS EDWARD BARTON . I am senior medical officer of the Surrey Lunatic Asylum at Brookwood, near. Woking Station, and have been there five yearsâ€”I have received a letter from you relative to Elizabeth. Ann Stack, to which this (produced) is my replyâ€”she was admitted on 6th December, 1875â€”I never saw you there, and you never wrote till 18th April.

WILLIAM CARTHEW DAVIE . I am master of the Lambeth Workhouse, and remember your being in the service of the Poor Law Guardians in 1879â€”you were not there in 1869â€”when you visited me Mrs. Adlum was with you, and you introduced her as your wifeâ€”-you stayed about 20 minutesâ€”I was not the master in 1869â€”your child may have been admitted in November, I cannot tell without the books.

The Prisoner in his defence staled that his first wife became insane in 1866, and after taking her to France and other places, and experiencing great trouble with her, and after being several times in a lunatic asylum, she was sent in 1869 to the Surrey Asylum, where he visited her constantly to 1872, and on his removal from London wrote for information concerning her health, until in 1874 he received information of her death; and that he believed her to be dead on his marrying the second wife.

p.rs: GUILTY.â€” Recommended to mercy by the Jury.â€”

div1.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JUNE 30TH, 1879.
